According to the police, the accused used the gun to shoot Wilson at Padanthalammoodu check-post near Kaliyikkavila in Kanyakumari district at night on January 8. After escaping from the crime scene on a bike, the duo came to Kochi in a KSRTC bus and reached the bus station here in the early hours of January 9.

They reportedly dumped the pistol in the water-filled drainage passing along the railway line near the bus station. The duo reportedly bought some newspaper from a shop in the station and read the news about the murder. It is suspected that they left for Uduppi from Kochi shortly after that.

“According to their statement, the same weapon was used to murder the officer. But we have to confirm it through forensic analysis. We are yet to know how they got the pistol. More details cannot be divulged as the investigation is still on,” said ASP Vishwesh.

The team had sought the support of Kochi Corporation and Ernakulam central police for the operation. Central police personnel were also present at the scene.

Title: Locomotives with GPS devices for real-time location of trains
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Allahabad: Boarding a train and finding out its exact location and status via apps is set to get easier.

In a nationwide exercise, Indian Railways is working on a project called Real-time Train Information System (RTIS) with Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO), wherein global positioning system (GPS) devices are being installed in electric locomotives . The project is being executed by Centre for Railway Information System (CRIS)

“In the first phase, 2,700 electric locomotives of IR have been fitted with RTIS including 115 locomotives of Electric loco shed, Kanpur of North Central Railway (NCR)”, said chief public relation officer (CPRO) NCR, Ajeet Kumar Singh. In the second phase, 4000 more electric locomotives of the country would be fitted with RTIS, he added.

Explaining on the present technology and how it would be upgraded, the CPRO says that at present whenever a train crosses any important station, the main server of CRIS is automatically gets updated but in the smaller stations, it is the station master who informs the control about the details of the train and the control feeds the same input to CRIS’s server.

“The major shortcoming was that although the passengers could get the location of a train in respect to major stations, they were in dark in respect to smaller stations. But, now as the locomotive would automatically transfer the information of its location at a real time basis—and the same would be refreshed every 30 seconds—any users, irrespective of the app he or she is using, will get the real time location of the train”, said Singh.

The system was on trial in the 2700 odd locomotives for couple of months and would be commissioned after around Three months following which the passengers can start using the real time information of a given train.

“Once fully implemented, information generated using RTIS will have more accurate location of trains and better forecast of arrival time. for enhanced convenience of passengers. It will also help in analysing actual running of each train in a particular section and will also come handy in pinpointing exact delays in section on various accounts. This will also enable our controllers to identify any abnormal stoppage of trains in section arising out of any emergency or incident so as requisite assistance is sent immediately”, said the CPRO.

Title: Housing society case: High court says why Telangana arguing against stand of its own special chief secretary
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Some plot owners of Bhagyanagar Housing Society , who had bought plots from the society’s land located between Kukatpally and Hi-Tec City in survey number 1007, on Thursday charged the Telangana government with going against the stand taken by its own special chief secretary (revenue).

Stating this before a bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy, plot owners’ counsel M V Durga Prasad said, “It is strange that the state is now arguing for registering this land in favour of third parties when its own special chief secretary filed a counter before the court that this land cannot be registered in favour of third parties.

The Special CS, in his affidavit, had stated that the persons claiming ownership over the parcel of land had failed to file the mandatory declaration under agricultural land reforms Act and hence the land cannot be transferred now.

The bench was dealing with three appeals filed by Prime Properties, Sri Siddharth Infratech and Services Limited and ACE HIBC Private Limited, who had challenged the order of the single judge. The judge had directed the registration department not to register land in favour of anyone till the title dispute, pending before a civil court, was finally adjudicated.

When Prime Properties tried to register the land in favour of third parties and presented the document to the registration department, the Kukatpally sub-registrar had earlier received the documents from the company and kept them pending. The single judge found fault with the sub-registrar, saying that even receiving documents for registration from “the company is unlawful because the company failed to file any declaration as required under the law”.

A legal wrangle on over the ownership of Rs 6,000-crore worth 119 acres of prime land situated between Kukatpally and Hi-Tec City area in survey number 1007. Two groups were fighting over the land and papers they produced claiming ownership show the alleged flow of title to them from two different owners. The bench posted the case to February 4 for further hearing.

The Supreme Court had earlier ordered status quo on the land and directed all parties to raise their contentions before the civil court, where the title suit was pending.

Title: Dehradun police launch hunt for promoter of club in forgery case
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

DEHRADUN: Dehradun police have launched a hunt to track down the promoter of an upscale private club in the city, Nazia Yusuf Izuddin, who is the sister-in-law of former Congress state president Kishore Upadhyay.

The move comes a few days after Izuddin's husband and Kishore Upadhyay's brother Sachin Upadhyay was arrested by police in connection with a forgery case. Police sources said that a city court has issued a non-bailable warrant against Izuddin as well but she is evading arrest and has become untraceable.

Speaking to TOI, Ajay Rautela, inspector general, Garhwal, said, “The court had issued a non-bailable warrant against her. Our teams are on a lookout and have been deployed at different places in Dehradun and Nainital to trace her.”

A police officer probing the forgery case, said that the couple would have to appear before the court that issued the non-bailable warrant against them for not joining the SIT probing the case. “Ideally, a person against whom a non-bailable warrant have been issued, does not get any relief from another court so we are expecting that she will surrender soon.”

Meanwhile, Sachin Upadhyay’s bail application which had come up for hearing on Wednesday in a judicial court in Dehradun was rejected. After his arrest earlier this week, Upadhyay was sent to a 14-day judicial custody.

Title: No tax hikes, VMC budget focuses on water supply
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Vadodara: The draft budget of the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) for the year 2020-21 was on expected lines – shying away from any tax hikes and muted on development.

A bulk of the big-ticket development works in the city will be dependent on grants and schemes. VMC commissioner Nalin Upadhyay presented the draft budget to the standing committee on Thursday morning.

With civic elections round the corner, it was widely expected that VMC will not impose any major hikes in taxes and charges for services. Against the proposed budget of Rs 3,554 crore last year, the proposed budget this year stood at Rs 3,770 crore. The civic body has proposed to take up development works amounting to Rs 1,621 crore.

The major development works proposed this year include seven flyovers that will be taken up with grants from the government. A new sports stadium in the Gotri area of the city has also been proposed by the civic body. A bulk of the other works pertain to services like water, sewage, storm water drains, street lights and others.

Another reason for the expectation was that the civic body had been drawing flak for supply of insufficient, turbid and contaminated water. In this situation, it would have found it very difficult to justify hikes and would have faced opposition.

Cash-strapped VMC is in dire need of resources to fuel any growth. With no hike in taxes, it seems to have had little room for including major development works in the project. Speaking after presenting the budget, Upadhyay said that the situation at the VMC was manageable without raising taxes. “We will be able to take up more development works as compared to last year,” he said.

Title: Startups put waste in recycle bin
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Hyderabad: TOI brings to you some unique startups participating in INK@WASH , a platform to promote innovations in waste & sanitation, organised by ASCI in association with the state and central governments on January 30 and 31

Title: Kerala: New outlets to give push for CNG vehicles
Content:
Representative image

KOCHI: The plan to convert more vehicles using petrol and diesel to those running on compressed natural gas ( CNG ) has picked up steam with the Indian Oil Adani Gas Private Limited (IOAGPL) preparing to roll out 12 more outlets in Kochi and its suburbs by March 31.As of now, there are seven CNG outlets in and around the city and the demand for the greener and more economic fuel has been going up.Officials with IOAGPL said the number of CNG vehicles in the city has been steadily growing. “Now, around 22,000kg CNG is dispensed from our outlets in and around the city a day. CNG use in the city has increased by around 2,500kg per month. So, we are sure that CNG penetration will further go up in the coming years. We are planning to roll out more CNG outlets,” said an official.Officials with the motor vehicles department (MVD) said they too would take measures to encourage more motorists to switch to CNG vehicles. “Around 250-300 new CNG vehicles are registered in the city every month. We are planning to give permits to 1,000 CNG autorickshaws to conduct service in the city. The vehicle owners should be city natives. Besides, there won’t be too many conditions for allotting city permits to the new batch of autorickshaws,” a senior official with Ernakulam regional transport office said.“As of now, auto drivers face long queues in front of the CNG outlets. Normally, autorickshaws conduct services in 3-5km radius. So, more outlets need to be set up within that limit,” the official said.Officials point out that the number of vehicles switching to CNG from diesel and petrol has not gone up as expected. “In the past two of years, when CNG outlets came up in the city, more than 1,000 vehicles, mostly cars, were converted into CNG. The number of such vehicles would have been much higher had the authorities been able to start more outlets to dispense the gas,” said K A Kunheed who runs a workshop where kits for CNG conversion are installed.“If the outlets come up across the state, there will be a leap in the number of vehicles running on CNG. It is during the long-distance trips that the vehicles get more mileage on CNG,” he said.According to MVD officials, the bad experience by those who switched to LPG from diesel and petrol also has had an impact on the prospects of conversion to CNG. “Proper and timely servicing of the conversion kits is key for maintaining the quality of the kits. Many of those who converted their vehicles to run on LPG a few years ago failed to conduct services on time. It led to snags, which forced many to go back to using diesel or petrol,” an MVD official said.Autorickshaw drivers are of the opinion that at least half of the autorickshaws in the city are running on CNG. “For filling the 5kg fuel tank of my autorickshaw, I have to pay just around Rs 285. As per the offer by the manufacturers (of CNG autos), 5kg fuel will give us a mileage of 280km. In reality, we get a mileage of 250km. Still, we spend only around Rs 1 per km. So, many are buying CNG autos or exchanging their old ones for CNG autos,” said Sadik, an auto driver in Kochi.

Title: Congress ex-MLA among 3 issued notices in Jamia Nagar violence
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The Special Investigation Team of Delhi Police probing the violence at Jamia that took place during the anti-CAA protests has issued notices to three people, including former Congress MLA Asif Muhammad Khan, local neta Ashu Khan and AISA activist from Jamia Chandan Kumar Singh. They have been asked to join the probe on Friday at 11am.

The three have been named in two of the three FIRs registered after the Jamia Nagar violence on December 15. Police sources said they were found leading anti-CAA protests during which the violence broke out. Subsequently, the rioters set three buses on fire and damaged at least a dozen vehicles.

The others named in the FIRs include Asif Tanha (SIO Jamia) and Kasim Usmani (CYSS, Jamia). Police sources said notices would be served to the others within a week.

The former MLA told TOI that he had the evidence to prove that he was not present at any of the sites of the riots. “I have CCTV footage from Shaheen Bagh, where I was present at the time of the violence. CCTV footage from the local police station will also show that I passed by in a procession around 4.20pm. If police can give me a single piece of evidence about my presence, I will take all responsibility for the violence,” Khan added.

The FIR mentions that policemen deployed at Mohammad Ali Jauhar Marg were informed that students of Jamia, ex-students and local politicians will protest against CAA and NRC on that day. The protest had been going on outside the university since December 12 because of which there was a heavy deployment of security forces to ensure no untoward incident occurred.

Around 3pm, a large number of students, including the seven named as accused in the FIRs, marched from Jamia to Mathura Road and blocked the stretch. Later, police were informed that the protesters pelting stones and set DTC buses on fire.

Title: Malayali nurse diagnosed with MERS-CoV
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: A nurse from Ettumanoor, who was admitted to a hospital in Saudi Arabia with symptoms of new coronavirus on Thursday, is afflicted with Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), it is learnt. This was also confirmed by the Consulate General of India in Jeddah (@CGIJeddah) on Thursday night.Studies have shown that humans are infected through direct or indirect contact with infected dromedary camels. MERS-CoV has been identified in dromedaries in several countries in the Middle East, Africa and South Asia.The condition of the woman, admitted to Aseer Hospital was improving, even as confusion prevailed over whether she had contracted the disease that had killed 17 people and affected 600 others across the world.On Thursday evening, Union minister of state for external affairs V Muraleedharan, quoting @CGIJeddah, had tweeted that “about 100 Indian nurses, mostly from Kerala, working at Al-Hayat hospital have been tested and none except one nurse was found infected by Corona virus. Affected nurse is being treated at Aseer National Hospital and is recovering well.”But later in the night, @CGIJeddah tweeted that Dr Tarik Al Azraqi, chairman of scientific regional infection control committee, Aseer Region, had confirmed that the Indian nurse, being treated at Aseer National Hospital, is suffering from MERS-CoV & not 2019-NCoV (Wuhan). We request everyone to refrain from sharing incorrect info, said the consulate.Also, Lok Sabha member Anto Antony and Ashraf Kuttichal, an accredited volunteer of the Indian embassy who visited the nurse at the hospital, said that no one was tested positive for 2019-NCoV.Quoting Dr Tareq Al Azraqi, Kuttichal said the nurse’s condition was improving. It was also learnt that the Malayali nurse was shifted to the general ward from the isolation ward around 3pm. Ashraf also gave her a mobile phone on her request. The nurse had joined the hospital two years ago.Meanwhile, Malayali nurses at Al-Hayat hospital said that were not ready to report for duty unless the hospital was sanitized, and compulsory test was conducted on all staff and visitors who took care of a nurse from Philippines who was infected with the virus. Kuttichal, also an employee of the hospital, said both cases were different, and the Filipina was being treated for lifestyle diseases such as blood pressure and diabetes.As many as 247 nurses from various nations have been working at the hospital. Malayali nurses work in private and government hospitals across Saudi Arabia. Hospital CEO Dr Ahmed Hayazi said that Saudi health ministry had taken all necessary steps to provide proper treatment to all suspected cases.Earlier in the day, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan had asked Union external affairs minister S Jaishankar to help the nurse, reportedly diagnosed with coronavirus. This was after there were reports that she had informed relatives that hospital authorities had quarantined her.Meanwhile, health department has strengthened the screening of passengers coming to Kerala from China. Health minister KK Shailaja said screening had begun at all airports in the state and instructions were given to immediately shift people to isolation wards in nearby hospitals if they are coming with flu-like symptoms from China.Instructions have also been given to set up isolation wards in district and general hospitals. The minister asked the people who came from China to immediately report to respective district medical offices.“No passenger from China, who came in the recent days, showed such symptoms. We have asked certain people to go for self-isolation. Though they have no symptoms of respiratory illness, as a precautionary measure, they have been asked to take extra care,” said state nodal officer for public health emergency Dr Amar Fettle.

Title: Poor response from consumers for PNG connections
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Kochi: The response from the public to city gas project has been lukewarm, said officials with the Indian Oil Adani Gas Pvt Ltd (IOAGPL). Only up to 30% of the consumers, whom they approached expressed interest in PNG connections, they said.

The firm has been carrying out the works as part of the city gas project in six wards of Thrikkakara. “Our officials have been approaching the residents for taking PNG connections. We also use the service of Kudumbashree workers for meeting the residents. But their response has been poor,” an IOAGPL official said.

“They asked us to first introduce the project in the municipality. They said they would take the connections once they get convinced about the benefits of PNG,” the official said.

The IOAGPL authorities have been planning to use more platforms for creating awareness on the benefits of PNG. “We have been trying to create awareness on FM radio. We will also be using other modes for convincing the residents of the benefits of CNG ,” the official said.

“PNG is cleaner and cheaper compared to other fuels like LPG. It is thinner than PNG. If it leaks, it would go up into the air soon. So, chances of catching fire are very remote,” he said.

“It is convenient as consumers get uninterrupted supply of gas, whereas they will have to wait for the LPG suppliers to deliver the refill cylinder at fixed intervals.

Municipal authorities said it would be convenient if IOAGPL provides connections to the households at one stretch. “They have been digging up the roads for laying main pipelines for supply of the gas. They have been giving connections to only a small percentage of consumers. Then, they will have to dig up the roads again for giving connections to the households. If more connections are given right now, digging up of roads over and again can be avoided,” an official with Thrikkakkara municipality said.

Title: The Art of Resistance
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The recent spate of kolams in Tamil Nadu protesting against the Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register of Citizens, reminiscent of grandmothers’ tales of charkha-centred "Gandhi flag" kolams, showed how ordinary citizens can transform an everyday art form into a potent socio-political weapon.

Back in the day, "swadeshi" kolams were drawn with the customary white and orange border, but decorated with green leaves to signify support for the nationalist cause. Dissent was sedition in the British Raj, but no one "discovered" Nazi affiliations in those who drew those kolams. It was left to free India to accuse Tamil women registering peaceful kolam protests of Pakistani connections.

Though the arts have no sustained, discerning support from state or society, this does not absolve artists of their responsibilities. Nor does lack of resources strip them of their power. A song, painting, verse, or a humble kolam, can unmute the silent, empower the disenfranchised and enable the humblest to curb the mightiest. The civil rights movement in the United States, led by such legends as Martin Luther King, was cemented by African-American spirituals. Anti-apartheid songs compelled the world to take note of atrocities in South Africa. Activist choirs in the Balkans keep protests for human rights alive. Braving charges of terrorism, Latin America continues to sing against multi-forms of oppression. In Hong Kong, subversive art on the streets and social media continues to support the demand for liberty. All over the world, activists, artists and thinkers use their creative powers to take on the neocolonial juggernaut.

India’s independence movement witnessed diverse factions uniting with the clarion call of "Vande Mataram". Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyay’s ode to the motherland (1882), translated into other tongues (including the recent "Tasleemaat maa tasleemaat" in Urdu), invoked pan-Indian pride. Though it united more than divided communities, its reference to Hindu gods prevented this ode from becoming secular India’s national anthem. However, it was Bankim’s song and not his own that Tagore chose to sing at the 1896 convention of the Indian National Congress, whose goals prioritised unity among people of different faiths. Early "Indian" flags — including the one unfurled in 1906 flag to protest against the British partitioning of Bengal — had "Vande Mataram" inscribed in bold Devanagari script. Proclaiming Hindu-Muslim brotherhood, the green strip below juxtaposed the sun with the crescent moon and star.

In 1904, Mohammad Iqbal’s poem announced the same idea: "Religions do not teach hatred. We belong to Hind, our homeland is Hindustan!" Neither Partition nor Iqbal’s subsequent allegiance shift to the Islamic state could dislodge that song from India’s collective unconscious. Famously did astronaut Rakesh Sharma sum up what he saw from space with Iqbal’s opening line, "Saare jahan se accha Hindustan hamaara".

In contrast, we see the recent branding of Faiz Ahmad Faiz’s poem as anti-Hindu, when everyone knows the man wrote it to trounce dictatorship in Pakistan. How ignorant we must be to not to see him subverting the imagery of Islam, and using the word "buth" not for Hindu gods, but for the idols of totalitarianism. Today his words "Hum Dekhenge" is resonate across the country and people are reaffirming the relevance of Faiz with translations in regional languages, including in Tamil.

For a heart-wrenching example of what art can achieve, we must time travel back to Leningrad (St Petersburg), 1942. Under the sparkling chandeliers in the packed Philharmonic Hall, a skin-and-bones orchestra determinedly stands up in frayed clothes, but with bow ties, hoping that Nazi bombardment would not drown its music. Loudspeakers relay Dmitri Shostakovich’s grand symphony throughout the city where millions are dying of hunger, forced to survive on anything they find — cats, rats, dogs, horses, and reportedly, human corpses. The last notes fade in haunting silence, and applause celebrates how the listeners "lived it, survived it, and managed to preserve their humanity". They were to face three more years of war.

Decades later, a few German soldiers return to the city they had blockaded. Why? To recall how spellbound they had been by the "Leningrad Symphony" sweeping over their dark trenches bordering the city. Shostakovich had taught them that art can steel the human spirit to resist every kind of oppression. Bodies can be smashed by force, but not the soul. Not when communities are inspired and empowered by word, visual and song.

No wonder then that the establishment in every part of the globe fears art, and employs every tool from fatwa and imprisonment to banning and burning books, paintings and films. Art has "fearsome" attributes indeed. It brings people together, sets the mind free, and instils hope. That is why Chopin, in exile, kept the soul of Poland together when the country was mowed down. And Picasso remains best known for "Guernica" his spine-chilling indictment of violence and repression.

(The writer is a playwright and theatre director)

Title: HC rejects Kusba villagers’ plea for rehabilitation
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Rejecting the plea by Kusba villagers , the Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court has directed respondents to remove the villagers from the encroached area coming under Gosikhurd dam.

While upholding the report of a committee comprising collector and tehsildar, which termed the villagers as encroachers, a division bench consisting of justices Ravi Deshpande and Amit Borkar asked respondents to expedite the process.

Kusba sarpanch Ishwar Lambat and others had moved HC through counsel Prakash Randive , contending that the entire village was severely hit by heavy rainfall which occurred in July. People had to be evacuated using boats as there was water logging everywhere. The village has 252 families and over 1,600 people residing, he said.

During the monsoon, even though there was little rainfall, all the villages were flooded. However, according to the government, the village is 452 meters above sea level. Due to geographical location of the village, which is near Gosikhurd dam, flooding is expected and it is difficult to access the place at that time. The government had said that the village does not need rehabilitation since it is encroached.

The petitioners presented pictures of the affected villages to the bench. They also requested that the village be rehabilitated in view of the problems faced by citizens during the monsoon. Taking into consideration all the issues presented by the petitioner, the HC had directed the government to file an affidavit in last hearing.

Title: Chennai: Anna University faculty to get 280 per cent pay hike
Content:
Anna University

CHENNAI: The state government has increased the monthly salaries of faculty of Anna University , its constituent colleges, government and aided engineering institutes by up to 280% as recommended by the seventh Central Pay Commission (CPC).An order issued on January 14 by the state higher education department announcing the hike was made public on Thursday.As per the order, the revised payscale will take notional effect from January 1, 2016, and monetary benefit from October 1, 2017, making the staff eligible for a lump-sum amount as salary arrears soon.Designations, mode of appointments and pay structure were also revised as per CPC recommendations for all institutions controlled by All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE).Accordingly, there will be only three designations in engineering colleges — assistant professor, associate professor and professor. The existing pay structure involving pay band (PB) and average grade pay (AGP) has been replaced with a pay matrix involving levels and cells.AGP of Rs 6,000, Rs 7,000, Rs 8,000, Rs 9,000, Rs 10,0000 and Rs 12,000 has been replaced with academic levels numbered 10, 11, 12, 13A1, 14 and 15 respectively. Each academic level consists of several cells (numbered 1-40) and salaries increase when teachers move to next cell.For example, let us consider an assistant professor, who is receiving Rs 8,000 as AGP now. His pay band was Rs 15,600-Rs 39,100. The AGP of Rs 8,000 corresponds to academic level 12 in the new pay matrix, with Rs 79,800 fixed as entry pay (cell number 1). Once he moves to the next cell (number 2) within the same academic level, he becomes eligible for an annual increment of 3%. So he will earn Rs 82,200 (rounded off to nearest 100). As he progresses through the matrix, the pay will increase and once he reaches cell 40 (last) of academic level 12, he will receive Rs 2,11,500 as salary.A formally constituted selection committee will decide on promotions to the next academic level and designations.Besides, teachers are eligible to get Rs 75,000 professional development grant (on reimbursement basis), research promotion grant from their institutes/universities and engage in consultancy services to generate revenue.As far as pension, gratuity, leave encashment, health insurance and other terminal benefits are concerned, the present state government rules will continue to be applied.

Title: Nitish Kumar hits back at Pavan Kumar Varma, says he’s free to quit JD(U)
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: Chief minister Nitish Kumar on Thursday virtually showed the door to senior JD (U) functionary and former Rajya Sabha MP Pavan Kumar Varma , who two days ago had sought “ideological clarity” over the party’s alliance with BJP for the Delhi assembly election.

“He (Pavan Varma) is a learned person; I have respect for him, even if he doesn’t respect me. He can go wherever he wants,” Nitish, who is also JD (U)’s national president, said. The CM made the comment while talking to the media soon after he attended an event organised to celebrate the 123rd birth anniversary of Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose.

Nitish made it clear that there was “no confusion” in JD (U) on any issue and that it would not withdraw its support to the Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ). He appeared to have taken exception to the way Varma made a letter written to him public. The letter talked about certain reservations Nitish had expressed during his private conversations with Varma, a former IFS officer.

“You (Varma) should see for yourself what kind of statements you are making about your claims on what I said to you. Should I say what you used to tell me? This is not the way,” Nitish said.

In his letter, which was later posted on social media, Varma said, “I remember you confessing to me in private how the current leadership in the BJP party has humiliated you. You maintained, on more than one occasion, that the BJP is leading India into a ‘dangerous space’… I fail to understand how JD(U) is now extending its alliance with BJP beyond Bihar”.

During his conversation with the media, Nitish made it a point to send a strong message to Prashant Kishor, another senior JD (U) leader who is vocal in his criticism of the CAA and the National Register of Citizens.

In an oblique reference to Kishor’s activities, Nitish said, “JD (U) should be understood properly. It works with complete dedication. Our stand on all issues is always very clear.” He added, “We are never in any confusion on any issue. But if anyone has any doubts, he should come and discuss. The matter can also be raised in party meetings.”

In his response, Varma said in New Delhi that he only sought to know whether JD (U)’s alliance with BJP for the Delhi polls was discussed within the party before it was announced.

He added, “I only sought to know whether this (alliance with BJP for Delhi polls) was done after ideological clarification or not. Even long standing allies of BJP like Akali Dal have refused to ally with BJP for the Delhi election due to their reservations against CAA.”

Union minister Giriraj Singh, who hails from BJP, described the statements of Varma and Kishor as “harmful” for the NDA. “Whether it is Pavan Varma or Prashant Kishor, whatever they have said, is unhealthy for the alliance. Senior leaders of our party look at these statements from the point of view of discipline in the alliance as well,” he added.

Title: 13-year-old stabbed to death with scissors for abusing man in Delhi
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: A 13-year-old boy was stabbed to death with a pair of scissors for hurling expletives at a man outside his house in Nihal Vihar. The boy had been playing with his friends at the time.

A day later, the accused returned to take his belongings when locals and some policemen investigating the case chased him. However, he managed to flee after climbing on the terraces of the nearby houses. He was finally tracked to Uttar Pradesh and arrested. The accused had shaved his beard to conceal his identity.

Police received a call on January 18 that a 13-year old boy had been taken to a hospital in Nangloi with multiple stab wounds. He was declared brought dead at the hospital. The incident occurred near Dal Mill Road in Kamruddin Nagar.

“The deceased was identified as Anand. His father had passed away, while his mother worked as a labourer in a shoe factory. A case of murder was registered at Nihal Vihar police station,” said a senior police officer.

The accused, Shambhu Nath alias Shivam (32), was apprehended from Shahjahanpur in Uttar Pradesh. He told police that while passing by he had stopped to talk to the other children when the boy verbally abused him.

Shivam stabbed the boy in a fit of rage and fled. Police scanned CCTV footage of several lanes close to the victim’s house and saw the accused fleeing in one of them. He was traced to his native village and taken into custody.

Title: Dist admin cracks whips on IOAGPL to expedite works
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

SLUG: CITY GAS

Kochi: With the Indian Oil Adani Gas Private Limited’s (IOAGPL) works in Thrikkakara municipality running behind schedule, the district administration has given the agency implementing the city gas project four more days to complete the works in the municipality. The IOAGPL was supposed to restore the dug-up roads by January 20.

The slow pace of IOAGPL’s road restoration works after digging them up for laying pipelines for piped natural gas (PNG) supply had come under fire from people’s representatives in the municipality.

At a meeting held on January 22, the collector informed IOAGPL officials that as the agency has failed to stay on schedule and restore the roads completely, the permission for digging up roads in the next six wards of Thrikkakara municipality, which was to be carried out in the next days, wouldn’t be granted.

It was after the intervention by the district administration that the city gas project, which had been progressing at a snail pace ever since it was launched in February 2016, gained momentum. Still, the speed and quality of the road restoration works drew criticism from the people’s representatives in Thrikkakara municipality.

The IOAGPL officials had cited difficulties in getting permission from local bodies to dig up roads for laying pipelines for PNG supply as the major reason for the inordinate delay in completing the project.

In around four years since February 2016, the OIAGPL has been able to provide connections only to roughly 1,500 families, whereas the target was 50,000 households. The collector had convened a meeting in January first week and decided to expedite the project and complete distribution PNG connections to 40,000 households in Thrikkakara municipality by March 31.

But yet another round of dispute erupted and the people’s representatives of Thrikkakara municipality and the district collector again convened a meeting again on January 9 to sort out the issues. At the meeting, it was decided to complete the restoration of roads by January 20.

The collector had also given instructions to the IOAGPL to complete the remaining work within 15 days of starting it. A schedule for completing the works in Thrikkakara was prepared and it was decided that the works will be completed in a phased manner.

In the first phase, pipelaying, distribution and plumping works to provide connections to the households are to be completed in six wards. In the next phase, works in the six more wards are to be carried out. The entire work in all the 43 wards in Thrikkakara municipality is to be completed by April 30.

When the collector convened a meeting to review the progress of the work on January 22, it was found that IOAGPL hasn’t completed relaying roads. “They haven’t completed relaying of around 700 metres of road dug up for laying the pipes. So, the people are agitated. If the work is progressing in such a manner, we will have to raise objections against digging up the roads for the project,” one of the ward members of Thrikkakara municipality said.

But IOAGPL representatives said they had laid pipes along 30km in the six wards of the municipality and that only a stretch of 700 metres need to be restored.

“Most of the road-digging works are being carried out as per horizontal dimensional drilling (HDD). We don’t have to dig up the road. We just have to dig up pits at certain points. So, we will be able to complete the repair works fast,” said Ajay Pillai, head of city gas project in Kochi.

As of now, they have given PNG connections to 152 houses in Thrikkakara municipality. Once the work in Thrikkakara is over, IOAGPL will start the works in Eloor municipality.

Title: Shortage of clotting agent hits haemophilia patients
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Kochi: Unavailability of clotting factor concentrates (CFCs) or factor VIII and IX — the agents in blood which helps its clotting — has been creating trouble to many haemophilia patients . As the government failed to clear arrears to the firms which supply medicine to Kerala Medical Services Corporation Ltd (KMSCL), they have stopped the supply of CFCs.

It is KMSCL which procures medicines for all the government hospitals in the state. “We are not getting supply of CFCs for the past few days,” said Dr N Vijayakumar, medical officer in-charge of Haemophilia Treatment Centre, Aluva. “In reply to our request for CFCs, the government issued orders permitting us to procure CFC for two patients. At the same time, around 980 patients have already registered with us. We are unable to provide treatment to them,” he said.

The haemophilia treatment centre at Aluva is the only facility for the patients in Kerala. Though some private hospitals provide treatment to haemophilia patients, it is not comprehensive treatment. “If I go for treatment at a private hospital, it will cost around Rs 25,000-30,000 even if it is a minor bleed. If it is a major bleed, it may cost lakhs at one go,” said Nasser, father of a kid who is suffering from haemophilia.

With the state government winding up Karunya Benevolent Fund (KBF) scheme, hundreds of haemophilia are facing hardships. The government has not included haemophilia patients as the beneficiaries of Karunya Chikisya Scheme which is to replace KBF. “Even if included in the new scheme, a patient can avail a benefit up to only Rs 2 lakh. In the case of haemophilia patients, hospital bills for treatment of major bleed alone will be Rs 2 lakh,” Dr Vijayakumar said.

This story is from January 24, 2020

Hyderabad: A writ petition has been filed by T Uma Mahendra, a resident of Petla Burz in Hyderabad, in Telangana high court , urging it to direct the police not to grant permission for protests being held against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

The petitioner said that the proposed midnight protest programme on January 25 by United Muslim Action Committee and AIMIM at Charminar should not be granted permission. “The organisers of the programme have already started publicising about the protest even before obtaining police permission and this should be discouraged,” he said.

Title: Repeal close relative clause in Surrogacy Bill: Couples
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Repealing the close relative clause, introduced in the Surrogacy (Regulation) Bill, 2019 was among the strongest demands raised by doctors and couples during a meeting with the select committee of Rajya Sabha on Thursday. They also appealed that the proposed five-year waiting period — before couples can opt for surrogacy — be reconsidered.Chaired by Bhupendar Yadav of BJP, the select committee was constituted in November last year after certain portions of the bill, which aims to ban commercial surrogacy in India, met with fierce opposition from stakeholders. The team’s visit to Hyderabad was part of a multi-city tour — Delhi, Anand and Mumbai — to interact with doctors, surrogates and couples. Based on the committee’s recommendations submitted to the Union health ministry, the Surrogacy Bill will be tabled in Parliament for clearance.“We have gone through years of trauma after we discovered that my wife cannot conceive because of ill health,” said a prospective parent, who recently found a surrogate. “Surrogacy is our only option, and I urge the committee to not punish innocent people unnecessarily by banning the practice.“I have approached every close relative we have, but each of them refused. It isn’t an accepted norm in our society yet,” he said.Another couple that TOI spoke to had a similar story. “We asked my sister and sister-in-law, but their husbands didn’t agree. We had our child through surrogacy five months ago,” said the father demanding that the waiting period be revoked. “Why put a couple through more distress?” he asked. His wife, a cancer survivor, had to get her uterus removed soon after marriage.Making a case for intending couples, another parent said: “My wife had renal disease. If not for surrogacy, we’d never have a child.” Keeping with his wife’s last wish, he later married the surrogate mother.Thursday’s meeting was attended by a sizeable group of surrogates too. “It is my body and I should be allowed to make that decision,” said one of them objecting to the clause that bans them from being a surrogate mother twice.Another said how surrogacy is beneficial for both parties involved. “It is our means to a better quality of life. The government should not object to that,” she added.While many infertility experts said they were wary of taking up surrogacy cases, especially post the bill, they urged the committee to allow “genuine couples” to opt for it.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Artificial groundwater recharge structures planned in two delta districts
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: With increased extraction of groundwater for agricultural needs causing concern, the state government recently ordered artificial recharge structures in rivers and tanks to augment groundwater resources in the delta districts of Tiruvarur and Thanjavur. The latest assessment by the state ground and surface water resources data centre of the public works department found that majority of the firkas in the two districts are overexploited and extraction is more than 100%.

Blame it on erratic monsoon, Thanjavur, the rice bowl of Tamil Nadu , depends on groundwater resources for more than 50% of the irrigation needs. The rate of groundwater depletion was so severe in the recent past due to poor rainfall and inadequate storage in Mettur reservoir. The scene is no different in Tiruvarur district. “The recent rains may have helped but there is a dire need for artificial recharge systems for sustainability. The PWD sanctioned Rs 61 crore for 704 recharge shafts and wells in Thanjavur district and 181 such structures in Tiruvarur district ,” said a senior government official. Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami had announced the scheme in the assembly in July last year.

Concerns about depleting groundwater also stem from the fact that the delta region has clay soil, which makes it vulnerable. Water doesn’t percolate through clay soil. “Only the upper reaches of Thanjavur and Pudukkottai have good number of tanks. Tiruvarur has a number of ponds. The artificial recharge structures in these water bodies will directly recharge the dry aquifers, which otherwise suffer due to clay layer,” another official said. The officials are hopeful of improving the groundwater table, because such interventions in the past in Tiruvarur between 2011 and 2013 resulted in maintaining the water level. However, the state government’s special kuruvai packages, announced due to poor storage in Mettur between 2013 and 2018, came with three phase power supply. It resulted in over-exploitation of groundwater resources by farmers.

The PWD’s assessment is that at least eight firkas in Thanjavur are in a critical state, where extraction is between 90% and 100%, and seven fall in semi-critical category (between 70% and 90%). Only five firkas – Sengipatti, Cholanmaligai, Eachankottai, Thekkur and Perumagalur are in safe category (less than 70%). Kumbakonam, Papanasam, Pattukottai, Peravurani, Thanjavur, Thiruvaiyaru and Thiruvidaimarudur taluks are over-exploited. In Tiruvarur, Kodavasal and Valangaiman taluks are the worst affected, followed by Nannilam and Nidamangalam. All four firkas in Thiruthuraipoondi taluk have turned saline.

Title: HC corridors abuzz with theories on Zaka Haq’s transfer
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Various theories are doing rounds regarding sudden transfer of Justice Zaka Haq from Nagpur bench of Bombay high court to Aurangabad bench by chief justice Pradeep Nandrajog.

According to lawyers practicing in the Nagpur bench, it was allegedly done with a mala fide intention as he had issued a contempt notice to registrar (administration) and flayed administration under him for negligence on January 2.

“I believe the CJ’s decision was triggered by the contempt notice issued to Nagpur bench of registrar for negligence on January 2 . The Nagpur registrar, in turn, had informed about it to the registrar general in Mumbai. There is nothing wrong in issuing notice to HC registrar if mistakes are found, as it’s a human nature,” former advocate general of Chhattisgarh , Jugalkishor Gilda , told TOI.

Gilda also questioned the “haste” shown in issuing transfer orders by the CJ, who would be superannuating by next month-end. “No heaven was going to fall if the judge was retained in Nagpur. The HC administration got an impression that he was donning the role of an administrative judge, which was not a reality. I think there are many other factors as well which are doing rounds in the HC corridors,” he said.

Lawyers further claimed that many of their fraternity were upset with “hefty cost” Haq used to impose against their clients, and in some cases against them for “blunders and for efforts to mislead the court”.

“We at the District Bar Association (DBA) are opposing justice Haq’s transfer, as he is one of the very few judges who diligently works beyond scheduled office time, of course with the consent of lawyers for the speedy disposal of cases. A particular group of lawyers doesn’t like his approach and about 15-20 of them, including senior lawyers, complained to the CJ in this regard,” DBA president Kamal Satuja said.

Satuja further said that the CJ should have followed the principles of natural justice by asking the judge on his version over the complaints. “As per these principles, which are upheld by the Supreme Court, the CJ could have asked his brother judge on what exactly led to the confrontation. Even the High Court Bar Association (HCBA) could have been taken into confidence before issuing transfer orders. The apex court had upheld that principles of natural justice are nearly equivalent to the fundamental right,” he said.

Another theory doing rounds is that a powerful group of lawyers had planned Haq’s exit as he had dismissed many of their cases, although on merit.

Title: Vadodara: Allocation made for handling water woes
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representational Image

VADODARA: The draft budget for the year 2020-21 proposed by Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) commissioner has taken a series of initiatives to improve water supply in the city. Throughout 2019, the civic body had drawn flak over water supply.

The draft budget has made a provision for a new water supply pipeline from the Ajwa Crossroads to Lalbaug via Some Talav. The existing pipeline here was prone to leakages and had led to water supply issues in the eastern and southern parts of the city. The new pipeline will take care of this long standing problem.

The civic body is also eyeing to take up improvement in its water supply network instead of relying on booster stations to ensure seamless water supply. To improve the water supply network in the city, network upgradation will be taken up by drawing a master plan taking help of experts.

A new water treatment plant will come up at the Nimeta water treatment facility of the civic body. The new plant will be of a capacity of 50 million litres per day (MLD) and will cost Rs 64.5 crore.

Stand by vertical turbine pumps will be installed at French wells in the Mahi river at Raika, Dodka, Fajalpur and Poicha. This will ensure that water supply is not affected when there is a breakdown.

Title: Won’t allow illegal construction near water bodies, says CM
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said the state government would not take a lenient approach to encroachments and illegal constructions that obstruct normal flow of rivers and water bodies. “Such obstructions will be removed,” he said while inaugurating national conference for developing policies and strategies for flood management organised by water resources department on Thursday.

The chief minister said Japan-model flood resilient development will be implemented in flood prone areas in the state. He said that people living in areas prone to water logging during monsoon will be shifted. “Housing will be shifted while their ownership over the land will be retained,” he added.

Experts from the Netherlands, the US and China are attending the two-day conference. Concepts such as ‘sponge city’ for Kochi and ‘room for river’ for Kuttanad were discussed at the conference. Sun Xiang, senior project manager of Shenzhen water planning and design institute China, explained the sponge city model of flood management, effectively implemented at Shenzhen city in China from 2015. Xiang, who visited Kochi where the state government is planning to implement Sponge City on a pilot basis, suggested that it would take a 10-15 years of time and a good investment to implement the project effectively.

Xiang said that they demolished concrete embankments of rivers and reused it to create permeable river banks. He suggested that river regulation and widening should be done to prevent urban flooding around river banks in Kochi. “Canals in Kochi should be dredged to facilitate easy flow of water to the sea. Pumps should be utilised to flush out water in case of emergency,” he said.

Another speaker Paul van Meel, who is water advisor of the Netherlands, hailed Kattakkada watershed management progamme as a model initiative in the state. He said deepening of the Thottappally lead canal was one way to reduce impact of flood in Kuttanad. “Bridges across major canals are not constructed considering the flood situation and it must be reconstructed. Steps must be taken to remove obstructions in the lower reaches of river so as to ensure quick outflow of flood water to sea,” he said adding that approach in upper and middle reaches of the river is to ensure soil and water conservation through integrated watershed management.

Water resources minister K Krishnankutty, who presided over the inaugural function, said watershed management projects will be immediately implemented in the state. “Environmental issues are caused by over exploitation of groundwater. Climate change and global warning have made lots of changes to the natural environment of the state. Changes in availability of water resources must be taken into consideration. Steps have been taken to introduce water budget,” he said.

Additional chief secretary (water resources) Viswas Mehta, additional secretary, ministry of jal shakti, T Rajeswari and secretary B Ashok attended the event.

Title: Nagpur: Lawyers, professors join anti-CAA protest
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The ongoing protests against the CAA, NRC and NPR)at Eidgah ground in Jaffar Nagar found support from lawyers

NAGPUR: The ongoing protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 ( CAA ), National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) and National Population Register ( NPR ) at Eidgah ground in Jaffar Nagar found support from lawyers, professors, doctors and academicians on Thursday.

The speakers termed CAA, NPR and NRC as “anti-poor and ‘anti-national” laws and appealed to non-Muslim religious minorities and those belonging to Scheduled Castes (SC), Schedules Tribes (ST) and lower Hindu castes to come forward and support the agitation.

“The CAA, NRC and NPR combo is leading India towards the concept of Hindu Rashtra, which was established by Savarkar and Golwalkar. This concept has no place for non-Vedic religions. After Muslims, they will target Jains, Buddhists, Sikhs and all minorities in the country,” said professor Prajwalla Tatte. She also called on women from all religions to join the protests, saying that the new laws would suppress women in the future.

Homeopathic practitioner Dr Shahwar Naziya claimed that giving citizenship to people from Pakistan and Afghanistan may bring back polio to India. “India was declared polio-free by WHO four years ago, but Pakistan is still grappling with it. People coming from Pakistan may bring polio back to India, as no one will check their health and immunization status while offering them citizenship,” she said.

“We must oppose CAA for the future of our kids,” Naziya appealed. She received a rousing response from the women present at the protests.

Dr Ratinath Mishra termed CAA and NPR as anti-India. “It is against the guiding principles of our constitution. The present government is following the ‘divide and rule’ policy of Britishers, and we will never let them succeed,” he said.

A group of lawyers from district and high court visited Eidgah ground and expressed their support to the agitation. High court lawyer Ravi Shakar Bhure said that it is a massive conspiracy in which the judiciary is helpless too.

“Citizens are protesting all over the country. India’s credibility as a democratic country is taking a hit. Even courts are denying petitions against CAA and NRC, which is disappointing for a law student like me,” he lamented. Lawyers Sheetal Deshpande , Shabana Khan, Akshay Samarth, Akeb-ul-Haq spoke on the occasion and promised to give the protesters all necessary legal help.

Title: Insurance agent abducted, killed for Rs 25 lakh in Delhi
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: An insurance agent was abducted and then murdered by four men after he failed to pay them a ransom of Rs 25 lakh . Crime Branch officers arrested all the accused.

The accused men — all of whom were involved in cricket betting — had planned to extort money from the victim, Deepak Dua, as they presumed he was earning very well.

DCP (crime) Rajesh Deo said that the mastermind of the racket, Vinod Kumar, was a cab driver who met Dua at his office in Rohini while transferring his LIC policy from UP to Delhi in December last year. He then planned to abduct him. He had roped in his friends, Monu Sharma, Sandeep and Sunny for the job.

On January 4, Sharma contacted Dua posing as an insurer and sought a meeting with him. He asked Dua to come to Nangloi metro station the next day. Sharma met him there and asked him to board a car. They then drove to a metro station in Noida where Vinod, Sandeep and Sunny also got in the car. On the way they started demanding Rs 25 lakh from Dua.

However, Dua pleaded with them saying that he did not earn much and agreed to transfer Rs 30,000 from his account. However, the accused refused to accept that and started thrashing Dua. When they realised that they couldn’t extort the money from him, Vinod decided to strangle him. The four men then parked the car near highway and strangled Dua. They then dumped the body in Bulandshahr.

Meanwhile, Dua’s family lodged a missing complaint at Prashant Vihar police station. They suspected that he may have been abducted as his phone was found to be switched off.

“We formed a team to track the mobile data and call details of the victim. One of the numbers led us to Sharma,” said Deo. When cops reached Sharma’s house in Nangloi, he tried to escape but was overpowered. He told cops that he and his friends were in debt after losing huge sum of money in cricket betting. Cops soon arrested rest of the gang.

Title: Hyderabad: Cybercrimes pose major challenges, say experts
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: With increase in automation and digitisation, cybercrime and cyber threats are on the rise, said experts at ‘Cyber Security Conclave 5.0 — the Next Gen Threats and Solutions’, a conclave organised in the city on Thursday.

At the event, Sanjay Bahl, director general, Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT-IN), said: “As the world is moving towards automation, cybercrimes and threats are also increasing and posing challenges in equal ratio.” He said CERT-In is focusing on collecting, analysing and disseminating intelligence on cyber threats for the benefit of all stakeholders, who could potentially be affected by these attacks.

Cyberabad police commissioner, VC Sajjanar, said that presently complaints on cybercrimes are more than traditional offences. “Most complaints are related to social media, online financial offences, and data theft. The loss incurred by the complaints due to Cyber Crimes is immense, and it has been posing tough challenges to the police,” he said.

The event was organised by Society for Cyberabad Security Council (SCSC) and Cyberabad police. During the conclave, sessions were orgainsed by SCSC for policemen to acquaint them with the latest cybercrime trends and its solutions.

Title: Tamil Brahmi inscriptions overwritten by vandals
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Cavern on top of Siddharmalai in K Mettupatti near Madurai

CHENNAI: Each rock bed inside the cavern on top of the Siddharmalai in K Mettupatti, 40km from Madurai, has an Tamil-Brahmi inscription. But just below the ancient inscription are also names in English — the handiwork of vandals.

Though the Archaeological Survey of India maintains the site, lack of maintenance leads to many anti-social elements camping at the site. Plastic food wrappers, empty packets of condoms and bottles are found scattered in the area. There are at least 28 sites where inscriptions of Tamil Brahmi have been discovered in the state. Some are maintained well, but significant places like the one in Mettupatti are forgotten.

Inside the cavern two rows of nine beds with names of the donors and Tamil Brahmi inscriptions are found. A stone footprint associated with Jainism, and locally known as Ramarpatham (mark of Lord Rama) is

also found.

A scenic place, reaching the top of the hill is difficult. This may be the reason why no one from the ASI takes an initiative to protect the site. Rock art expert K T Gandhirajan, who camped at the site five years ago, said there is hardly any awareness about the site among the public. "Five years ago, we (a group of artists and heritage enthusiasts) climbed the hill and spent a night under the stars, discussing the significance of the site in the dead of the night," he said.

The rock beds apart, a one-line inscription in Tamil Brahmi on the boulder at the entrance of the cavern is considered one of the oldest in Tamil Nadu . Scholar Iravatham Mahadevan later deciphered it as "Amanan Matirai Attiran Urai Utayanasa" (The abode of Attiran, a Jain monk (Amanan) of Madurai (Matirai) gifted by Udayana (Utayanasa). The inscription talks about the donation of a cave-shelter by Utayana to Attiran.

"Since there is no one to take care of the site, vandals have a free run and destroy the beauty of these inscriptions. It’s ridiculous," said K Muthukumaran, a heritage activist based in Madurai.

Many who visit the Ramarpatham and the temple on top of the hill are not aware of the existence of the Tamil Brahmi script at the spot. "I don’t know what it means. I have been to this place a couple of times, but have not noticed the inscriptions. Nobody ever told me about it," said K Murugan, who was visiting the temple with friends.

Since puja is performed regularly at the temple, the staff of the temple draw arrow signs using white paint to wards the cavern, which helps heritage enthusiasts who visit the Tamil Brahmi site and rock beds. Otherwise there are no information boards. "I don’t know what the ASI is doing here. It’s high time it took some initiative in promoting important sites like this," said Gandhirajan.

Title: This year, families to join Pride Walk
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The third edition of Pride Walk , organized by Queerythm, an organization working for the welfare of the LGBTIQ community, will be held on February 8. This edition will see the families of the community members joining the Pride Walk.

The walk will be held from VJT–University Road to Manaveeyam Veedhi, which will be followed by cultural events.

“We have invited the families of the community members to participate in the Pride Walk. We expect that they will join the march to support the community members. It will be a beautiful experience. We need support from more people,” said Prijith P K, president of Queerythm.

The organizers have planned an inclusive event, as people with disabilities will also be attending it.

“There are a few deaf and mute persons in our community who find it difficult to communicate with people about their identity. Even, many of us do not know sign language and the Pride Walk will be a platform for all of us to interact with each other. Along with the cultural programmes, the event will politically sensitize the participants about the current issues faced by the country,” added Prijith.

This edition will also observe green protocol. A photo exhibition on ‘queer love’, drama by ‘Q Rang’ group, and fashion show by Queerythm fashion group ‘Neev’ will be part of the event.

In addition to social media campaigns, promotional events will be held in the city in the coming days. The representatives of Queerythm will convene a meeting on Saturday to finalize the schedule of events.

Title: Cigarettes worth Rs 6 lakh seized
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Kochi: In a special operation carried out by the Ernakulam excise division, around one lakh illegally-stored, untaxed-cigarettes worth nearly Rs 6 lakh were seized from shops and godowns in various parts of the district.

The joint raid was ordered by Ernakulam excise deputy commissioner A S Ranjith, based on the tip-off of illegal sale of low quality and expired cigarettes by many shops. The raid was carried out in association with the excise offices at Tripunithura range, Ernakulam circle and Angamaly.

Majority of the seizure was from a shop named Bombay Stores at Thevara Junction run by one Ayub (45) of Kozhikode. The godown of the store was also raided. The excise also raided the house of one Abdul Raheem at SRM Road and seized similar tobacco products. Officers said the products were smuggled in trains mostly from Tamil Nadu.

“The seized cigarettes featured popular brand names but none of them had the manufacturing details, mandatory statutory warnings and graphical representations,” said Ranjith.

Title: Consortium to develop state as med innovations hub launched
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said the state government was trying its best to harness all modern and emerging technologies and utilize them for taking up challenges the state has been facing on the development front.

The chief minister was launching Kerala Innovation Day celebrations and Kerala Medical Technology Consortium ( KMTC ) at a function organized by Kerala development and innovation council (K-Disc) in the state capital on Thursday. The occasion also witnessed the CM inaugurating a mobile app, ‘Kerala Food Platform’, another initiative by K-Disc.

“We should be able to make use of emerging technologies like blockchain, machine learning and artificial intelligence for improving the activities in various government departments,” the CM said, adding that massive progress in the IT sector across the globe is leading to big changes in the job sector.

K-Disc, Vijayan said, was trying to help Kerala leverage this progress in modern technology and to implement an advantageous development policy and planning. “The government agency has already identified 15 such projects and startups to pilot them. This will definitely modernize the administrative system in the state,” he pointed out.

The CM also said the ‘technology innovation champion 2020 award’ would further strengthen the efforts to achieve a total modernization of the state’s governance. The award would be given to agencies and government departments, which implement innovative projects, besides the employees involved and will be continued as an annual event, he said.

KMTC, the CM said, would trigger speedy research and development of entrepreneurship in public healthcare. “The Kerala food platform would help create a strong market for the state’s agriculture products and increase farmers’ income through marketing of value-added products,” he added.

Health minister K K Shailaja, who presided over the function, said KMTC was aimed at speedy diagnosis of diseases and for conducting research which can lead to progressive changes in the healthcare sector. The event also witnessed technical sessions and exhibitions related to K-Disc and KMTC’s projects and activities.

Title: Indigo flight lands after seven-hour delay
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Photo used for representational purpose only

NAGPUR: Passengers of a Mumbai-Nagpur flight of Indigo Airlines had to wait for nearly seven hours to reach here as the plane was delayed for different reasons one after the other.

It began with a technical problem in the aircraft, followed by issues with the airport here and finally the flying time for the crew getting over. The aircraft, which was supposed to land at Nagpur by 1pm, finally reached at 8pm. It also affected the passengers who were to fly to Mumbai.

Initially, the plane could not take off on time from Mumbai due to a technical problem. By the time the fault was rectified, the runway at Nagpur airport was closed for an hour for daily maintenance.

On Thursday, the airport was shut between 3.30 pm and 4.40pm. Finally, when the airport re-opened, the flying hours of the pilot and the crew was over. The Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) has fixed a flying hours for the pilot and crew which cannot be exceeded.

Passengers had to wait for a fresh crew and pilot. “The plane finally took off around 6.30pm reaching Nagpur by 8 pm,” said sources.

Indigo had not issued a statement till the time of going to press.

Title: Adding dignity to sanitation work
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Adding dignity to sanitation work

TOI brings to you some unique startups participating in INK@Wash, a platform to promote innovations in waste and sanitation.

Title: Delhi: Nirbhaya case convicts refuse to prepare will
Content:

Title: Former teacher alleges salary fraud in CBSE school in Kochi
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Kochi: A former teacher of Al Ameen Public school in Edapally, which is affiliated to CBSE , tweeted that the school management allegedly collected blank cheques from teachers. She has shared her concerns on twitter with the Prime Minister, Kerala chief minister and Union ministers.

“…they credit the CBSE recommended salary to the teacher’s account. Within minutes, they debit around 9,000 from our accounts and evade the tax,” said Swapna Lekha V B in one of the tweets.

In another tweet, she said as a teacher she believes that its her duty to raise voice against the exploitation of teachers by the school management. “It’s our duty to stop this financial fraud. They have been evading large amounts of income tax for several decades. I hope the authority would look into this matter,” she said.

Swapna, in another tweet, alleged that when she complained about this corruption to the CM following which an inquiry was conducted, the school authorities “called me alone to the room and threatened me and terminated me from service.” Swapna, who was working in the school for the past seven years, was terminated from service early this month.

She has also lodged a complaint with the Elamakkara police raising similar allegations. She also told police that the school authorities have threatened to kill her. “Since it is a non-cognisable offence, we have sent a report to the court. We will take necessary action as per the court directive,” said an officer from Elamakkara police station.

Despite several reminders from CBSE, there is constant allegation that most private CBSE schools do not have a uniform pattern for providing wages to teachers. They are paid lesser than their counterparts in the central and state government schools. Schools here are also not comfortable putting the teachers’ salary online.

However, school authorities have denied the allegations. “Nothing of this sort has ever happened in the school,” said school principal Lekshmi Haridas. “She was taking photos of school documents and teachers. She even entered my room in my absence and took photos of documents signed by me,” the principal alleged.

Title: Nurses association seeks govt help
Content: Kochi: “As soon as the Filipino nurse tested positive for corona virus, swabs were collected from those who came in contact with her on the very same night. One Malayali nurse tested positive and officials from the Indian Embassy immediately arrived at the hospital and she was shifted to a hospital under the ministry of health,” said a nurse working at Al-Hayat National Hospital in Aseer in Saudi Arabia in a message to the nurses ’ association in Kerala The hospital in Aseer is located at a remote area, almost 700km away from Riyadh, the capital of Saudi Arabia.Further the message states that her condition is stable. “She is undergoing treatment and there is no panic situation. She has symptoms of fever at the moment, but nothing critical,” the nurse added in the message.The nurses’ association has written to the state government, requesting it to provide all help to the 30 Malayali nurses whose swab was collected as they had come in contact with the Filipino nurse.“We spoke to the nurses and they are concerned about the situation. But they said that they don’t want to return home as there is no panic situation. Yet, we have requested the state government to contact the Indian Embassy to ensure that they get every help possible,” said Indian Nurses Association (INA) president Mohammed Shihab.“On January 21, we received a message that one of the staff at Al-Hayat Hospital tested positive for corona virus. At present, the situation is under control,” said former vice-president of United Nurses Association (UNA), Sibi Mukesh.Al-Hayat National Hospital is a private hospital, having its presence in Riyadh, Aseer, Jazan and Qassim
