Title: Dalit colony: Water source cut after 3 attend pro-CAA event in Kerala's Malappuram
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

MALAPPURAM: Twenty-two families of a dalit colony near Valanchery in Malappuram district were allegedly denied drinking water after three among them attended a pro-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) programme organized by BJP.

The residents of Cherukunnu SC colony alleged that a Muslim family in the neighbourhood, which use to provide drinking water to them, stopped the supply from January 17, citing the participation of three among them in a ‘Janajagratha Sadass’ supporting CAA as the reason. The event was held at Valanchery town a week ago.

After senior BJP leaders raised the issue through their Twitter handles on Thursday, revenue authorities decided to convene an all-party meeting and take immediate steps to restore the water supply.

Most of the residents of the colony are BJP supporters. Akhila Cherukunnu Parambil, a resident, said the water supply scheme of grama panchayat was not functioning for more than a year and they were forced to walk around 1km to collect drinking water.

“Recently, the Muslim family arranged a facility to pump water from a water source to their home. They offered three buckets of water to each of the family in the colony daily. On Friday, a woman member of the family told us that photos of three men of the colony attending the pro-CAA programme was being circulating on a social media group in the locality and the family cannot continue to provide water as they were under pressure from a section of people to stop the supply,” said Akhila.

C P Velayudhan, a former CPM branch committee member, said the family stopped providing water suddenly and people in the colony, irrespective of party affiliations, were hit. Velayudhan said that he would bring the issue to the notice the CPM leaders. For the last three days, Sevabharathi unit in Painkannur has been supplying water to the colony.

However, Sainudheen Kalappadathil, a member of the Muslim family, said: “We stopped supplying water due to technical issues. My wife never told them anything about CAA. These allegations are fabricated.”

Meanwhile, Tirur tahsildar T Murali, who visited the colony on Thursday, said that revenue authorities will file a detailed report on the incident to district collector Jafar Malik on Friday. “Panchayat authorities will take immediate steps to provide water to the colony,” he said.

“We are yet to verify the allegations of the colony residents,” added Murali.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Mass withdrawal over NPR-KYC link ruffles bank
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Since Saturday, about 600 people have withdrawn their entire deposits worth about Rs 6 crore (File photo)

MADURAI: Smarting under an unprecedented money-withdrawal spree by customers who misread a bank notice requesting National Population Register (NPR) details for its KYC, the Kayalpattinam branch of Central Bank of India in Tuticorin has launched a campaign to allay fears. Since Saturday, about 600 people, predominantly Muslims, have withdrawn their entire deposits worth about Rs 6 crore.

There are about 18,000 accounts in the branch of which 15,000 are savings, said branch manager A Mariappan. Kayalpattinam is a coastal town with about 10,000 households. Many of the men work abroad and hold NRI accounts with the bank. Shabana (name changed) said they were told that the notice may be a consequence of their protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act and that there was no safety for their deposits. Her husband who works in the Middle East had told her to withdraw the few lakhs they had in the bank, which she did on Monday.

“We went on a campaign in an autorickshaw announcing that KYC was only for new accounts and very old ones when a ration card was enough to start an account, and that the NPR certificate was only an option. But we are yet to get the message through,’’ said Mariappan pointing out that customers withdrew Rs 50 lakh even on Thursday. The bank notification published in a Tamil daily on January 11 had said that NPR details can be provided by customers for the KYC linked to their accounts. The withdrawals began after the notification was widely circulated on social media. The customers presumed that it was mandatory to furnish the NPR certificate. Officials said they were surprised to see hundreds of customers queued outside their bank early on Saturday morning to withdraw cash.

“It was only a little while later that we realised that they had come to empty their accounts, and there was nothing we could do about it,’’ Mariappan said. “Monday was the day of highest withdrawals and most of the customers who came to withdraw money were women, who rarely come to the bank on other days,’’ he added.

Social activist and member of the Mass Empowerment and Guidance Association S K Salih said the people’s fears were justified as they were at the forefront of the protest against the CAA and NRC. “We took out a rally of 6,500 people, carried a 650-metre-long national flag and conducted special prayers in schools against it. We wore badges saying ‘No CAA and No NRC’, and here we were being asked to submit NPR details. Our biggest fears are becoming true,’’ he said. “This is a nation where demonetization occurred on a single night and nothing can be ruled out,’’ he said.

Title: Recurring house break-ins mock at Koodalpudur cops
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Madurai: House break-in incidents continue to take place in the Koodalpudur police station limits despite the stepped-up vigilance by the city police. Koodalpudur, having a vast area from Park Town to Paravai Market to New Vilangudi, continues to be a hotspot for burglars.

At least six incidents targeting locked houses have been reported since December 2019, which is one fourth of the total incidents reported in Madurai city having 22 police stations.

Another incident was reported in Vinayaka temple in the police limits, where articles worth thousands of rupees were stolen. The incidents were reported from places such as S Alangulam, Anaiyur and Park Town. In one of the incidents, 44 sovereigns of gold jewels and Rs 2.17 lakh in cash were stolen from a locked house at S Alangulam on December 24.

Close to 700 grams of gold jewels and about Rs 4 lakh in cash were looted in six house break-in incidents in the police limits. House break-in incidents were also reported in Tallakulam, SS Colony and Thirunagar police stations limits in Madurai city. After the introduction of Delta vehicles and increase in visible policing, crimes including house break-ins have largely come down in other police station limits.

A police officer said that they have stepped up vigilance during night. There are at least three police beats, three two-wheeler patrols, one Delta vehicle and the station inspector would be moving at nights. But, house break-in incidents could not be stopped since the area is too vast to cover. “Houses are sparsely built and the area is also vast. The station’s jurisdiction is on the borders of Madurai district police, making it easier for criminals to escape without any trace,” he said.

A higher police officer said that the only way to prevent burglary is to catch the gangs operating in the locality. They are confident of catching them in 10 days, he said.

Title: Delhi: Primary healthcare given a boost, but hospitals need infra injection
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: Five years ago, no one had heard of a mohalla clinic . But the idea of neighbourhood health centres has been a hit among Delhiites , especially the poor, who earlier postpone all doctor visits unless the illnesses was really serious, both to save money and the time spent in overcrowded government hospitals.“When my wife fell ill recently, I went to the mohalla clinic operating from the house next door,” revealed Sanjay Kumar in east Delhi’s Vinod Nagar. “The doctor examined her and prescribed medicines for free. I would have had to pay a private doctor Rs 150.” Kumar, who came to Delhi two decades ago from Rae Bareli in UP, is a Congress party supporter. Saying he hadn’t decided who to vote for in the assembly elections, Kumar did express happiness, however, at Delhi government’s success in boosting primary healthcare by introducing mohalla clinics.When Aam Aadmi Party came to power in Delhi for the second time in 2015, it promised to build 1,000 mohalla clinics across the state. However, only 450 such clinics have become operational. “There is no mohalla clinic in our area. We have only been hearing about its benefits,” said Rinki Yadav in south Delhi’s Sanwal Nagar. BJP and Congress have regularly alleged corruption and deficiencies in the running of the clinics, but it hasn’t dented the popularity of these convenient healthcare stations.It isn’t surprising then that AAP hopes the clinics will garner it support during the polls. More than half of them are run from rented premises instead of portacabins, as envisaged in the original plan when the first clinic was inaugurated in west Delhi’s Peeragarhi in July 2015. “The plan to build more mohalla clinics was delayed by unavailability of land and the obstructions created by the BJP-majority municipal corporations,” alleged an AAP functionary.But the opposition parties point out that the AAP government failed to improve tertiary care in the capital. A report by a BJP think-tank, released last week, claimed that Delhi government had added only 394 beds in state-run hospitals instead of the 30,000 beds it had promised during the 2015 assembly polls campaign. Public Policy Research Centre also said the AAP government had been pulled up numerous times by Delhi high court for its inability to meet the city’s growing healthcare demands.A recent inquiry conducted by a high court-appointed expert panel on the functioning of state government-run hospitals revealed that most had long waiting lists for major procedures, while those located on the city’s periphery lacked basic equipment and staff. The 250-page report said some of these centres were forced to shut emergency services after 4pm and three peripheral hospitals were cited as referring the patients requiring emergency services to a “bigger centre” after that.The report also noted that most public hospitals struggled with staff shortage and key equipment. At Lok Nayak Hospital, one of the largest public health facilities in the capital, there were less than half the stipulated staff in the obstetrics and gynaecology department at night. Even a sanitation employee wasn’t on duty though almost half of all deliveries takes place at night, the panel said.Government officials claimed to be working to improve things. “We have started a helpline that patients can call to complain about any deficiency,” said one of them. “Also, we have ensured availability of free medicines and we are working overtime to expand the health infrastructure by constructing new hospitals and adding more beds to the existing ones.”The official added, “The Indira Gandhi Hospital in Dwarka, which will be the largest in southwest Delhi with 1,241 beds, the 600-bed facility at Ambedkar Nagar in south Delhi and a 772-bed hospital in Burari, northwest Delhi, are likely to become functional in three months.”Since few Delhi state-run hospitals have MRI and CT scan facilities, the government introduced a scheme two years ago to allow patients referred by select hospitals to have such tests done in empanelled private diagnostic centres. Similarly, if the waitlist for surgery was too long, patients could avail of treatment at select private hospitals. “More than 17 lakh people have benefited from the scheme, while over 1,000 people have undergone free surgery in private hospitals,” a government official said.Critics, however, observe that outsourcing key services and surgeries to private establishments may not be a good idea. “The money spent annually by the government in getting MRIs done outside its hospitals, for example, can instead buy required machines. Only two-three Delhi government hospitals have MRI facility, and in Lok Nayak Hospital, the waiting time for a scan is two years,” said a doctor.

Title: Congress MLA Lalit Vasoya’s ‘firing’ video creates ripples
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Grab from video that went viral on social media

RAJKOT: Hardly had the flutter on social media around Abdasa Congress MLA Pradyumansinh Jadeja’s son Jaideepsinh’s video on Instagram showing him firing in the air died down, that another politician added fuel to the fire with another fresh upload of a similar video on Facebook.

The new video shows Dhoraji Upleta Congress MLA Lalit Vasoya learning how to fire, was uploaded by his supporter Dinesh Patel. However, Vasoya may escape action as the video was taken at the time of his training to ‘fire a pistol’.

“I have applied for gun licence for my personal security. As it is mandatory for any licence applicant to acquire the certificate from the weapon training centre in Gondal, I had gone there. It was while I was practising with a pistol that my video had been shot,” Vasoya told reporters.

Later, Vasoya also asked Patel to remove the video from his account. Jaideepsinh uploaded three videos on Instagram showing him firing in the air from his pistol and 12 bore gun, leading to his arrest on Wednesday night.

Title: Serampore model for restoration of European colonies along Hooghly
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

WBHC chairman Shuvaprasanna, along with (far right) conservationist Manish Chakraborti and Serampore Initiativ... Read More

KOLKATA: The West Bengal Heritage Commission has proposed the replication of the Serampore Initiative, which led to the restoration of Danish heritage in Serampore, to take up similar projects in former European colonies along the Hooghly . Portuguese were the first to settle in Bandel , followed by the Dutch in Chinsurah and French in Chandernagore.

“The Serampore Initiative that saw the Danish government, National Museum of Denmark and the West Bengal Heritage Commission (WBHC) sign an MoU and contribute towards restoration of important Danish architecture in Serampore can act as a model to drive similar initiatives in other European settlements in Hooghly,” WBHC chairman Shuvaprasanna said.

Conservation architect Manish Chakraborti, who executed the restoration of St Olav Church, Denmark Tavern and North and South Gate of the court compound, said the National Museum of Denmark had steered the research, while the Danish government and WBHC had financed the project. “This collaborative and bottom-up approach is a potential model for conservation-led development in other historic settlements along the Hooghly,” he said. On Thursday, WBHC assigned heritage plaques to the restored buildings. St Olav Church, restored in association with the Calcutta diocese, has won a Unesco heritage award of distinction.

Bente Wolff, project head of Serampore Initiative, said the key takeaway from the Serampore model was how it catalysed larger contributions and supplementary projects from the state government and Serampore municipality, like restoration of Government House, upgrading of the riverfront, historic streets and the historic town square. “We also have the relocation planned for government office, away from historic town core, demolition of sub-standard buildings and construction of new bus terminus to relieve the town core of overload of buses,” Bente added.

Title: Goa: Committee for draft masterplans of eco zones gets extension
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Draft zonal masterplans have to be now prepared for these areas

PANAJI: The state government on Thursday extended the term of the committee to prepare draft zonal masterplans for the eco-sensitive areas declared in the state by three months. The Union environment ministry had notified five wildlife sanctuaries and one national park and areas around them in Goa as eco-sensitive zones.

Draft zonal masterplans have to be now prepared for these areas. The ministry of environment, forest and climate change has notified Bhagwan Mahaveer Wildlife Sanctuary and National Park, Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary, Netravali Wildlife Sanctuary , Cotigao Wildlife Sanctuary, Bondla Wildlife Sanctuary and Dr Salim Ali Bird Sanctuary as eco-sensitive zones and the areas around as wildlife protected areas.

The activities that are prohibited, regulated and permeated in eco-sensitive zones are defined in the notification. A committee to monitor the compliance of the notification was constituted.

The state level eco-sensitive zone monitoring committee for Goa held its meeting and decided that as the land details are already available with the town and country planning department, the chief town planner will get the draft zonal masterplan for eco-sensitive zones prepared.

“The notification requires the preparation of a zonal masterplan for effective management of eco-sensitive zones for each protected area within two years of the date of its publication for consideration and approval by MoEF,” the government stated in a notification.

Title: Truck owner, driver nabbed by police for faking robbery
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Bareilly: Police have resolved the highway truck robbery case and arrested the truck owner and driver for planning a fake robbery in Izzatnagar area of Bareilly district. The truck’s owner and driver had faked the robbery and sold a rice consignment which they were handed over by a businessman for delivery.

The police have arrested both the accused and recovered Rs 6 lakh along with the truck. The truck’s driver had filed an FIR that his truck was looted by armed robbers in Izzatnagar area on January 20.

Truck owner Munna Yadav and driver Prem Singh, both residents of Deoria district, approached SHO Izzatnagar police station and lodged a police complaint that they were carrying rice from Bihar to Uttarakhand when 3-4 unidentified robbers had thrashed, confined them and eloped with the truck along with loaded rice on Nainital-Bareilly state highway. An FIR was registered under IPC sections 343 (punishment for wrongful confinement) and 394 (voluntarily causing hurt in committing robbery) at Izzatnagar police station.

During the investigation, SHO KK Verma found that Munna Yadav had filed a fake complaint. And after following him through his informers, Verma caught him red-handed with the looted truck with a fake registration number of West Bengal. Yadav had already sold the rice to someone else and had shared the money with his driver Prem Singh.

Yadav later told police that he faked the robbery because he wanted to collect money for the treatment of his mother who is suffering from a critical health condition.

SSP Shailesh Pandey told TOI on Thursday, “During investigation, we found that the story narrated by the truck owner had many loopholes. It didn’t match with the chronology of events and during cross-questioning, driver and the owner had differing statements. We monitored the movement of the truck owner and recovered the looted truck which was hidden elsewhere with a fake registration number. We booked him for cheating along with the sections of robbery.”

Title: LED bulbs stolen from streetlights in Madurai
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The city corporation is planning to seek police help after LED bulbs and controller units have gone missing from the lamp posts on the streets in the last few days. High wattage LED bulbs, which were installed recently under the Smart City scheme, were found missing in many areas. Apart from bulbs, controller units, which control street lights based on preset timing, were also missing.

A private contractor, who procured materials and installed new LED bulbs and fittings, recently informed the corporation officials about the missing components. The officials, who suspected that the components might have been stolen, are planning to lodge a police complaint through a petition to the police commissioner.

Sources from electrical department of corporation said that all the missing bulbs are 120 watts and each one of them may cost between Rs 5,000 and Rs 6,000. Each controller unit costs more than that.

Sources said that it has been noticed that at least six bulbs and 18 controllers are missing in places like Avaniyapuram, Chinthamani, South Marret Street, Alagappan Nagar, TVS Nagar and Muthupatti. There is a strong suspicion that equipment could be missing in other parts of the city also and teams are conducting checks in all the areas.

The corporation took up the work of replacing street lights into LED bulbs under the Smart City scheme in 72 old wards at the cost of Rs 25 crore last year.

A higher official from the engineering wing of the corporation said that it is suspected that some disgruntled employee under the private contractor could have been behind the theft. CCTV footages, which have been taken out from nearby houses, show that some people stole the bulbs and units. “We will consult with corporation commissioner and lodge a complaint with the police commissioner to catch the thieves,” the official said.

Title: Check your Aadhaar, Telangana tops error charts
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Telangana may have achieved 100% universal Aadhaar coverage along with a few other states, but India’s newest state has the highest error percentage in the country.While Telangana has 13.6 % errors, Karnataka has 8.6% errors and the rest have less than 5.5% errors in Aadhaar cards issued in their respective states, according to the study by global social impact advisory group Dalberg.Most of these errors are mistakes in dates of birth or names, followed by goof-up in names, addresses, the gender of the person and photographs, the report says.Experts say the errors assume significance in the backdrop of the proposed implementation of the National Population Register (NPR), which will seek data on dates of birth and Aadhaar numbers of citizens. Neighbouring Andhra Pradesh has just 0.80% errors in Aadhaar cards issued in the state.The pilot project of Aadhaar enrolment was first kicked off in 2010 in the then undivided Andhra Pradesh.“The transliteration tool which converts Telugu into English and vice-versa was not updated. Officials used a customized tool which has resulted in errors in names and addresses of people,” cybersecurity expert Sridhar Nallamothu explained. “The cameras that were used were of outdated VGA (video graphics array) type which was part of first-generation smart mobile phones released in 2002. Similar phones were used during 2010 pilot project,” he added.Experts also blamed operators belonging to private enrolment agencies hired by the Unique Identity Authority of India (UIDAI) for mistakes. “After opening the network with their finger authentication, the operators allowed others who are not authenticated to carry out the enrolment work,” said a senior official, who did not wish to be identified. “UIDAI had even cancelled contracts of some of these enrolment agencies,” he recalled.Another glaring error that often came to the fore was mobile phone numbers not displayed on Aadhaar cards. “It was either due to the cardholder forgetting to give his or her mobile number to the operator or the number not being filled in the designated column by the operator,” experts said.Officials countered that care was taken as monitors were arranged for the benefit of citizens to see what is being entered in the system by the operators. “There may be some technical errors. But generally, illiterate people would not know what was being shown on the monitors and might have nodded to what was being asked of them by the operators,” said a UIDAI official.

Title: Nashik: Schools asked to register under RTE for 2020-21
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: Schools across Nashik district have started registering on the SARAL portal for admitting students under the Right to Education ( RTE ) Act for the academic year 2020-21.

The primary education directorate of the state government has instructed the schools to complete the registration process before February 11 following which the students will begin applying for admissions.

“Once the schools register on the portal and provide the number of students that can be benefited, the same will be verified by the Block Education Office (BEO),” a Nashik zilla parishad ( ZP ) official said.

Nashik ZP is the nodal agency in Nashik for undertaking the process of admissions in schools of the district under RTE Act.

According to the ZP official, earlier there was a provision of four rounds of lottery for students to get admissions under the RTE if the number of applicants was more than the number of seats available in schools.

“But now there will be only one round of lottery for admitting students in schools under the RTE. Moreover there will be a waiting list of equal number of students who will automatically get upgraded against cancellation of admissions,” he said.

In the academic year 2019-20, a total of 457 schools had registered themselves under this scheme. “This year we are expecting over 550 schools to register on the portal. Also, last year, over 1,400 seats remained vacant. Since there will be only one lottery this time and a waiting list of equal number of students, we are expecting 100% admissions under the scheme,” the ZP official said.

The ZP has also directed the schools to update online data of students studying under the RTE scheme and the number of vacant seats that would be available in the next academic year. Students, who had registered last year, will be automatically registered this year.

The primary education directorate has asked the BEO as well as the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) to constitute a scrutiny committee for checking the admission documents.

Although minority schools and schools that get grant from the government are exempted from the scheme, the BEO has to upload the details of such schools along with those that are shut for the purpose of scrutiny.

Title: Kerala: Woman barges into pro-CAA meet, ‘assaulted’
Content:
Screegrab of the video

KOCHI: A meeting organised by a Sangh Parivar outfit within the premises of the Ernakulam Pavakulam Temple in support of CAA on Tuesday morning has kicked up a row after the video of a woman who went to the event uninvited being pushed out of the hall and verbally abused by a group of women and men went viral on social media.The controversy worsened further on Thursday with the Ernakulam North police registering cases against both the woman and the meeting attendees, based on each other’s complaints.Police said the incident occurred when the woman, identified as Athira of Thiruvananthapuram , entered the hall, where the meeting named Mathrusangamam organised by Janajagarana Samithi was proceeding, and alleged that the speakers were “propagating lies”.This led to a minor scuffle and heated exchanges and the woman was finally pushed out of the hall. The video also showed some women attendees verbally abusing the woman with communally-loaded and provocative comments.Later on Tuesday, BJP industrial cell secretary C V Sajini who was speaking at the event at the time of the incident, filed a police complaint against the woman. Based on this, police registered an FIR against Athira under IPC Sections 447 (criminal trespass) and 294 (b) (sings, recites or utters any obscene song, ballad or words, in or near any public place). The police said Athira, a make-up artist, stays in a hostel near the temple. The case was transferred to women’s police station on Wednesday.“It was a closed-door programme and the woman barged in with abusive words. The participants pushing her out was a normal reaction. Police should probe the larger conspiracy behind the incident,” said Sajini.Based on Athira’s complaint on Thursday, police also registered a case against 29 people under IPC Sections 143, 147, 323, 294 b, 506 and 509 read with 149. “She said she was on her way to the bank when she happened to hear the speech which she alleged propagated lies. She said she was assaulted by the women,” police said.In Video: Watch: Woman assaulted after barging into pro-CAA meet in Kerala

Title: ‘Elected local body heads must serve with compassion’
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Madurai: Higher positions would come their way if the newly-elected village panchayat presidents and vice-presidents serve their villages well and are compassionate to the needs of the poor, minister for co-operatives Sellur K Raju has said.

He was speaking after inaugurating the second day training programme for local body representatives in Madurai on Thursday. Stating that they are directly connected to the government’s financial administration, the minister urged the rural body representatives to open WhatsApp connectivity with the people of their village so that they could redress their grievances better.

People, the president and the officials should be connected through WhatsApp for better administration, he said. Providing all facilities to the people should be the first priority, Raju said.

He said that 3,273 panchayat ward members, 420 panchayat presidents, 214 panchayat union ward members, 12 panchayat union chairpersons, 23 district panchayat ward members and district panchayat president have been elected in Madurai district.

Similar training programmes for village panchayat presidents were held in other districts too, following which a more extensive five-day training programme would be organized by the district rural development agency soon.

Madurai north MLA V V Rajan Chellappa, project officer DRDA Priyanka Pankajam, assistant director of panchayats Chelladurai among others were present.

Title: Goa: Cashew farmers hopeful for 2020, mango farmers see bleak year
Content:
The mango crop is very sensitive to weather parameter changes unlike cashew, hence the flowering is eccentric

PANAJI: While 2020 seems set to see a good cashew crop, it may not be a good year for mangoes. The blossoming of the cashew fruit, which takes place between November and January, has been on track this year, farmers said. With cashew beans having already started to sprout in some orchards, stakeholders anticipate a bountiful season this year.“The flowering process is complete and small green nuts have started appearing in their place. We are expecting a good cashew season this time, since the crop’s development looks very promising so far,” said Valpoi-based farmer and cashew processor Vinod Barve.However, there has been no flower bud initiation in the mango crop yet. The upcoming season looks bleak, farmers said. Agriculture experts attributed this to fluctuating weather parameters.“There needs to be a dry spell of 45-50 days after the rain,” said director of agriculture Madhav Kelkar. “Owing to the fact that there was continuous and erratic rain (last year), there may be delayed flowering of the mango crop.”Agriculture Technology Management Agency’s (ATMA) North Goa project director Dilip Paranjape said the mango crop has not received enough “water stress” this season.“The mango crop requires water stress. The season will be delayed as of now owing to the prolonged monsoon. However, if the monsoon further delays, the crop may get time to reach fruition and we may get a good mango produce,” he said.Principal scientist (horticulture), ICAR-CCARI, A R Desai, said that farmers will have to be patient and observe how the mango crop behaves. “The mango crop is very sensitive to weather parameter changes unlike cashew, hence the flowering is eccentric,” he said. “There are a lot of fluctuations in the weather due to global climatic changes.” He also said that the cashew crop will get farmers more income than the mango crop.

Title: ‘Shakti Wing’ to check crime against women, children in Sabarkantha
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Himmatnagar: In order to prevent crimes against women , children and elders , the Sabarkantha police has formed special squads ‘Shakti Wing’ in all police stations of the district on Thursday.

According to a release issued by the Sabarkantha police, each Shakti Wing will consist of one male and two women cops.

“The Shakti Wing will visit different schools, colleges, tuition classes, shopping malls and residential colonies to find out if there are any victims of sexual abuse or harassment. If the wing members find such victims, they will take them to the nearest police station and lodge their complaints,” said the release.

“The special squad will carry out regular patrolling at tuition classes, gardens, tea stalls and bus stands. It also aims to act as bridge between those who are reluctant to approach police and the cops,” the release explained.

“The members of the wing will also spread the awareness about sexual crimes against women and children,” added the release.

Title: Garbage situation in South Goa worsening, says Michael Lobo
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

New garbage dumps are developing in villages neighbouring Margao

MARGAO: Minister for waste management Michael Lobo on Thursday said that the garbage situation in the rural parts of South Goa was taking a turn for the worse with new garbage dumps developing in villages neighbouring Margao.

“I was in Margao for most part of the day, today, and I saw garbage dumps in Navelim, Rumdamol and Davorlim. These dumps need to be cleared at the earliest in the interest of the locals,” Lobo said in the presence of chief minister Pramod Sawant, while addressing the gathering at the inaugural function of Saras 2020 at Margao.

He added that a garbage treatment plant will soon come up at Verna industrial estate for which one lakh sq m of land has already been acquired. “The environment impact assessment is complete, and the South Goa collector will soon conduct a public hearing over the project. The facility will have capacity to treat 250 tonnes of waste per day and energy will be generated through this project,” Lobo said.

He urged people to support the project. “Do not get carried away by politicians trying to put spokes in the wheels of development,” Lobo said.

The rural development minister also urged Sawant to clear the file for setting up Goa Bazaar, a permanent sales outlet for artisans and self help groups, at Merces, as he said the project would lead to empowerment of women.

Title: MIDC keen to levy & collect property tax in industrial areas under civic limits
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Two industrial estates of MIDC, Satpur and Ambad, are located in the limits of the NMC

NASHIK: The Maharashtra Industrial Development Corporation ( MIDC ) is keen to levy and collect property tax in industrial areas that falls under the jurisdiction of municipal corporations across the state and has written to the state government, seeking its nod.

Currently, the MIDC is levying and collecting 50% of the property tax and the remaining 50% is given to the respective gram panchayats. The MIDC had issued a circular in this regard in December last year following a government resolution (GR) issued in September 2019.

The MIDC wants the same model to be replicated for industries located in the limits of municipal corporations like Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ). MIDC CEO P Anbalagan, who was in Nashik on Wednesday, said at present such taxes are being levied and collected by the local civic bodies in rural areas.

“We are against recovery of property tax from industries by the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC). We want the property tax to be collected by the MIDC from industries in municipal corporation limits too,” Anbalagan said, adding they have already sent a proposal to the state government for approval.

Anbalagan was in the city for a meeting with industrial associations from five districts of Nashik division . Two industrial estates of MIDC, Satpur and Ambad, are located in the limits of the NMC.

The NMC collects the property tax from the industries in these two estates and in return provides road and look after maintenance of streetlights. But the agency wants more funds to create and maintain infrastructure in the industrial areas which could be garnered from collection of property taxes.

During a meeting, NIMA presidents Shashikant Jadhav had said that most of the roads in Satpur and Ambad MIDC areas have been handed over to the NMC for maintenance work. “Some roads in these two industrial areas are yet to be handed over to the NMC. Hence, the civic body is not developing these roads,” he said.

Anbalagan, however, refused handing over of roads to the NMC. “I am against handing over of roads to the NMC. We may give an NOC to the NMC for developing the roads in both the industrial estates,” he said.

New investment proposals in Nandurbar

Anbalagan on Wednesday said that two large industries have shown interests to invest around Rs 1,000 in Nandurbar. This will generate over 2,500 jobs. These industries are from textile and food processing sectors.

“Apart from Nandurbar, three other industries are also making investment over Rs 1,000 crore in Supa MIDC areas in Ahmednagar district. The land has already been given to these industries,” he said.

Title: Corpn takes up beautification work on Pudukottai road
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Trichy: The corporation has launched the beautification drive on Pudukottai road connecting the city with the airport. The median on the Trichy-Pudukottai NH-36 is being spruced up with flower-bearing plants and decorative trees.

Previously, Bharathidasan road was beautified in a similar way on a pilot basis. Following a positive response, the corporation proposed to beautify Pudukkottai road late in 2018.

The civic body reconstructed a portion of the centre median of the road passing through PWD office, Trichy SP office and Central prison at an outlay of Rs 34.4 lakh. The height of the median was increased to prevent criss-crossing of cattle and pedestrians. Four borewells on the 4km stretch to facilitate drip irrigation to water the decorative plants.

“The selection of road for the beautification project is a wise choice. With the presence of Trichy airport, a lot of international tourists use the Pudukkottai road. More such roads should be developed and maintained,” said N Manivannan, member of Trichy Intra-City Development Endeavours.

Based on suggestions from horticulture experts, flower-bearing plants that will not be consumed by cattle have been planted on the centre median. Foxtail palm trees, a decorative tree that grows for over 7 feet is also placed on the centre median of Pudukkottai road.

“We have completed 50% of the proposed beautification work. The remaining work shall be completed within a month. Permission from NHAI was obtained to beautify the stretch,” a corporation official said.

With TVS tollgate and Subramaniapuram being one of the gateways to access the city, officials said that workers have been appointed to periodically clean and water the green cover on the centre median.

Title: Protests over labourer death at Kheri mill
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Bareilly: Around 500 residents including family members of a youth, who was crushed to death when he accidentally fell on a cane carrier, staged a protest against sugar mill administration in Nighasan area of Lakhimpur Kheri district on Friday. The protesters demanded compensation for the bereaved family from the mill.

Deceased, Monu Khan, a resident of Ghosiana village, had been working on contract at the sugar mill for two years. He accidentally fell on to the cane carrier and his neck got stuck into the slat conveyor chain resulting into his sudden death

The protest was called off after police filed an FIR against mill administration under IPC section 304A (causing death by negligence). Khan’s body was sent for an autopsy.

Monu is the second labourer to die while working in Lakhimpur Kheri this week. Earlier, a 22-year-old suffocated to death inside a juice tank of a sugar mill in Isanagar area on Sunday.

Mill owner Puneet Agarwal has also promised compensation to the aggrieved family.

Deepak Shukla, SHO of Nighasan police station, told TOI, “The protest was over after the FIR was registered against the manager of Tirupati Balaji Sugar Industries. Prima facie it looks like an accident. The victim was not wearing any safety gear which shows negligence on the part of mill administration.”

Title: Following in Wangchuk’s footsteps, girls at Kolkata school forgo ironing to save power
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Rupsa Mitra was in Class I when ‘3 Idiots’ was released. Years later, when Rupsa watched the film, she loved the character, Rancho, who was based on Sonam Wangchuk , innovator and Magsasay Award-winning environmentalist who lived in Ladakh. Little did she know that one day, she would follow in Rancho’s footsteps.Wangchuk, who has stopped ironing his clothes to save electricity and promote the planet, has inspired an entire school to emulate him. On Thursday, Rupsa, now in Class XI, was among the 1,800-odd girls at The BSS School who wore uniforms that were tidy but not ironed. “Our principal suggested we iron clothes one day less. When I told my parents about it, they were perplexed. After all, schools have for ages insisted that students should wear starched and ironed clothes. I had to explain to them that it would save electricity and was good for the planet,” the Arts student said.All students at the school, from Class I to XII, have been urged to adopt the practice. Class-X student Sneha Dey, who irons her clothes on Monday, Thursday and Saturday evenings, skipped doing so on Monday. “If the electricity I save helps light up even one home, it will make me happy,” she said.Principal Sunita Sen said a friend had drawn her attention to Wangchuk’s pledge on un-ironed clothes. “This is the 70th year of the school and we were looking for a pragmatic social initiative in which all students could participate without burdening their parents. The un-iron initiative is perfect,” she said.Calcutta Girls’ School principal Basanti Biswas also found the initiative heartening: “Something like this will lead to sensitisation of teachers, students and parents about energy conservation and environment.” Seema Sapru, principal of Heritage School , said she, too, felt inspired by Wangchuk’s movement and would, in fact, roll out the programme at the institute after the Boards exams were over. “I will encourage students not to iron twice a week,” she said.South City International School principal John Bagul extended his good wishes to The BSS but said it was difficult to implement it in a co-ed school as that could lead to boys turning up in crumpled clothes. “We are not yet ready for unpressed clothes,” said Bagul.Un-ironed uniform though does not mean shabby clothes. As fashion designer Rimi Nayak said, it actually translated to better care for one’s clothes. “Fold clothes with care after you wear them so that there is no awkward crease. Use hangers or fold properly and place them under the mattress. If someone decides to wash, the clothes can be straightened out and hung to dry,” she said.Wangchuk said smart crease was an indulgence one could do without to help the planet. “The power saved from ironing a person’s clothes can power four rural households,” he said. Environment activist Bonani Kakkar gave a thumbs up to the initiative. “Congratulations to the school. I hope many more schools would follow suit,” she said.

Title: Rights award for DU profG N Saibaba
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Kozhikode: G N Saibaba, professor at Delhi University and the leader of the Revolutionary Democratic Front (RDF), has been selected for this year’s Mukundan C Menon award instituted by the National Confederation of Human Rights Organisations (NCHRO).

Saibaba is currently in jail for alleged Maoist links.

Members of the jury felt that Saibaba has been working for the protection of the tribals and the poor in different parts of the country. He has been using his pen to highlight gross human rights violations in the mineral-rich areas in India, the jury said.“Though a paraplegic who could not move without assistance, he has never wavered from his mission despite great physical difficulties,” the jury said.

The award, consists of a cash purse of Rs 25,000, a plaque and a citation, given by NCHRO every year in recognition of the services rendered for the protection of human rights. TNN

Title: Wildfire ravages 3km of Kutch forest land
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The wildfire was reported on Thursday afternoon

A major wildfire was reported between Ravapar and Mata na Madh of Nakhatrana taluka in Kutch district on Thursday afternoon.

The fire gutted 3 km radius of forest area and could be doused by officials of Gujarat Mineral Development Corporation and forest department only late in the evening.

Title: Jaganmohan Reddy hints at doing away with Andhra Pradesh legislative council
Content:
Andhra Pradesh chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy

AMARAVATI: The Andhra Pradesh cabinet is likely to meet on Monday to give its nod to the resolution proposing to abolish the legislative council . Later, a bill to this effect may be introduced in the state assembly.Chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy on Thursday dropped enough indications on the government’s plans to do away with the bicameral system of legislature. A day after the legislative council referred the bills on three capital cities and abolition of AP Capital Region Development Authority (APCRDA) to a select committee, Jagan, said, “It is high time we thought of the need of continuance of the legislative council, which has been creating obstacles to making of laws by members of the state assembly who are elected by people,” he told the assembly.Stating that the council chairman’s decision to refer important bills passed by the assembly to a select committee had pained him and many legislators, the CM pointed out it was not mandatory for states to have a legislative council as only six states in the country have the system.“The upper house was created through a law made by the assembly to give advice on key issues,” he said. “Surprisingly, the legislative council in the state has become a big impediment to implementing peoples’ agenda. People gave mandate to legislators elected by them to make laws in their interest. We need to give a serious thought on whether to continue the council if it continues to block bills passed by the assembly.”Jagan further said the present assembly has enough intellectuals including professors, doctors, engineers, IT professionals, journalists, farmers and actors. “We trust the council will really help us make better laws, but this council has shattered our trust,” he said.Targeting TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu, he said the opposition leader in the assembly sat in the council gallery for hours together only to influence the chairman and breach rules. “The chairman clearly violated the rules by referring the bills to the select committee. He himself said it was against the rules. Still, he took the decision. It is like committing a murder despite knowing it is a crime,” Jagan fumed. He added that they would sit again on Monday and discuss the issue of continuing the council before taking a final call.In fact, several ministers have been talking about taking extreme measures including going for dissolution of the council. They have openly told council members to use their wisdom before trying to create hurdles to government business.The CM also requested assembly speaker Tammineni Sitaram to convene the House on Monday to discuss the issue. The assembly was originally scheduled to meet for three days, but the session was extended by a day on Thursday. On Jagan’s request, the speaker adjourned the assembly to Monday.Earlier, Jagan held discussions with former attorney general Mukul Rohatgi, who has been hired by the state government to defend the three capital cities case in the high court, and advocate general Sriram Subramanyam. He also summoned ministers and senior functionaries to the camp office and discussed the strategy to be adopted to take the issue forward.Earlier, the council was abolished in 1985. The then Channa Reddy government had passed a resolution to revive the legislative council in 1990 and sent it to Parliament for approval. Though the Rajya Sabha cleared the legislation authorising revival of the council, the legislation was stalled in the Lok Sabha due to its premature dissolution in 1991. In 2004, the YSR government passed another resolution on July 8 to revive the council, which finally happened in 2007.

Title: Polls to elect education panel chairperson & deputy next week
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

In the new nine-member committee, BJP has a majority with five members

NASHIK: The elections to the chairperson and deputy chairperson posts of the education committee of the Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) are likely to be held sometime next week.

On Thursday, the office of the town secretary of the municipal corporation, wrote a letter to divisional commissioner Rajaram Mane. The town secretary urged Mane to conduct the elections for the posts of chairperson and deputy chairperson of the education committee.

“The elections are likely to be held on any day next week. The dates are to be declared in a day or two,” said an NMC official.

The general body of the municipal corporation had revamped the education committee that deals with the NMC schools.

City mayor Satish Kulkarni had declared the names of the nine new education committee members during the recent general body (GB) meeting of NMC. The tenure of existing nine members of the committee had ended in November 2019.

In the new nine-member committee, BJP has a majority with five members. The Shiv Sena, meanwhile, has three members on the committee. NCP has just one member on the committee.

The new nine members of the education committee includes Sangita Gaikwad, Sarita Sonawane, Shivaji Gangurde, Sahin Mirza and Mukesh Shahane — all from the BJP. Jayashri Kharjul, Chandrakant Khade and Suryakant Lawte from the Shiv Sena are also part of the committee as is Jagdish Pawar from the Nationalist Congress Party (NCP).

Title: Man gets seven-year jail term for raping minor
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Bareilly: A fast track court of additional sessions judge Shrikrishan Chandra Singh awarded seven years of imprisonment to one Sanjeev Kumar Gangwar after finding him guilty of raping a minor girl in 2009. District government counsel advocate Suneeti Pathak said, since the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 was not in existence at that time, the rapist was awarded only seven years of imprisonment under IPC section 376 (rape) of Indian penal code.

According to the FIR lodged at CB Ganj police station, on June 2, 2009, Gangwar had abducted the girl when she was 14 years old. At that time, he was in his early 20s. The girl’s family had approached police and an FIR was lodged on June 16, 2009 in the matter.

Later, police followed up a clue and on July 12, 2010, rescued her from CB Ganj area when Gangwar was waiting to catch a bus with the girl.

Suresh Babu Sahu, additional district government counsel, said after his arrest in 2010, Gangwar had managed to get bail and is now, out of jail.

“The court has order to cancel his bail. He has been awarded seven years in jail under IPC sections 363 (kidnapping), 366 (inducing woman to compel her marriage) and 376 (rape). He is also slapped with a fine of Rs 9,000,” Sahu added.

Title: Enraged over sister’s affair, elder brother tries to kill her, cops come to girl’s rescue
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Bareilly: A man took his 18-year-old younger sister to a roadside cane field and allegedly shot at her. Thinking she was dead, he left her and fled from the spot. Police said that the girl’s brother was very upset after learning about her affair with a local youth.

The accused belongs to Budaun. On the pretext of visiting another sister, who is married and resides in Sambhal, the man took his younger sister - a BA first year student - on his motorcycle on Wednesday evening. As soon as they reached Behjoi, he stopped the motorcycle. He then shot at his sister and left her at the roadside field and fled. After regaining conscious, the girl somehow reached a road where a police response vehicle (PRV) on patrol spotted her. They took her to a hospital. Her condition is said to be critical.

The injured girl is from Aurchhi village under Faizganj Behata police station limits in Budaun district, the police said. “It was already dark and luckily our PRV team spotted the girl. She was bleeding profusely after being shot at. She was immediately taken to a community health centre at Behjoi from where doctors referred her to a higher medical facility. Her condition is critical,” SHO Behjoi inspector Ravindra Pratap Singh said.

The police added that upon reaching hospital, the girl narrated the entire incident. She told police, “I was going with my brother to visit our sister. He stopped the motorcycle saying that he needed to answer the nature’s call. Soon, he pulled out a pistol from his pocket and before I could realise what he was going to do, he shot at me. After a while I found myself lying on the field.”

The SHO also said that the girl’s brother was enraged after learning about her affair with a youth from their village. Since the girl continued to see the youth, he decided to kill her, the SHO said, adding, “We have registered an FIR under section 307 (attempt to murder) against the man, who is still absconding. Two teams have been formed to arrest him.”

Title: BJP out, but Fadnavis on calendars in Mantralaya
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

MUMBAI: Several calendars that were printed by the state legislature that mentioned Devendra Fadnavis as the chief minister were removed from all offices of Mantralaya on Thursday.

These were 2019 calendars that had one additional page for January 2020, which works as a stop-gap arrangement till the government prints new calendars for Mantralaya, the state secretariat, in the new year.

As these were printed early in 2019, Fadnavis and other ministers of the time were mentioned along with their posts.

“We always give one additional page for the first month of the next year as it takes time for us to print calendars, and government holidays and leaves are marked for the first month of the new year in those calendars for the government staff to follow,” an official from Vidhan Bhavan said.

The calendars remained in use for nearly two months despite a regime change in late November. NCP MLA Jayant Patil said if the mention of the previous government was deliberate, then officials would be penalised.

Title: BDA razes under-construction illegal colonies at three locations
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Bareilly: Coming down heavily on rampant illegal constructions going on in the city, the Bareilly Development Authority (BDA) demolished unauthorised constructions of residential colonies in Bara Bypass, Izzatnagar and Bhojipura areas in the past three days.

BDA officials said despite notices to colonisers and builders, the construction work continued in these areas. Residential colonies spreading over 20,000 square metres and 18 bighas were being developed illegally in the Green Belt area, and hence, were demolished, said officials.

Speaking to TOI, BDA vice-chairperson Divya Mittal said, “The construction of residential colonies is rampant in the city, especially on the outskirts. We identified three unauthorised constructions taking place near Bara Bypass, Bhojipura and Izzatnagar areas and warned the colonisers and builders over illegal construction in the Green Belt area. We even served notices to the violators and sought their response, but to no avail. Thus, a crackdown was launched and illegal constructions were demolished during the past three days.”

BDA sources said a coloniser, Shamshuddin, had allegedly taken up the construction of a residential colony illegally after occupying around 20,000 square metres in the Green Belt area in Mudhiya Ahmed Nagar near Bara Bypass. Similarly, Bhupendra Kurmi and Vinod Kumar allegedly occupied 18 bighas for setting up a colony Maharaja Agrasen City in Izzatnagar area, while one Ghulam Sabir was allegedly constructing Aryan City in Saidpur area of Bhojipura illegally, said officials. Since all these constructions were taking place in the Green Belt area, they were demolished.

The police force from Izzatnagar and Bhojipura police stations assisted the BDA enforcement squads in carrying out the demolition drive without any hurdle, said officials.

In December, BDA had demolished as many as six residential constructions and sealed several others that had come up illegally in the Green Belt area in Mudhiya Ahed Nagar near Bara Bypass. The encroachers had occupied nearly 20 bighas for more than five years. Six structures were demolished while several others were sealed by BDA.

Title: Citing HC order, panchayat officer suspended over scam allegation appeals for restoration
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Bareilly: Suspended district Panchayati Raj officer (DPRO) Chandrika Prasad on Thursday met district magistrate (DM) Nitish Kumar to request that he be allowed to rejoin work, as the high court has quashed the government’s order, attaching him to headquarters. The DM asked Prasad to approach the government first, as the court order didn’t mention him. Prasad was suspended last month after he was held responsible of misappropriating public funds.

UP joint secretary Jogendra Prasad had issued the order on December 17, in which Prasad was attached to state headquarters in Lucknow, along with six other DPROs, all of whom were found guilty of misappropriating funds while releasing performance grants to village panchayats, in departmental inquiries.

The other suspended DPROs are Rajendra Prasad of Unnao, Radha Krishan Bharti of Sonbhadra, Amarjeet Singh of Bulandshahr, Arvind Kumar Singh of Lucknow, Shahnaz Ansari of Kasganj and Lalji Dubey of Pratapgarh.

On Thursday, at the meeting with the DM, Prasad argued that all six other suspended DPROs had been restored to their official positions following the HC order, but the DM was not swayed by this argument.

“I don’t follow what other DMs do. I’ll follow rules. In this case, Prasad can be allowed to join his office only after I receive such directions from the government, to whom the HC order is directed,” the DM said.

Notably, DPRO Prasad was booked for misappropriation of funds released by the Centre as “performance grants” for the betterment of self-sustaining village panchayats. The FIR was registered on November 23 at Barabanki district, where Prasad was posted before being transferred to Bareilly in September 2019.

Vigilance inspector Anil Yadav had registered the FIR against Prasad under sections 420 (cheating), 466 (forgery of record), 467 (forgery of valuable security), 468 (forgery for of cheating), 471 (using as genuine a forged document), 166 (public servant disobeying law) of IPC, and the Prevention of Corruption Act.

Title: Trichy to host district-level chess tourney
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: A district-level chess tournament for children less than 15 years will be held in the city on January 25 and 26.

Organised by the Yarish school of chess and approved by the Trichy district chess association , the tournament will be held at ER higher secondary school in Melachintamani.

Participants will be classified under four categories namely under-7, under-9, 13 and 15 age categories. Contestants securing first two spots in the under-7 and under-13 categories will get a chance to represent Trichy in the state-level chess tournament.

“The chess tournament is open only to Trichy district players and birth certificates should be submitted as age proof. Registration can also be done on the spot but before 9.30am on January 25,” V Senthil Prabu, organiser said.

Participants have to bring their own chess kits including clocks. The tournament supervised by an arbiter recognized by the FIDE (International Chess Federation) will follow the FIDE chess rules.

An entry fee of Rs 200 will be collected from each participant. Interested participants are requested to contact 99526-91664 for registration.

Title: Nashik: 4 years on, plan for flyover at Sarda circle in a limbo
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The four-lane elevated corridor was planned from Sarda Circle in the heart of the city to Datta Mandir chowk a... Read More

NASHIK: The project to build a six-km long flyover at Sarda Circle to decongest the key junciton has hit a roadblock.

The National Highways Authority of India ( NHAI ), which was preparing the draft of the project, has conveyed its inability to do so due to financial constraints.

The four-lane elevated corridor was planned from Sarda Circle in the heart of the city to Datta Mandir chowk at Nashik Road at a cost of around Rs 1,000 crore.

The project would have reduced the regular traffic chaos at the busy Nashik Road, especially Dwarka chowk, which remains chock-a-block with vehicles daily during peak hours.

The Nashik unit of NHAI shot off a letter to the state public works department (national highway division) a few days back informing that they would not be able to undertake the project unless the Union ministry of road transport and highways provides funds for it.

It has requested the state PWD (NH division) to prepare the detailed project report (DPR). NHAI sources confirmed the developments and maintained that the agency was not in a position to implement it.

“The project is at a nascent stage as the DPR is yet to the prepared. So the other agency can implement the project,” added a NHAI official.

During his visit to the city in November 2016, Union road transport and highways minister Nitin Gadkari had announced that the flyover project would be undertaken by his ministry.

Nashik MP Hemant Godse had drawn Gadkari’s attention about the need to have a flyover to tackle the congestion in that stretch.

According to sources in the state PWD (NH division), the issue would be discussed with the senior authorities of the department. “The project entails huge cost. We would prepare the DPR if we get the nod from the department,” added PWD officials.

Initially, the state PWD (NH division) had started preparing the project DPR when it was planned but after Gadkari’s announcement, the Nashik unit of NHAI took over the responsibility of making the DPR.

Interestingly, the Nashik unit of NHAI had proposed to the headquarters in October last year to include the flyover project under the ministry’s ambitious Bharatmala project, a mammoth program for the highways sector that focuses on optimizing efficiency of freight and passenger movement across the country.

Godse claimed that he would pursue the matter both with Centre and the state government to ensure that the project sees the light of the day. “The project will be implemented even if the implementing agency gets altered. This flyover is essential to reduce the congestion at Dwarka circle and Nashik Road,” he added.

Godse said that since an elevated corridor is also planned at Nashik Road under the proposed Nashik Metro project, there is need for all agencies to have a meeting to see that both the flyover and the metro corridor at are planned properly.

Title: 20 farmers get back 17 bighas of ‘occupied land’ by Jauhar University
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Rampur: A day after taking possession of 104 bigha of land of Mohammad Ali Jauhar University, run by the Jauhar Trust, Rampur administration on Thursday launched the process of releasing “occupied land” to those farmers of Aliyaganj village who had registered 26 FIRs relating to land grab against MP and senior Samajwadi Party leader Azam Khan. Six more farmers will take the possession of their land on Friday.

Rampur DM Aunjaneya Kumar told TOI that possession on 17 bighas of farmers’ land that lie on Jauhar University campus was given to 20 farmers on the spot after their names and land numbers were found in revenue records.

The land is not part of the 104 bigha that the administration took over on the directions of revenue board court in Prayagraj.

Meanwhile, Jauhar university vice-chancellor Sultan Mohammad Khan had condemned the action taken by the Rampur authorities and said they had violated the directions of the Allahabad high court order that without prior permission from varsity authorities, police and administrative officials shall not enter the campus

The 17 bigha of land was allegedly grabbed by Azam Khan for his university. In this connection, more than 26 FIRs had been lodged against Khan. Farmers had alleged that Azam had grabbed land with the help of former circle officer Alay Hasan Khan, who is on the run.

Earlier, Rampur district administration had also put up the names of Azam Khan and Alay Hasan Khan on the land mafia portal of the state government.

Title: Gujarat: Two accused in Rs 91.5 lakh angadia theft case nabbed
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

RAJKOT: Two accused in the Rs 91.5 lakh Limbdi angadia theft case in Surendranagar district were arrested from Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan, respectively on Thursday.

One of the accused, Babusinh Tomar (30) was arrested from Fatehpur Sikri in UP, while the other, Devendrasinh Parmar (34), was nabbed from Dholpur in Rajasthan.

Earlier, Surendranagar local crime branch had arrested Udhamsinh Gurjar and Pradeepsinh Parmar, the key accused of the crime on December 25 last year.

Gurjar and Tomar had been following Ramesh Naran Angadia Firm employee, Pravin Patel, from the time the latter had boarded a bus to go to Rajkot from Ahmedabad ST bus depot on December 12 last year. The accused had plotted to steal Patel’s bag at Nandanvan Hotel on Limbdi National Highway, where the third accused, Devendrasinh, had already reached on a stolen bike.

“When Patel’s bus reached Nandanvan Hotel and he alighted along with other passengers for refreshments, Gurjar and Parmar allegedly stole his bag containing 2kg gold worth Rs76 lakh, two gold chains worth Rs10.50 lakh and Rs5 lakh in cash, and fled from the bus,” said Deepak Dhol, inspector with Surendranagar LCB.

Gurjar, who had been caught on a CCTV footage and identified, was arrested from Dholpur in Rajasthan, revealed Pradeepsinh’s name leading to his arrest. Pradeepsinh divulged the names of the other co-accused.

The other accused booked in the case include Santosh Gehlot, Pushkar Jat and Bijendrasinh Rajput. “We had formed three teams of cops and dispatched them to Fatehpur Sikri, Agra and Dholpur. We had obtained the addresses of Tomar and Devendrasinh. Hence, we nabbed them from their residences in Fatehpur Sikri and Dholpur,” said Dhol.

The police recovered 599 gram gold worth Rs 22.4 lakh from Tomar and Devendrasinh. From Gurjar and Pradeepsinh’s possession, cops had earlier recovered 1.265 kg gold worth Rs 48 lakh and Rs 1 lakh in cash.

Title: Policy for rare diseases on anvil but fails to tap into patient knowledge
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: While the Centre has made attempts to address the problem of rare diseases and even finalised a draft policy for rare diseases, experts say that the draft has completely missed out on covering the aspect of patient knowledge . In such cases, it is often the patient who may have more knowledge about the condition than doctors themselves.However, the policy in its current form fails to tap into this knowledge. Experts opine that the policy has been drafted based mostly on assumptions and does not address the real issues. It is estimated that around five to seven per cent of the population suffers from such diseases but there is no robust registry for such patients .“It does not address the crux of the problem which is to know who these patients are and where they are. They have not added the most important constituent to this conversation — patients advocates, patient groups and patients. It is a global practice to include patients while formulating a policy and it is more important in case of rare diseases. A patient is much more aware of his problem than anybody else, including the doctors and unless this knowledge is tapped, the policy will not serve the purpose,” said Syed Sanaullah, management committee member of the Indian Organisation of Rare Diseases (IORD), an umbrella organisation representing patients and patient groups for rare diseases.While the draft policy talks about having a national registry by ICMR and focussing on high-risk families (of known patients), there is no concrete attempt on identifying and diagnosing patients in a systematic manner. The focus needs to be on finding unknown patients.“It often takes years for a rare disease patient to be identified. Therefore to have a robust registry, an effort needs to be made in bringing about awareness among doctors, having a system where all patients are screened and creating some kind of a knowledge bank for reference when a doctor wants to cross check for a rare disease,” pointed out Dr Srinivas Namineni, a paediatrician who works with rare disease patients. He also said that the policy ignores the aspect of ‘orphan drugs’, which are useful to treat rare diseases but are not manufactured due to being unprofitable.

Title: Two booked for illegally lion sighting in Amreli
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Spot where cub’s carcass was found

Rajkot: Two persons were booked for illegally lions sighting in Ramgadh Vidi of Savarkundla range in Amreli district on Wednesday night.

Police said the accused, identified as Bakul Khuman, had called Nirav Joshi to see lions.

“As lion sighting has been made legal only in Sasan and Devalia of Talala taluka in Gir Somnath district and Ambardi Park in Dhari by the government, sighting the lions elsewhere becomes a crime. Khuman, a local, knew where the big cats would be found and had called Joshi to see them. After receiving information about them, we detained them and collected Rs 15,000 from them,” said a forest official.

Box: Cub carcass found

A decomposed carcass of a three to four month lion cub was found from Senjal revenue of Savarkundala range of Dhari Gir east on Thursday. “The cub is believed to have died 10 to 12 days ago. The reason for its death can be ascertained after its postmortem,” said a forest official.

Title: Accused in murder case hacked to death by gang
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: A 28-year-old man was hacked to death by an armed gang at Woraiyur on Thursday morning. The deceased, D Pugalendhi from Minnappan street in Woraiyur, was the second accused in the murder of S Manikandan, 22, from Minappan street. The prime accused Senthilkumar , 43, is Pugalendhi’s uncle. Both had come out on conditional bail a month ago.

Police said the gang surrounded Pugalendhi close to his house when he was on his way to Woraiyur police station on a two-wheeler to sign as per the bail conditions. The gang then launched an indiscriminate attack with machetes and knife. He sustained fatal injuries on his head and several parts of his body.

The murder murder triggered panic among the people in the area.

The body was shifted to the Mahatma Gandhi memorial government hospital in Trichy . Police said they are yet to get concrete clue about the number people involved in the murder.

On September 22, 2019, Senthilkumar and Pugalendhi verbally abused Manikandan near his house and attempted to murder him with machete. Manikandan received heavy blow on the back of the head and left chin. He was admitted to the MGMGH for treatment where he died.

Title: Bike-borne chain snatchers strike at pedestrians
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Two people were robbed of their gold chains by bike-borne chain-snatchers in different incidents in the last two days.

In one of the incidents, a couple of culprits targeted S Rajammal, 55, of Kamaraj Nagar near the Airport on Wednesday. In her complaint, Rajammal said that she was returning from work when the bikers came towards her near the service road on Kaja Nagar main road. The pillion rider snatched her 3.5 sovereign gold chain and the duo escaped.

Though the woman screamed for help, there was no one to come to her aid. She lodged a complaint with the KK Nagar police, who registered a case. The woman said that she can identify the bike.

In the other incident, M Gunasekaran, 21, of Gandhi Nagar, A Palur was returning home on Tuesday night when two people on a bike came near him near the Agraharam Vinayagar temple, and snatched his 1.5 sovereign gold chain and fled the scene.

He lodged a complaint with the Jeeyapuram police on Wednesday. The Jeeyapuram police registered a case of robbery. The accused were yet to be arrested in both cases.

Title: Hyderabad court to decide Tunda’s fate on February 4
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Lashkar-e-Taiba operative, Abdul Karim Tunda

HYDERABAD: Fate of suspected Lashkar-e-Taiba operative, Abdul Karim Tunda (77), will be decided by Nampally court on February 4 , some six years after he was arrested for being a co-conspirator with a Pakistan national, Saleem Junaid.

Tunda was accused of being a bomb expert and declared an accused in the 1998 Saleem Junaid conspiracy module case registered by a special investigation team (SIT) of Central Crime Station (CCS). SIT officials arrested Tunda in October 2013, a few months after he was nabbed by central security agencies at the Indo-Nepal border. Prior to that, he allegedly resided in Pakistan for several years.

After conducting trial against Tunda, Nampally court on Wednesday decided to give its verdict on February 4. Tunda has been brought to Hyderabad after he was taken to different locations of the country, since he faces a bunch of criminal cases across India. Last week, he was shifted to Ghaziabad in Uttar Pradesh from Cherlapally jail, and he will be brought back to the city by Hyderabad police to produce him in the court on February 4.

Tunda is accused of training several youngsters to commit different terror activities in India by calling them to Pakistan and Bangladesh in the mid 1990s. One of these youngsters happened to be Pakistan national Saleem Junaid, who was nabbed in Hyderabad when he and few other members of the module were planning to commit terror strike during Ganesh festival in Hyderabad in 1998.

It was on the confession of Junaid, Hyderabad police then included Tunda, who was then a fugitive, among the 24 accused persons in the case for training Junaid and others in Bangladesh to commit offence in Hyderabad. Junaid was convicted in this case with six others several years ago. Tunda is booked under sections 120 b (conspiracy) of IPC, Arms Act, Explosives Act, Passport Act and others.

Title: Govt hospitals to start ante-natal hepatitis check
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: State-run hospitals will soon start ante-natal checking for hepatitis B in order to prevent mother-to-child transmission of the virus. This is one of the various measures that the state health department is taking up to combat hepatitis, in sync with the World Health Organisation’s (WHO) target to eliminate the virus by 2030.

“We are setting up ante-natal screening facilities for hepatitis B in all state-run hospitals across the state. This will help us take measures in case the woman is detected positive,” said a health department official on the sidelines of a dissemination meeting on hepatitis, organised by Liver Foundation West Bengal (LFWB) on Thursday.

“We need to spread awareness to every health worker so that they understand the disease burden. This will help tackle the hepatitis menace to a great extent,” said Ajay Chakraborty, director of health services.
