Title: Manjula Manasa suspended from Mysuru Bar Association
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Mysuru Bar Association members on Thursday abstained from court proceedings and staged a protest

MYSURU: A day after leader of the opposition Siddaramaiah made remarks about a section of Bar Association members that they behaved like hooligans during a recent general body meeting, the association members abstained from court proceedings on Thursday and demanded apology from him.

It has also suspended advocate Manjula Manasa who was also former chairperson of Karnataka Commission for Women, for making the bar proceedings public and turning it into a political issue.

Association president S Anandkumar on Thursday told reporters that Siddaramaiah’s statement has pained the members. He should immediately withdrew his remarks failing which a statewide protest will be launched, he said.

“Siddaramaiah while speaking to the press had claimed that a woman advocate was threatened during the meeting. It is totally untrue. No such incident has taken place,” he stated.

The Bar had decided not to represent the accused student in sedition case and it was a unanimous decision, Anandkumar added.

“Siddaramaiah today is not a member of the Bar Council or the Mysuru Bar Association . His comment on Bar members have hurt the fraternity and we demand his apology,” the president stated.

Meanwhile, Manjula Manasa, a member, who allegedly revealed the association’s proceedings in public and was along with former CM Siddaramaiah when he made his remarks about the Bar’s decision, has been suspended from membership with immediate effect.

Title: Secunderabad: Old age home management, kin of inmates booked
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: With a call landing on ‘Dial 100’ about a group of senior citizens and youngsters being illegally confined at an old age home at Nagaram on Wednesday night, police rushed to the place and discovered that they were lodged there with the consent of family members. However, the squalid conditions at the place forced authorities to conduct a probe and they found out that the facility was operating illegally.

Police registered a case against management and family members of senior citizens. Preparations are on to shift all inmates to other rehabilitation centres under the supervision of revenue, women and child-welfare department officials.

On Wednesday, Keesara police received a call on the ‘Dial 100’ facility about people being illegally confined at Mamatha Old Age Home at Shilpanagar, Nagaram.

“Our team went there and found out that they were not kidnapped. Relatives of the inmates lodged them there by paying the organisers amounts ranging between Rs 5,000 and Rs 10,000 per month. However, the conditions in the facility were pathetic. There is just one toilet for 73 people and there are no sufficient beds. Psychiatric patients are being chained at times,” Keesara inspector J Narender Goud said.

Police along with revenue, women and child welfare department officials conducted an inquiry into the allegations of running the facility illegally as a psychiatric rehabilitation centre with 73 inmates, including 22 women.

“The organisers, who were running the facility for the past three years, have permission to run an old age home. But they also started taking people suffering with psychiatric problems and those suffering from alcohol and smoking addiction, which is illegal. Based on the violations found, a case was registered under Sections 406,420,324,342 of IPC and Section 24 of Maintenance and Welfare of Parents and Senior Citizens Act, 2007 against the organisers and family members of the senior citizens,”the inspector said.

“The inmates will be shifted to other centres with proper medical care under the supervision of police, revenue and women and child welfare departments,” he added.

Title: Bihar schoolteacher’s math video stumps Anand Mahindra, Shah Rukh Khan
Content:
Ruby Kumari

Whaaaat? I didn’t know about this clever shortcut. Wish she had been MY math teacher. I probably would have been a… https://t.co/kUjnP1tfep — anand mahindra (@anandmahindra) 1579683428000

Can’t tell you how many of my life’s issues this one simple calculation has solved wow! Sending it to #byju to incl… https://t.co/STRHdIMcXw — Shah Rukh Khan (@iamsrk) 1579687755000

PATNA: A schoolteacher from Bihar’s Banka district now counts Bollywood superstar Shah Rukh Khan and industrialist Anand Mahindra among her fans. A video of her “unique” method of teaching multiplication to her students has gone viral with more than 15,000 retweets and over 55,000 likes from Twitter users.The extraordinary teaching skills of Ruby Kumari of Baunsi Middle School in Banka drew nationwide attention after Mahindra posted a tweet along with the video. “Whaaaat? I didn’t know about this clever shortcut. Wish she had been MY math teacher. I probably would have been a lot better at the subject! (sic),” the industrialist wrote.Ruby’s video was already drawing attention after ‘Teachers of Bihar’, a group that promotes teachers from the state on social media, posted in on Twitter, Facebook and other social media platforms.But after Mahindra’s tweet, the video spread like wildfire on the internet and soon it was the turn of Shah Rukh to get stumped. “Can’t tell you how many of my life’s issues this one simple calculation has solved, wow! Sending it to Byju to include it in their teaching methods (sic),” the actor wrote in his tweet.Overwhelmed by the likes of Mahindra and Khan tweeting about her, Ruby, made another video to thank Shah Rukh, Mahindra and people across the country who loved her maths trick. “I thank superstar Shahrukh Khan and Anand Mahindraji for liking my video and retweeting it. I am very happy my innovation is being watched by people across the India. I am thankful to the ‘Teachers of Bihar-the Changemakers’ for giving me the opportunity by sharing my video on their platform (sic),” she posted.In the video, she is shown demonstrating to her students how to do the multiplication of 9X4 using a simple method to calculate using fingers. To multiply 9X4, she shows, hold the fourth finger on left hand and count the digits to its left, which gives 3, and then count the digits after the fourth finger, which gives 6, joining both gives the result 36. In the video students are seen enjoying doing the multiplication shortcut.Education minister Krishna Nandan Prasad Verma told TOI, “I’m impressed with the way Ruby Kumari taught the kids at school. Other teachers in the state should also coin such innovative techniques that students find easy and fun to learn.”He added: “Earlier, Bihar was known for the wrong reasons but now several changes are being witnessed in the education sector under the leadership of CM Nitish Kumar.”In Video: Watch:Teacher turns fingers into calculators in unique way to multiply

Title: Infighting had destroyed many great civilisations: Mohammed Kunhi
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Thousands of devotees took part in the Shivarathri Shivayogi car festival organised as part of Suttur Jathra M... Read More

MYSURU: All faiths have a sole aim of uniting people irrespective of caste, creed, sex and colour, but unfortunately people these days are divided on religious lines, said Mohammed Kunhi, director of publishing house Shanthi Prakashana.

Delivering a special lecture at the religious meet organised on the third day of Suttur Fair on Thursday, Kunhi bemoaned that we are living in a polarized era.

“We should understand there is only one God for all faiths”, he added.

Renowned philosophers have pointed out in the past that world’s great civilizations were destroyed not by an external attack, but by internal squabbling and fight, he said.

“The bone of contention of all religions is over religious supremacy, but the aim of dharma is not to defeat people but to unite them. It never encourages anger and provocation among people,” he said.

In his address, Karnataka Sahitya Academy president B V Vasanthkumar advised Lingayats and Veerashaivas to stop fighting over the issue of religious status.

Hindus and Muslims must adopt the teachings of Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa and Santa Shishunala Sharief, he added.

Shivarathri Shivayogi car festival

Thousands of devotees took part in the Shivarathri Shivayogi car festival organised as part of Suttur Jathra Mahtosav .

They pulled the chariot and the festivities began at 10.30am after Suttur Mutt Seer Shivarathri Deshikendra Swami with Charukeerthi Bhattaraka Swami of Jain Mutt of Shravanabelagola pulled the car after offering puja to Adijagaduguru Shivarathri Shivayogi Swami Utsavamurthy.

On Thursday, in a first, devotees pulled both the small and big chariots around the Mutt.

Cattle fair inaugurated

Minister of mines and geology C C Patil inaugurated the 62nd cattle fair held as part of the Suttur fair in the presence of Davangere Gavimutt Dr Sri Nalwadi Shanthalinga Shivacharya Swami and Urilingapeddi Mutt Jnanaprakash Swami.

Title: Hyderabad: Students to mark 70th Republic Day with events on CAA and NRC
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

AIMIM is planning a meeting similar to Tiranga Rally on midnight of January 25. (File photo)

HYDERABAD: To mark the 70th Republic Day on January 26, students from various institutes across the city have organised events on Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens ( NRC ).

“As the Constitution completes 70 years of existence, we believe it is time to raise our voice against CAA and NRC which are unconstitutional. We will be launching a campaign from the university to bring together students opposing CAA and NRC across the country,” said Maulana Azad National Urdu University (Manuu) student union president, Umar Faruq Quadri.

The Manuu student union has decided to carry out a ‘Tiranga Rally’ on January 26 within the campus. As part of the campaign, the union will be appealing to students’ community across the country to send one lakh postcards to President Ram Nath Kovind raising their concerns over CAA and NRC. “After the rally, several social activists will join us and deliver a talk on CAA and NRC. Following this, we will be issuing postcards from Manuu,” said Quadri.

To mark the occasion, Nalsar University will be organising a conference — Courts & The Constitution, 2019 in review — on January 25 and 26.

The conference aims to review the past, present and discuss the future of constitutionalism in India. “During the conference, various developments pertaining to courts and constitutions will be reviewed. It is an annual conference. This time, it is being conducted on the 70th Republic Day over its relevance with the day,” said a Nalsar student.

It maybe noted that the executive council of the university’s student bar council had also objected the CAA and NRC. Meanwhile, students of University of Hyderabad ( UoH ), English and Foreign Languages University (Eflu), Tata Institute of Social Sciences ( TISS ) are also contemplating holding events over CAA and NRC on Republic Day.

Title: IOC to adopt Miyawaki method for green development
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The Indian Oil Corporation (IOC), with the help of Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC), will take up greenery restoration and development by adopting Miyawaki method in the city. The Miyawaki is a method developed by the Japan botanist Akira Miyawaki to develop dense and native forests. This technique ensures plant growth is 10 times faster and the resulting plantation is 30 times denser than usual. To begin with Miyawaki method will be first implemented in Gachibowli and extended to other areas in the later phases.

The IOC, which is taking up the project under corporate social responsibility, has invited TRS MP Joginapally Santosh Kumar as chief guest for the inauguration on February 17. IOC general manager SS Prasad said Santosh Kumar was invited as he has taken up `Green Challenge movement like a mission in the state for improvement of greenery in the state.

Prasad said the IOC had taken up projects in education and sanitation field under corporate social responsibility scheme earlier. Santosh Kumar appreciated the efforts by the IOC and said it was the responsibility of every citizen to protect the environment. He said he had adopted one forest near Keesara and assured all help in the project taken up by the IOC.

Title: MIM plans massive meet at Charminar to mark Republic Day
Content:
Asaduddin Owaisi

Mark your calendars: 1 On the intervening night of 25-26 Jan, a Poets’ Protest Meeting @ Charminar to celebrate th… https://t.co/8hJlKfJUa5 — Asaduddin Owaisi (@asadowaisi) 1578663538000

HYDERABAD: Seeing the response to Tiranga Rally, the All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen has now decided to organise another meeting at Charminar on the intervening night of January 25 and 26 as part of its protest against CAA and NRC . “On the intervening night of 25-26 Jan, a Poets’ Protest Meeting @ Charminar to celebrate the Republic of India (& to save it from #CAA_NRC_NPR),” tweeted AIMIM president and Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi .The party plans to organise a mushaira (social gathering with Urdu poetry) and will hoist the national flag at midnight. An event — ‘Ek Shaam, Shamvidhaan Ke Naam’ — is also being organised by the Hyderabad Muslim Women’s Forum and Transgender Organisations JAC at Lamakaan in the afternoon.Numerous flash protests against CAA and NRC are also planned at several public places such as metro stations, malls, parks across the city on Republic Day. A public meeting is a also being organised by the All India Dalit Muslim Adivasi Progressive Front at Mehdipatnam.Meanwhile, the Telangana high court on Thursday directed the Hyderabad police to inform the court by Friday whether they had accorded permission to the proposed January 25 midnight programme by the United Muslim Action Committee and AIMIM at Charminar.

Title: Runway re-carpeting, work on bays at Trichy international airport to begin in February
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Re-carpeting work of the runway at Trichy international airport will begin in the first week of February during which time some flights will be rescheduled during the night, Airports Authority of India has said. Two more additional bays will also be established as part of development works, airport director K Gunasekaran told TOI.

While the runway work is estimated to cost Rs 20 crore, the additional bays will be established at a cost of Rs 1 crore. A Mumbai-based company has bagged both the contracts and Rs 19.85 crore has been sanctioned already, Gunasekaran said. The runway with a length of 2,423 metres and width of 45 metres is being re-carpeted with tar after ten years. This includes a 580-metre-long stretch made of concrete now. “Frequent landing and take-off of flights usually lead to exhaustion of runways. Natural weather phenomena like rain and sun also affect the runway surface which should be re-laid once in five years. So, re-carpeting is essential for the safety of flights as well as passengers”, Gunasekaran added.

“Re-carpeting activity on runway would lead to disruption of flight movements. To enable the work to be executed without any disruption, flight movements have been rescheduled. Flight operation has been suspended between 1 am and 8 am at the airport”, he further stated. Establishing of two more bays is also a major development work slated to begin in a few weeks. As of now, there are five bays at the airport but only two of them are connected to aprons. Hence to decongest passenger traffic, new bays are to come up with apron, Gunasekaran added.

Title: BBMP says Bengaluru is ODF++, but urine-filled roads tell another story
Content:
The footpath on 11th Main in Malleswarm reeks of urine

TimesView It is only fair that BBMP impose the strictest penalties on people who urinate in public places. Especially, since most of them have access to toilets at home. But it’s also necessary to make sure public toilets are clean and well-maintained, and most importantly, functional. Bodily functions can’t always be controlled, but the fact that people urinate in the open is emblematic of the way we regard every deserted stretch, and sometimes even populated streets, as possible urinals. This attitude needs to change. In conjunction with building more toilets, a largescale campaign designed to discourage public urination would be necessary.

BENGALURU: Last week, BBMP declared Bengaluru Open Defecation Free (ODF)++ — which requires a city to be free from open urination among other things — and invited objections, if any, to the tag. Several Bengalureans, however, feel Palike officials should instead have taken a walk near Chickpet Metro Station to know where the city really stands.Puddles of urine pave the roads next to the station but people still manage to find space to relieve themselves. Not many can walk through these stretches — there’s no way you can avoid them if you have to go to City Market from the Metro station — without feeling nauseous.Sajjan Raj Mehta, a trade activist, said, “Chickpet is a busy market area with 15,000 shops and a daily floating population of over two lakh. But public toilets are very few. Lack of knowledge is another reason why people don’t use public loos as no signboards are put up anywhere.”Chickpet is no aberration. Such stretches dot the city. In Malleswaram, a 300-metre stretch on 11th Main is used by auto, cab and ambulance drivers to attend to nature’s call, notwithstanding that a pay-and-use toilet is only 200 metres away.“My house directly faces the spot. The issue has been brought up several times at ward committee meetings, but all the authorities do is assure us another toilet will be built soon. We are yet to see any progress,” said a member of Malleswaram resident welfare association.As per records, Bengaluru has 587 functional public toilets, including 418 pay-and-use facilities and 169 e-toilets. Another 102 pay-and-use toilets are not used.BBMP officials said they are working on ensuring people don’t urinate in public. Special commissioner Randeep D told TOI, “Currently, at some urinals, the public is charged Rs 5 or Rs 10, but we want to bring in a policy where urinals are free. One can actually see the closest toilet on Google. We also want to install signboards in a few areas. We will start restoring the 100-odd toilets that are currently dysfunctional.”It may be recalled that earlier this month Randeep had tweeted, “BBMP has imposed fines on those found urinating in public. As BBMP is keen to make Bengaluru Open Urination Free, request citizens to use Google Maps to find the nearest public toilet.”Police were earlier fining people urinating in the open. “We were asked not to impose penalties as a senior citizen raised objections saying that he was diabetic and that making him pay fine was tantamount to harassment,” a senior police officer said.Penalising those urinating in public is now the duty of BBMP health officers. There’s a proposal to increase the fine from Rs 100 to Rs 500 for a first-time offender and Rs 1,000 for subsequent offences.RWAs have lobbied with corporates to get public toilets built in their areas under CSR. But large tracts of Benglauru are still bereft of such facilities. “I have never seen a public loo in Whitefield...Lack of toilets has led to the present situation. We have e-toilets that have been installed under CSR,” said a Whitefield resident.Randeep said they need to double the number of toilets. “The challenge in coming up with more toilets is locating the correct site. If we find the right place, we don’t find sewage lines. It will take a couple of months to provide all the facilities from our end.”

Title: All-night concert at IIM Bangalore this weekend
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

IIMB file photo

BENGALURU: The Indian Institute of Management, Bangalore will host the 17th edition of ‘Yamini’, an all-night music and dance concert, at its amphitheatre from 6.30pm on Saturday. The concert, organised by Spicmacay’s IIMB Chapter, will conclude at 6.30am on Sunday.

The event will see a mix of artists, from senior to recent Sangeet Natak Yuva Puraskar awardees.

Sixteen students studying different programmes at IIM-B worked for eight months to put the concert together. Faculty coordinator of the event is Prof Tirthatanmoy Das, who teaches economics & social sciences at the institute.

Dhrithi Mahadevan, doctoral student, marketing, and key organiser of Yamini 2020, said the event follows the pattern of five back-to-back concerts from dusk to dawn: Carnatic vocal concert, Hindustani vocal, Carnatic instrumental, Hindustani instrumental and one dance form.

The line-up this year is: Abhishek Raghuram for Carnatic vocal, Vidwan Shashank Subramanyam for Carnatic instrumental (flute), Rajan & Sajan Misra for Hindustani vocal, Shubhendra Rao for Hindustani instrumental (sitar), and Guru Keremane Shivananda Hegde (Yakshagana).

Entry is free, though a valid ID card is needed.

Spicmacay or the Society for the Promotion of Indian Classical Music and Culture Amongst Youth is a non-political nationwide voluntary movement that organises programmes of classical music and dance, folk arts, crafts, yoga, classic cinema, etc.

Title: Telangana: Cops bust international gang moving ganja from AP to Sri Lanka
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Police seized 180 kilos of ganja worth Rs 21 lakh from the possession of the accused.

HYDERABAD: Mahabubnagar police on Thusday busted an international ganja peddling racket and arrested four persons who were transporting the contraband from Andhra Pradesh to Sri Lanka . Police seized 180 kilos of ganja worth Rs 21 lakh from the possession of the accused. The gang was using RFID tags to track the contraband during its transit across international waters.

The arrested were identified as P Satish from Madurai, K Kalyan from Hyderabad, M Ajith of Tamil Nadu ’s Theni and G Surendran of Chandrayangutta. Their associates — Sivaneswaran, Ramu, Murthy and Ram Reddy — are absconding. On January 4, a car driven by Sivaneswaran carrying 180 kilos of ganja stuffed in water proof packets, rammed into a parked lorry at Thatikonda on NH-44 near Bhootpur.

Ajith sitting in the front seat suffered severe injuries in the mishap while Sivaneswaran fled from the scene with the help of other accused in another car abandoning Ajith. The driver of the lorry noticed ganja in the car and informed the police.

During investigation, cops found out that Satish and Kalyan who have a history of ganja peddling were transporting the seized ganja from Sileru in Vishakapatnam to Madurai. Recently, Satish and Kalyan had started procuring ganja from Ramu and Murthy at Sileru for Rs 5000 a kilo and selling the same to Jayachandran of Rameshwaram for Rs 13,000 a kilo.

“From Rameshwaram area, the accused were transporting ganja to Sri Lanka through boats and selling the same in Sri Lanka for Rs 18,000 a kilo. The gang tags the contraband with RFID chips to track its movement over the sea,” Mahbubnagar SP Rema Rajeswari said.

On January 1, Satish came to Hyderabad and met Kalyan. They hired Surendran’s car to transport the contraband. On January 3, Satish, Sivaneswaran, Ajith, Kalyan and Surendran met in Bhadrachalam and went to Sileru. They purchased 180 kilos of ganja from Ramu and Murthy. Another accused Ram Reddy packed the contraband into two kilo packets and loaded in one car.

While Sivaneswaran and Ajith were travelling with the contraband, Satish, Kalyan and Surendran were piloting their vehicle in another car . After the accident, Sivaneswaran called Satish and informed him about the mishap. “Satish picked up Sivaneswaran and they fled from the scene abandoning Ajith and ganja,” the SP said. A special team formed by the SP arrested Satish, Kalyan and Surendran at Moosa Dhabha in Bhootpur on Thursday. Ajith is said to be out of danger.

Title: 837 school buses in Kolkata ply without fitness certificates
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Thousands of students in the city are being ferried to and from schools precariously. A recent scrutiny by the transport department following the instruction of the transport minister Suvendu Adhikari has revealed that 837 buses of 153 schools in Kolkata, Salt Lake and New Town have no certificate of fitness (CF). All these buses will have to go off the roads, if they don’t undergo fitness tests within January 31.The unfit buses will be confiscated, according to a transport department official. “I will not allow unsafe ferrying of students,” Adhikari told TOI. A CF clearance is mandatory for all commercial vehicles. The transport department checks about 20 things, including road worthiness of tyres and brakes, before issuing the clearance.The scrutiny began after Adhikari had caught a school bus driver talking over phone near Fort William. The transport department officials summoned the driver and cancelled his licence. During the probe, the officials found a large number of school buses are plying illegally across the city and vulnerable to accidents any time.“We could have taken action immediately. But our minister cautioned us against causing any disruption for transportation of students. We have issued notice to the school bus owners, asking them to comply with the norms. If they don’t follow our instruction, we will take actions,” said an official.With a number of school buses not undergoing the CF tests, they have been prone to accidents. As per the Motor Vehicles Act, a vehicle must have a fitness certificate issued by the manufacturer while it also needs another fitness certificate from the state RTO authorities.However, the school buses not only ply without CF, but also have defaulted road tax. The government will earn Rs7.5 crore to regularise these vehicles. “We have already formed a team to crack down on the vehicles not complying with the CF regulations.

Title: IIT mgmt school restricts placement to one offer only
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Kolkata: Students at Vinod Gupta School of Management (VGSoM), the first management institute in an IIT system, were restricted from opting for multiple offers during the final placement this year. Instead, the school said the students would have to follow the IIT placement rule of opting for a single offer. Despite the change in rule, the institute saw 100% success in recruitment .

Most of the class selected consulting as their preferred domain, with 26% of them going for it. Among the other key domains were operations (19%), sales (17%), marketing analytics (15%) and finance (12%). It has become one of the first management schools to conclude its final placements for 2019-20 academic year. Top 25% of the students have secured an average compensation of Rs 23.2 lakh a year and top 50% Rs 20.8 lakh per year. The highest offer rose up to Rs 29 lakh. Last year, the average compensation of the top 25% was Rs 18.5 lakh and that for the top 50% was Rs 17.21 lakh.

“Among the top recruiters were ITC, Accenture Digital, Amazon, PwC, Deloitte, Blackbuck, ZS Associates, Titan, Kotak Mahindra Bank, Oxane Partners, Vedanta, ICICI Bank, Axtria, Tiger Analytics, Wipro, IBM, IDFC First and Tata Power. including McKinsey, Crompton, EPIKInDiFi, Facebook, Cogoport, Media.net, Loadshare and Mahindra & Mahindra participated for the first time,” said dean Prabina Rajib.

Rajib, added, “VGSOM defied the current economic slowdown due to the school’s unique pedagogy and calibre of students,”

Title: Centre gives nod for common facility to help powerloom units
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Tirupur: The Centre on Wednesday gave the final approval to establish a common facility centre (CFC) to support powerloom units in Palladam and Somanur areas.

Powerloom unit owners said the facility would help them to produce value added weaving products rather than depend on master weavers every time. They found Palladam Powerloom Weavers Cluster Private Limited, a special purpose vehicle, to run the CFC.

The approval was granted at the 52nd steering committee meeting of the micro small enterprises-cluster development programme (MSE-CDP) conducted by the ministry of MSME in New Delhi on Wednesday.

The Rs 17.62-crore centre would come up at Kethanur, where the powerloom owners association had purchased four acres for the purpose. While the Centre would fund 67% of the cost, the state government and the powerloom units would bear 10% and 23% of the cost respectively.

More than two lakh powerloom units are functioning in Palladam and Somanur areas in Tirupur and Coimbatore districts. They undertake job works from master weavers.

“The powerloom units produce fabric from warp and weft supplied from master weavers. Around 10% of master weavers are from Erode, and the rest are from cities like Ahmedabad, Surat, Jaipur and Kolkata,” said M Balasubramaniam, secretary of the Tirupur-Coimbatore districts’ powerloom owners association.

“As each powerloom unit could not separately set up facilities for sizing, bleaching, printing and stitching, they could not add value to the produced fabrics. But with the CFC, they would have such facilities and it would help them develop their own weaving products, both apparel and home textiles, and market them,” said Balasubramaniam, who was also managing director of Palladam Powerloom Weavers Cluster.

“We have planned to take at least 100 powerloom units on board, and so far, 54 have joined in the cluster. Nowadays, powerloom units are struggling to get regular orders and job works rates are also insufficient. With the CFC, the powerloom units would get wings to fly on their own,” he added.

Title: PAC pushes for extension of platform at railways station
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

PAC members, led by chairman PK Krishnadas interacted with the passengers at Nashik Road railway station

NASHIK: The Passenger Amenities Committee ( PAC ) of the Indian Railways visited the Nashik Road railway station on Thursday and stressed on increasing the length of platform number 1 to accommodate longer trains.

Headed by chairman PK Krishnadas and members Rajendra Ashok Phadke, G. Premendar Reddy, Himadri Bal, Kaku Vijayalakshmi and C. Ravindran, the PAC held a dialogue with passengers and officials and tried to understand the issues they face, the services they want from Railways in general and from Nashik Road railway station in particular.

The PAC arrived at Nashik from Pune. According to Phadke, the PAC conducted an inspection of the station and the facilities offered by the railway administration. Later, they interacted with the passengers, sought their feedback and noted down their requests and grievances.

“The major demand of the passengers was accommodating the longer trains running long distances on home platform – PF 1 so that the passengers alighting the train can easily walk out of the station without having to take the staircase,” Phadke said.

At present, all the major trains coming from Mumbai arrive at PF 2 and those heading towards Mumbai arrive at PF 3. There are four platforms at the Nashik Road railway station.

“In either direction, passengers have to access the foot overbridge (FoB). This is a strenuous thing for women, patients and senior citizens and, hence, we have stressed for increasing the length of PF1,” he noted.

The committee has also demanded an escalator at platform 4 though the work for escalator on PF 2/3 is going on. “There is a ramp and there is staircase of PF 4. The elevator is being constructed. But the PF 4 can also be converted into home platform as the parking space outside has a direct access to the platform. If the escalator is constructed here and trains going to Mumbai are diverted to this platform it would be a major relief for the commuters,” he said.

The PAC also has suggested that the FOB connecting all four platforms should be constructed on Bhusawal-end of the station, facilitating the smooth movement of the passengers.

Title: Bengaluru: GoAir flight cancellations to continue this quarter
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Cancellations on flights operated by GoAir will continue, and even increase, in the first quarter of 2020, the airline said on Thursday. Over the past few weeks, GoAir flights across routes have been cancelled due to staff crunch.

The airline had grounded several flights on the directions of Directorate General of Civil Aviation to replace the snag-prone Pratt & Whitney engines on its 13 A320 Neo fleet. Now, it has said pending delivery of aircraft will cause more cancellations and suspensions.

Several GoAir flights departing from or landing in Bengaluru have been cancelled over the past few weeks, while many scheduled for operations over the coming week have been cancelled in advance.

The cancelled flights include GoAir flight G8 403 from Bengaluru to Indore, G8 815/122 from Bengaluru to Kolkata via Hyderabad, G8 518 from Bengaluru to Hyderabad, G8 404 from Bengaluru to Kochi and G8 404 from Varanasi to Bengaluru.

“The change is due to issues beyond our control,” reads the cancellation message sent by the airline to several passengers, many of whom have been forced to spend more on last-minute bookings.

“In four weeks, we have gone through unplanned grounding of aircraft which were supporting our current fleet operations. And now, we have been informed by our business partners Airbus and Pratt & Whitney of their inability to deliver previously promised aircraft and engines by March 2020,” reads the statement issued by GoAir on Thursday.

“We have been forced to temporarily suspend certain flights that are part of our network...We have undertaken these suspensions as far ahead of time as possible in order to minimise inconvenience to customers...We expect — with the support of Airbus and Pratt & Whitney — to reinstate these flights and operate them at the earliest,” it adds.

Title: Land grabbing: Officers may face suspension for inaction
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Many government properties including raja kaluve, lanes, tanks and waterbodies have been encroached in the sta... Read More

MYSURU: Officials dragging their feet in taking action against land grabbers are likely to face suspension. This is the latest warning the department of revenue has issued as an initiative to safeguard all its properties from being encroached.

Until now officials didn’t have any accountability with regard to delay in reclaiming the encroached government properties. The Public Accounts Committee has taken a serious note of the report of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India that has found considerable delay in reclaiming the encroached properties. Due to poor action by officers, properties worth crores of rupees belonging to government are lost. Even the wrongdoers are going scot-free.

The revenue department has dashed off a missive to the deputy commissioners of Karnataka, a copy of which is with TOI, asking the district heads to take necessary action in this connection. Deputy commissioner Abhiram G Sankar said that principal secretary of the revenue department has issued directions to look into all land encroachments by regularly reviewing the progress.

Hundreds of government properties including raja kaluve, lanes, tanks and water bodies, grazing land and gundu thopu (forested areas) have been encroached in Mysuru and in rest of Karnataka, said RTI activist BN Nagendra. Though officers are in the know, they are lackadaisical in taking action. Land grabbers are taking advantage of it to grab lands by creating fake documents. Nagendra said he has facilitated revenue and Mysuru Urban Development Authorities to identify a minimum of 50 such properties.

Principal secretary of the revenue department N Manjunath Prasad has directed deputy commissioners to take stern action against officers in case they don’t act on complaints and take necessary steps to protect government lands. The DCs have been asked to review the state of affairs in two weeks and initiate action against land grabbers. Time-bound action is a must on the part of officials and if any officers are found dragging their feet, action must be taken against them. Grabbing land using fake documents must be treated seriously. If there is suspicion on any officers helping any grabbers they should be immediately placed under suspension and inquiry must be initiated. Cases pending in court must be expedited. All government lands must be preserved by putting up a fence and a board. Most importantly, deputy commissioners must review such cases once a month, states the letter.

Title: Central govt a mute spectator to Bedi’s anarchic behaviour: CM
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Puducherry: The Union government remains a mute spectator to lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi ’s autocratic and anarchic behaviour, charged chief minister V Narayanasamy on Thursday.

Speaking at the birth anniversary celebrations of freedom fighter Netaji Subash Chandra Bose, Narayanasamy questioned whether Puducherry needs an ‘anarchic’ lieutenant governor with ‘anti-labour and anti-people policies’.

He questioned Bedi’s decision to order the closure of the government-run Anglo-French Textiles (AFT) when the council of ministers decided to extend voluntary retirement scheme to the 600-odd workers in the mill before taking a call on the closure.

“Who gave her the authority to order the closure of AFT when the general public, workers, elected members and the council of ministers decided to offer VRS to the workers? Do we need such an anarchic, anti-labour and anti-people lieutenant governor in Puducherry? We have been raising this question regularly and urging the Centre to recall her, but the Centre remains a mute spectator,” said Narayanasamy.

He pointed out that the decision on closing the mill was referred to the Centre and the President in April last year following a difference in opinion between the council of ministers and Kiran Bedi.

“In the meantime, she took the powers of the Centre and the President and forced the officials to issue orders for the closure of the mill. The status quo must be maintained until the President or the Centre takes a final call on its closure. The lieutenant governor has been posing obstacles to the government. We demand that the Centre recall her immediately,” he said.

Narayanasamy vowed that the government will not permit closure of the mill at any point of time. “The government is keen in running at least unit three in the mill,” he said.

The CM said offering VRS to the workers was one of the 38 demands of the government when all the ministers and elected members of the Congress and its ally DMK and leaders of its allies staged a sit-in protest under his leadership in front of Raj Nivas last year.

“We reached an agreement to form a committee to study the VRS option and when we sent the file seeking approval for constituting the committee later, the lieutenant governor retracted and decided to close the mill,” Narayanasamy charged.

He said Puducherry BJP president V Saminathan, who called on him along with representatives of trade unions, also endorsed the government’s decision to offer VRS to the workers and rejected Bedi’s move to close the unit.

Title: High-altitude sports centre to be ready by February 20: Official
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Udhagamandalam: With a new deadline, a contract agreement with a private player has been renewed to set up a high-altitude sports training centre with synthetic track at the HADP open ground in the town.

Though the work was started in October 2016, the project has not been completed till now. As per the earlier agreement, Syncotts International, the private player, was supposed to complete the work by October 2017.

Nilgiris district sports officer S Jayachandran said a re-contract agreement with the contractor was established recently specifying the deadline for completion of the work by February 20.

In 2016, Rs 7.05 crore was sanctioned for converting the cinder track into synthetic. While a sum of Rs 5.05 crore was sanctioned by the ministry of youth affairs and sports, the rest Rs 2 crore was funded by the Hill Area Development Programme (HADP).

Jayachandran said, “As the contract with Syncotts lapsed, it was renewed with the condition that the synthetic track would be completed by February 20, 2020.” Work on football ground and synthetic track is almost over. Only erection of four floodlights is pending. “Soil test report has been obtained for erecting four floodlights,” he added.

The ground is going to be athletic cum football ground, while the football ground will be maintained as natural with grass. The synthetic athletic track will have six tacks with 400 meters distance as per international standard. The training centre will have facilities such as heat therapy and hydrotherapy for the trainees.

The HADP ground houses a sports hostel with a capacity of 60 beds. “As of now, 58 sports persons from various districts in Tamil Nadu are taking training. At present, the training is being held at the Ooty government arts college ground,” Jayachandran said.

Title: Kolkata: Kalighat Bridge height barrier damaged
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The damaged height bar near Gopalnagar on Thursday evening

KOLKATA: Traffic came to a halt on Kalighat Bridge around 7.30pm on Thursday when a bus hit the newly constructed height barrier. The KMDA officials put up height barriers on both sides of the bride in the early hours of Thursday. The 45-year-old bridge connects Alipore with Kalighat over Tolly’s Nullah.

The KMDA engineers, who were alerted by the traffic control room about the incident, rushed to the spot and took stock of the damage.

Though it was a holiday, there was vehicular pressure on SP Mukherjee Road, Chetla Bridge and Durgapur Bridge due to the closure of the Kalighat Bridge.

Earlier, the bridge came under scanner for its poor health. The police and engineers, who were part of the height barrier installation, said that vehicles had to be diverted through other roads from 10pm on Wednesday to 5am on Thursday for the work.

Title: Bengaluru: Woman insists on safe sex, man kills her
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Subramanyapura police arrested on Thursday arrested Mukunda HH for allegedly murdering a woman at her residenc... Read More

BENGALURU: A 42-year-old sex worker recently found dead at her west Bengaluru residence was allegedly murdered by a customer who refused to heed her condition for safe sex. The woman had declined to return his money. Police said the customer, Mukunda HH, 48, a security guard in a private firm and resident of Veerasandra near Electronics City, was arrested on Wednesday and has confessed to the crime.

The woman, who was separated from her husband and lived with her minor son in Gayathrinagar near Rajajinagar, met Mukunda in Majestic around 1pm on January 11, when he was about to catch a bus to reach his village in KR Pet taluk, Mandya district. She demanded Rs 2,500 for a sexual favour and finally settled for Rs 1,500. She took Rs 500 as advance and they took a bus to Rajajinagar and an auto to reach her residence.

“Mukunda said he gave the woman an advance of Rs 500 in Majestic and paid another Rs 1,000 on reaching her house. She asked him to wear a condom for safe sex. But he declined and asked her to return his money. She refused and threatened to raise an alarm if he demanded the cash or tried to have sex with her without a condom,” police quoted Mukuknda as saying.

“He allegedly took out a knife from his bag and threatened to stab her if she didn’t return the money. In the heat of the moment, he stabbed her in the stomach and she began screaming for help. He then decided to eliminate her and slit her throat before fleeing the spot with her fake gold chain and two mobiles,” a police officer said.

The incident came to light around 3.45pm when the woman’s son returned home from school. Subramanyanagar police registered a case of murder. N Shashikumar, deputy commissioner of police (north), formed a team headed by inspector M Sadananda, which investigated the case from several angles, including monetary dispute, extra-marital affair and the woman’s troubled marriage, but made no headway initially.

“We spotted the killer with the woman in an auto after analysing footage from over 150 CCTV cameras. We also found her mobile was operational in Majestic a few hours before her death. We deployed plainclothesmen in Majestic, who traced Mukunda when he came to catch a bus to his village,” an officer said. Police produced him before a court and took him into custody.

Title: 8 yrs after getting son baptised, Gujarat Hindu mom faces FIR
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

AHMEDABAD: A single Hindu mother who had her son baptised at a local church in Anand almost eight years ago was on Wednesday booked under the Gujarat Freedom of Religion Act for converting her child without the district collector's permission.

The police ostensibly acted on a petition filed with the Anand collectorate in 2013 by one Dharmendra Rathod, who runs an organisation called Forum for Peace and Justice. Rathod had challenged the then eight-year-old child's baptism on grounds of his mother not taking her estranged husband’s consent or applying for the district magistrate’s clearance before going ahead with the conversion.

"The inquiry had been pending for about six years. Anand district collector RG Gohil concluded it on January 3, 2020, and ordered the police to register an FIR in the case," Rathod said.

Collector Gohil told TOI that a Hindu parent getting her child baptised without official sanction was "a gross violation of the Gujarat Freedom of Religion Act". The purpose of the Act, promulgated in 2003, is to prohibit conversion from one religion to another "by force, allurement or fraudulent means".

According to rights activist Manjula Pradeep, the 42-year-old woman facing prosecution had visited a church on April 8, 2012, on her own and requested the Catholic priest there to arrange a baptism ceremony for her son. "No child can choose his or her religion — he or she adopts the parents’ religion, like in this case. The child can convert on becoming an adult; so there is no ground for filing an FIR against the mother just because she got her child baptised," she said.

Petitioner Rathod claimed that since the child's father and mother were both Hindus, his conversion to Christianity was subject to both parents' consent and subsequent permission from the district magistrate. "The child’s parents married in 2001 and divorced in 2008. After learning of his son's conversion, the father — a Hindu OBC from Uttar Pradesh — challenged it in a letter to the Union home ministry in 2013. The ministry directed the then chief secretary to look into the case, but no action was taken," he said.

The FIR against the mother has been registered under Sections 3 and 4 of the Act. Section 4 prescribes imprisonment for up to three years and a maximum fine of Rs 50,000 for any violation of the law.

Title: 1,500 trees in Karmal Ghat may make way for highway widening
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The state government is likely to get forest clearance to cut over 1,500 tress to widen the national highway at Karmal Ghat at Canacona by March. The government will also take a final decision on the construction of the Porvorim six-lane stilt bridge by month-end.

PWD minister Deepak Prabhu Pauskar told TOI, “We will get forest clearance to cut over 1,500 trees at Karmal Ghat within two months for the expansion of the national highway.”

He added that the department has made a proposal to the forest department to plant three times the number of trees felled for the expansion at other locations. “Chief minister Pramod Sawant is also the forest minister and he is trying to get the forest clearance for the highway expansion,” he said.

“We will try to clear all hurdles blocking the expansion work,” he said.

On the six-lane stilt bridge from Pundalik Nagar to Socorro junction, Pauskar said the final decision will be made by the end of this month.

The PWD minister said that that the CM will hold a meeting with the contractor, Porvorim residents and others.

Some residents of Porvorim have gone to court over the bridge but have now agreed to withdraw the petition, he said. Others have asked Sawant to reduce the six-lane stilt from Pundalik Nagar to Socorro junction to a four-lane corridor on NH 66. “A decision will be taken at the end of this month and work will start from February,” he said.

He also said that residents of Porvorim want the height of the bridge between 6 to 6.5m, but we have decided to go with 6m.

Pauskar said that people must compromise for the development of the state as it is being done for their benefit. “We want roads to get better, we want tourism to increase. It is said that for the growth of any country, roads should be in good condition,” he said.

Title: Assembly gives final nod to English medium education in govt schools
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Amaravati: Continuing to push for English medium in government schools, the Andhra Pradesh Education Act 1/1982 (Amendment) Bill, 2019, was tabled in the assembly on Thursday again. The bill, which was introduced in the winter session in December, 2019, was passed by the assembly and sent to the council, which sent it back with amendments. The bill was passed in the assembly on Thursday.

Speaking on the bill in the assembly, chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy lashed out at the TDP for stalling such historical bills in the council.

“I do not understand as to why the opposition members are so against poor children getting better education and food,” the chief minister fumed. He said they were trying to create a hurdle for the bill despite knowing that they cannot prevent it from being passed. He asserted that the government was committed to transform right to education into right to english-medium education and is ready to walk the mile for its implementation.

As part of the initiative, the government is set to provide education kit to about 36.10 lakh children studying in government schools on June 1. The kit comprises text and note books, fabric for three-pairs of uniforms, shoes, socks, belt, school bag and tailoring charges. The kit would be handed over to the children at least a fortnight ahead of the reopening of the schools. Each kit costs Rs 1,355 and will cost the government an additional Rs 487 crore.

Jaganmohan Reddy stated that for decades several lakhs of children, particularly from SC, ST, BC and minority communities, have been waiting for English medium to be introduced in government schools as their parents could not afford private schools. English as medium of teaching is used in about 98.5% private schools while in only 35% of government-managed schools English is the medium of teaching; while 23.67% of the government schools are teaching in English at the primary level, he said.

“Children can learn fast and upgrade their skills if they are taught in English medium right from the primary level. Our intension is to provide better and quality education to the children from under-privileged sections,” said the chief minister.

Title: Sulur cop under the lens for amassing wealth
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The registrar of Tamil Nadu Lokayukta has forwarded a petition to the vigilance commission seeking to conduct a preliminary inquiry against the Sulur police inspector for owning assets disproportionate to his known source of income.

The petition was sent by M Kandasamy, 52, who owns a power loom unit at Kalivelampatti near Palladam in Tirupur district, a few weeks ago.

The petition was sent to the chairperson of Tamil Nadu Lokayukta, Chennai, detailing the allegations against Sulur police inspector R Thangaraj.

In his complaint, Kandasamy alleged that Thangaraj had bought eight cents of land worth Rs 25 lakh at Irugur near the city on March 2017.

After obtaining permission from the Irugur town panchayat, Thangaraj had constructed a house on the land in a build-up area of 4,000 sq ft at a cost of Rs 2 crore, the petition said. But Thangaraj did not inform the government about his new house.

In 2019, Thangaraj bought a site worth Rs 25 lakh at Kollupalayam near Kaniyur, Kandasamy said.

The petitioner also attached documents showing that the land at Irugur was registered in the name of inspector’s wife at Singanallur sub-registrar office. He has also attached the building plan approval issued for the new house.

A copy of the land document registered at Sulur sub-registrar office for land at Kollupalayam was also attached. He has also attached an RTI reply given by the office of the superintendent of police, Tirupur, for not getting any prior permission to buy lands in 2017 at Irugur.

“Thangaraj had involved in purchasing assets worth Rs 4 crore in the last three years. So, I had sent the complaint to the Tamil Nadu Lokayukta to take stringent action him,” said Kandasamy.

When contacted, Thangaraj was not available for comments.

Following the complaint, S Pandian, registrar /district judge (retired), Tamil Nadu Lokayukta, Chepauk, Chennai, had sent a replay to Kandasamy informing that his complaint has been registered as Lokayukta C No 1/2020 and the same has been forwarded to the vigilance commission, secretariat, Fort St George, Chennai, for conducting preliminary inquiry under section 19 (1) of the Tamil Nadu Lokayukta Act, 2018.

“After the Tamil Nadu Lokayukta chairperson and members instructed the vigilance to conduct preliminary inquiry, I am getting threat calls from police officials,” Kandasamy said.

Title: Raise percentage of crop loan from banks, farmers urge finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Nirmala Sitharaman

TRICHY: A group of farmers from the delta districts met Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman in Chennai and submitted a charter of demands to be addressed in the Union Budget, including enhancing the percentage of crop loan given by nationalized banks.

The farmers said the Union government had directed all nationalized banks to hike interest rates on agriculture jewel loan to 9.90% from 7% at a time when they are struggling to earn through farming. The government also stopped prompt payment of loan incentive to farmers. The Centre should at least enhance the percentage of loan given to farmers for agriculture and allied agriculture activities to 30% from the existing 18%, the memorandum said.

Another long-pending demand of the farming community is the implementation of the M S Swaminathan committee recommendations to fix reasonable price for their produce, which is 50% over and above the actual cost of production.

The ever-increasing input and labour costs are forcing farmers to ponder whether they should continue cultivation. In such a scenario, they are not allowed to fix a reasonable price for the produce on their own. So, till farmers get a reasonable price for their produce as per the recommendations, entire crop loan taken by farmers from nationalized banks should be waived off, the memorandum added.

The farmers also said that agricultural scientist Subhash Palekar’s zero budget natural farming should be made as a farmers’ movement. His concept should be taken to each and every farmer across the country. For that, the government should undertake his mission and the same should be included and announced in the forthcoming budget.

A delegation of farmers including secretary of Thanjavur District Cauvery Farmers Protection Association, Swamimalai S Vimalnathan, Thanjavur met the finance minister.

Title: Goa government has no data on budget allocation: House panel
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

PORVORIM: The state assembly’s budget committee met on Thursday to review budgetary allocation and utilisation of funds earmarked in the 2019-20 state budget only to find that the information was not available, said committee chairman Vijai Sardesai.

Sardesai, who is the Goa Forward Party president and former deputy chief minister, said that officials from the finance department who attended the meeting were ill-prepared. Sardesai has asked the government to collate the data and present it at the next budget committee meeting on February 5.

“We have come to know that a meeting of the budget committee never has been held. The government officers who came said that they are tied up with the15th finance commission and therefore don’t have the information,” he said.

There are seven MLAs on the budget committee; Joshua D’Souza, Alexio Reginaldo Lourenco, Francis Silveira, Pravin Zantye, Atanasio Monserrate and Clafasio Dias.

Interestingly, BJP MLA for Mapusa Joshua D’Souza agreed and said that he was surprised over the lack of preparation. “This is the first time the committee has met and the review is taking place. I was quite surprised at this,” D’Souza said.

The committee grilled the government officers on the budgetary allocation made to all departments, utilisation of the allocated funds, re-appropriation of sanctioned funds and whether the government was taking loans to pay salaries.

When reporters asked Sardesai if he received answers, the Fatorda MLA said, “The finance department’s officer came completely unprepared.”

“Is there any sanction that is pending which has already been approved in the budget because finance sends files back saying there are no funds. If funds were earmarked for a particular purpose then where is the question of rejecting it saying there are no funds?” said Sardesai.

BJP MLA Joshua D’Souza said that at least two major projects, the bus terminus and the bridge over river Tar in Mapusa are stuck for want of financial approval. Sardesai said that several projects in his constituency have also been stalled due to lack of funds.

“We have asked for the expenditure details on social schemes such as Laadli Laxmi and whether there is any pendency in these schemes and if there is a deficit. We have asked for details of all the big-ticket projects in North and South Goa to see if contractors are being paid on time. These are questions that are put to the government,” said Sardesai.

D’Souza agreed with Sardesai’s concerns. “He raised some valid points. Ultimately it is for the people. The secretaries and officials have to give a response to his queries,” said the Mapusa MLA.

Title: Goa: Over 64,000 helmetless riders booked from October to December
Content:
Road accident data compiled by the state for the last quarter of 2019 revealed that a total of 48 people have ... Read More

PANAJI: Helmetless two-wheeler riders qualified as some of the highest traffic violations in the last quarter of 2019. Figures shared by the state transport department revealed that there were 64,616 violations detected from October to December, last year.This is a nearly 30% decrease from the number of violations in the same quarter last year. In the same period in 2018, there were a total of 84,787 violations recorded by the transport department for helmetless riding.However, compared to 2017, there is a 21% increase in violations (see infographic) owing to the fact that there were far lesser helmetless riders caught breaking the rules, that year.Road accident data compiled by the state for the last quarter of 2019 revealed that a total of 48 people have lost their lives in fatal accidents in October and November. Of these, 35 people that were killed were two-wheeler riders and three people were helmetless pillion riders. The statistics for December are yet to be compiled by the state transport department.“The overall licensing process of two-wheelers must be made stricter compared to four-wheeler licenses. The driving licenses of those caught riding helmetless should be suspended, and a strict penalty must be imposed to deter motorists from violating traffic rules,” said road safety activist Dilip Naik.He said that the negligence of two-wheeler riders lead to road fatalities— costing not just the riders’ lives, but “also risks the lives of the pillion rider.”

Title: City businessman braves -35°C, heavy snow to create a record
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Coimbatore: A city businessman, along with his team, has succeeded in creating a record by driving an electric vehicle to an altitude of 5,731m at Sawula Pass in the Himalayan range in western Tibet. He has broken the previous record of 5,715.28m created by a Chinese man in 2018.

N Suresh Kumar, 40, who also conducts expeditions to the Himalayas, was roped-in to perform the feat for an automobile company through his friend.

Suresh said the feat was achieved after an effort of eight days and amid harsh weather conditions of around -35°C, heavy snow and an unfriendly terrain.

“We started on January 1 from Kathmandu in Nepal. That afternoon, the notary of the Guinness Records sealed our altimeter so that we don’t tamper with it,” he said. This proved to be a challenge as they had to carry 22 power banks to power the altimeter in the cold, as they cannot open the seal to change it to battery mode.

The next seven days formed the core of the feat, said Suresh. On the fourth day, his team, which consisted of a Nepali and three Tibetans along with him, was sent back by Tibetan police at Keyrong, a valley, as there was a heavy snow fall and five to six feet of snow had covered the ground. Only on the next day afternoon, they were permitted to pass.

On January 7, they first attempted the record from a place called Saga to Sawula Pass in the Himalayan Range in Tibet. “We reached 5,682m, around 100m before the target, but turned back due to heavy snow fall. If I had travelled another 100m, we would have reached our target on January 7,” he said.

“On the route back, we stayed at a village, and requested the village head to employ a JCB vehicle to clear the snow. But as the snow was being cleared, wind brought it back to the track,” he said.

On January 8, they reached the summit at an altitude of 5,731m at Sawula Pass in their Hyundai Kona Electric Car by 3.15pm (Beijing time).

Title: 5 under scanner for novel coronavirus infection, 2 from Mumbai quarantined
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Mumbai/Pune: Five persons — two from Pune and three from Mumbai — have been put under surveillance in the past 48 hours after they landed at Mumbai airport from China to ensure that they have not been infected with the novel coronavirus.

Two of the three Mumbai residents, exhibiting mild cough and cold symptoms, were admitted to Kasturba Hospital in Chinchpokli late on Thursday as a precautionary measure, said an official.

The three Mumbai residents are of Jogeshwari, Kalyan and Nalasopara. “Since the passengers from Kalyan and Nalasopara have shown signs of mild cold and cough, we have asked them to come and get admitted to Kasturba Hospital so that we can run some checks and rule out any infection,” said BMC executive health officer Dr Padmaja Keskar.

State epidemiologist Dr Pradeep Awate said they had exhibited no specific coronavirus symptoms. Two of the five passengers had been to Wuhan, the epicentre of the novel coronavirus outbreak. “Those two passengers are also currently asymptomatic like the other three, who had been to other parts of China,” said Awate.

Sources said the Nalasopara traveller had stayed in Foshan city — almost 1,000km south from Wuhan — for six days. The person left China on January 21 and arrived at Mumbai airport at 4am on Wednesday. The local health officer said the woman complained of body ache and cold when the health department officials contacted her. “We referred her to Kasturba for the physician’s opinion,” said the official.

The Kalyan resident was in Guangzhou, also almost 1,000km south of Wuhan, for six days from January 16. “He had cold and cough. A complete blood count test showed normal results,” said an official.

The state health department officials have decided to follow up with the five passengers for 28 days.

A total of 1,323 passengers returning from China and other affected countries have so far been screened at the Mumbai airport since January 18.

Title: Pune: Yerawada Bridge caught between immediate repairs & heavy traffic
Content: The traffic divisions have also expressed concern over what the civic body would do about the potable water... Read More PUNE: The Yerawada Bridge that connects Koregaon Park area to Ahmednagar Road needs urgent repairs. But, the Pune Municipal Corporation and the traffic branch of the Pune police have been unable to reach a consensus over closing of the bridge for maintenance and improvement works and re-routing of traffic.A structural audit of the 40-year-old bridge, popularly known as Bund Garden Bridge, conducted by Dhole-Patil Road based Subduction Zone Consultants has listed 15 major and minor works that need to be undertaken for safety.The civic authority first sought permission to close the bridge for traffic for one month late last year. However, the traffic department refused permission citing metro work in the surrounding areas and a heavy flow of traffic.Both entities are locked in a debate with no consensus on road closure and diversions to make way for the maintenance works.The Yerawada and Koregaon Park traffic divisions are reluctant to stop vehicular movement on the bridge and impose any diversions. The divisions have put the onus of a decision in the matter on the deputy commissioner of police (traffic) office.Officials from both traffic divisions opined that closing the bridge for traffic and imposing diversions would lead to chaos.“We estimate traffic jams up to 3km on either side of the bridge along Ahmednagar Road if diversions are not made. We have experimented routing the traffic to the Airport Road through Shastrinagar junction and even closing one flank of the Yerawada bridge, but both have led to chaos,” officials from the Yerawada traffic division said.On the proposal to turn the one-way on Babasaheb Ambedkar bridge into a two-way for the duration of the maintenance works, officials from both divisions said all the adjoining areas including Bund Garden Road (up to the RTO junction), Koregaon Park Road (up to Rajendra Sinhji Institute), Kalyaninagar, Deccan College Road and Ahmednagar Road would be badly affected.The traffic divisions have also expressed concern over what the civic body would do about the potable water pipeline running under the median of the Yerawada bridge. They also had reservations about the possible delays in completion of the maintenance.“We have written to the PMC about works that need to be undertaken before the bridge’s maintenance. If we have to close each flank of the bridge for 15 days, some works need to be undertaken to ensure smooth flow of traffic and safety of motorists. This includes removal of traffic islands, removal of encroachments, installation of railings on footpaths and installation of sign boards. Managing traffic may be possible only after these are completed,” Yerawada division officials said.Deputy mayor Siddharth Dhende said, “The bridge is dangerous and repairs are needed. The joints along the bridge have to be replaced as it could lead to a disaster if left unattended. Other works include resurfacing, repairs to railings and footpaths. The water pipeline will be left untouched during the work.”According to Dhende, a meeting with officials from the traffic department has been scheduled for Friday. A senior police officer said they would discuss the matter with top civic officials and a solution would be arrived at.

Title: Industry seeks funds from finance panel to improve infrastructure for private sector
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Limited availability of land for revenue generation projects and a protracted stress on the state’s resources due to migrants impinge on Goa’s fragile economy, representatives of Goa’s industrial sector stated in their recommendations to the 15th Finance Commission.Goa Chamber of Commerce and Industry (GCCI) has requested the 15th Finance Commission for Rs 2,500 crore to address industry requirements along with special grants to help Goa meet specific project requirements.GCCI president Manoj Caculo and immediate past president Sandip Bhandare met 15th Finance Commission chairman N K Singh, and submitted a representation seeking project specific grants from the central pool.“Migrant population is putting tremendous pressure on all the state infrastructure — healthcare, housing and sanitation, public transport, education, etc, besides creating a huge law and order nuisance in the state. The resultant degradation of the local infrastructure needs to be adequately compensated through higher allocations of central funds,” Caculo said.Representatives from CREDAI-Goa, Economic Development Corporation Ltd, Goa Industrial Development Corporation, GCCI, Chartered Accountants’ Association of Goa, Confederation of India Industry (CII), Goa Barge Owners’ Association (GBOA) and Goa Mineral Ore Exporters’ Association (GMOEA) met the finance commission.GMOEA has pointed out that ban on mining has adversely impacted lakhs of people and almost all sectors of the economy. The mining ban has also caused a huge loss in terms of tax and non-tax revenue to the state. GCCI, GBOA and GMOEA have requested the 15th Finance Commission to compensate Goa for the revenue loss due to closure of mining.“As a result of inadequate funds at its disposal, the state has been unable to allocate funds for development of industrial infrastructure. The state needs additional funds for various reasons enumerated above and hence we request the finance commission to recommend special grants to meet specific requirements,” Bhandare said.CII - Goa said that the commission asked for inputs from industry stakeholders on Goa’s economy and industrial sector. “The commission wanted to know how to get growth in Goa and what the industries are looking for. If Goa has to look for sustainable growth, with its limited resources, we need to look at industries which are not resource hungry and at the same time drive up employment,” chairman of CII-Goa Lalit Saraswat said.CII has suggested that Goa needs to improve its public transport system for which funds should be allocated.

Title: Crook steals contactless cards, spends nearly Rs 42,000 in Pune
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A pickpocket stole a 43-year-old bank employee’s contactless debit and credit cards on Tuesday and went on a shopping spree.

The crook was savvy enough to know that contactless card transactions under Rs 2,000 don’t require a personal identification number (PIN), and spent Rs 41,551 at various places before the man got the cards blocked.

According to the complaint, the bank employee was travelling in a Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) bus, when the pickpocket pinched his wallet containing all the cards. Within five hours, the complaint stated, the suspect used the cards at different food outlets and clothing stores.

The complainant, a resident of Shevalewadi, has lodged a first information report (FIR) with the Bund Garden police.

Rupesh Pisal of the Bund Garden police, who is investigating the complaint, said the incident occurred when the complainant was commuting between Pune railway station and Pimpri at 8am.

At 8.23am, the complainant received an SMS alert that Rs2,000 was spent on his debit card at a food joint. Some time later, the card was used at a dairy outlet near the station. When he started getting a stream of messages, the complainant realized his cards were stolen. “By the time he got around to blocking the cards, the suspect had already spent Rs41,551,” Pisal said.

Around Rs14,000 was spent using the complainant’s debit card, while the rest was spent using his credit card. “We have yet to get details of the credit card transactions,” Pisal said.

‘Contactless payment’ is a new technology that allows a card holder to simply tap the card on the point of sale machine to pay. Contactless cards sport a little ‘Wi-Fi’ symbol on them. They are embedded with chips that make use of the ‘Near Field Communication’ technology. One PoS machine can only read one card at a time, and the card needs to be within 4cm of the machine.

Title: 2 YSRC mins could lose job in cabinet
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Amaravati: Deputy chief minister Pilli Subhash Chandrabose and marketing minister Mopidevi Venkata Ramana will be out of the cabinet once the legislative council is abolished. CM Jaganmohan Reddy had inducted them into the cabinet from the council. While the term of Subhash Chandra Bose is coming to an end in 2021 March, Venkata Ramana has term till 2023.

Although, there is no immediate threat to their job in the cabinet, once the Parliament clears the bill they have to quit the posts within six months after President gives assent. Curiously, Subhash Chandrabose himself requested the CM on Thursday to abolish the council on Thursday.

Meanwhile, TDP national general secretary Nara Lokesh who is an MLC has term till 2023. Former minister Yanamala Ramakrishnudu, who played key role in TDP gaining upper-hand in the council has term till 2025. While nine members from YSRC would lose the posts, TDP would be the biggest victim as all of its 34 members would lose job in case the council were to be abolished. In fact, 16 members would retire in 2021 that would have given Jaganmohan Reddy a chance to gain majority in the council.

Title: ‘Salesman pockets Pongal gift hamper’
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Tirupur: A salesman of a ration shop on Kangeyam Road at Aranmanaipudur here allegedly pocketed Rs 6,000, which was a part of Pongal gift hamper distributed by the state government. A video of him admitting it has gone viral on social media.

The video was taken by S Saravana Prakash of Perichipalayam. “I did not get Rs 1,000 given for ration card holders. But I got a message that I have received the Pongal gift on January 21,” he said. Subsequently, Saravana checked about it with the salesman. “He said since six card holders did not get the gift hamper, he took the money,” Saravana said, adding, “But it was not possible to take the money without the ration cards. Also, he needed to get the signatures of the beneficiaries.”

Saravana said the salesman refused to show him the register when he demanded to see it. A PDS official said they did not receive any complaint. “But we will inquiry into the issue and take action against the salesman, if he were found guilty,” the official said. tnn

Title: Maharashtra: Travel plans to China trip after disease outbreak
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The coronavirus outbreak has cast a shadow on citizens’ China travel plans, prompting cancellation of some bookings and enquiries about the plausibility of spending summer holidays there.Sources in Indian travel and hotel booking e-commerce website ixigo stated that search enquiries for Beijing and Shanghai had dropped. Data showed 40-45% decrease in bookings from Mumbai to China in January after the coronavirus outbreak as compared to the December travel figures.Several Puneites plan trips to China from Mumbai, which has direct flight connections to the country.Travel companies claimed that almost all their clients booked for China were calling them up to ask if they should cancel their upcoming trips to the country. Vikas Agarwal, the director of VT Travel, told TOI that four passengers who had booked air tickets to the US with a transit stop at Shanghai, China, cancelled the entire booking on Wednesday fearing issues in clearing immigration upon reaching the US.“The US has begun screening travellers from China for the new virus and my clients were worried about facing problems while clearing immigration in the US if they touched down in China during the journey. They made a fresh booking to the US with an airline with a transit stop in Dubai,” said Agarwal.He said his clients had to bear an additional cost of Rs50,000 for cancelling the earlier booking, and another Rs1 lakh for fresh and closer-to-travel-date booking.Balu Ramachandran, senior VP, Cleartrip, told TOI, “We have started to see some signs of travellers refraining from booking to China after the virus outbreak and the subsequent travel advisory. The last week registered a 33% dip in Pune specific bookings from the week before that. We are yet to observe any immediate traveller reactions in terms of bookings’ cancellations to the country.”Santosh Gupta, the owner of Shree Vinayak Holidays, said his company had blocked air tickets to China for seven business travellers from the city in February. “But the clients called me up informing about cancelling their travel to China after the news of the virus outbreak,” said Gupta.Aloke Bajpai, co-founder, ixigo, said, “We haven’t seen immediate cancellations on current bookings, but search enquiries for Beijing and Shanghai have dropped by 37% after advisories were issued for travel to China. A prolonged outbreak might result in a decrease in business travel bookings from India, which form the majority of the outbound numbers to China.”Rishikesh Pujari, the director of Vihar Travels, said, “We are closely monitoring the situation and awaiting an official travel advisory from the Chinese government.”

Title: Pune: Shaniwarwada requires upkeep, Aaditya Thackeray to visit
Content:
The iconic fort that was home to several Peshwes who challenged the Mughals and later the British, celebrated ... Read More

PUNE: The utter neglect of a monument as iconic as Shaniwarwada has upset not only the descendants of the Peshwas but also history scholars in the city.Udaysinh Peshwa, one of the descendants, said the palace of his ancestors has fallen into disrepair. “I had written to the previous chief minister, but nothing has been done. Hence, I have decided not to write to anyone or speak with anyone seeking restoration. Maharashtrians have forgotten their own history,” he added.The iconic fort that was home to several Peshwes who challenged the Mughals and later the British, celebrated its 288th foundation day on Wednesday.Uday Kulkarni, author of The Era of Bajirao, tweeted to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray and member of Parliament from Pune, Girish Bapat on Thursday, saying that the 18th century Ganapati painting just inside the Delhi Darwaza of Shaniwarwada is on the verge of disappearing.Tourism minister Aaditya Thackeray , when told about the plight of Shaniwarwada, said, “I am coming to Pune soon. I will be reviewing all tourism related places. Once the review is done, we will see what the government can do to revamp tourist facilities.”Kundan Kumar Sathe, secretary of Thorale Bajirao Peshwa Pratishthan, said Shaniwarwada was seven floors high and it took the British seven days to burn the entire structure down.“Imagine the grandeur of the palace and think about what it has come to now. We have been sending letters to all state ministers for the restoration of the monument but nobody has done anything so far.
