The government needs to tell the Archaeological Survey of India to restore Shaniwarwada,” he added.Kulkarni said a lot of Maratha art history that is on the walls of old wadas is being destroyed due to neglect. “Shaniwarwada is a Grade I heritage structure as declared by the ASI. We have so much history, so much to preserve and showcase to the world, yet we do nothing about it,” he added.Several letters to the administration urging them to write to the ASI in Delhi to allocate funds for the restoration of these monuments have been written, he said.“Once all this is gone, an entire part of our rich history will be lost to future generations. Some people say painting over the old one will destroy the authenticity of the original. But if we do not restore it, we are losing it all. Hence, restoration is better,” Kulkarni said.An Archaeological Survey of India official, on the condition of anonymity, said funds are scarce for restoration. “We get money only for maintenance and not for restoration. If such funding is allocated from the headquarters, then we can take up restoration,” he said.

Title: Maharashtra: It’s still winter, but humidity brings on slight perspiration
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: High humidity levels, especially during the early morning and late evening hours, have marked the weather this month.Data from the India Meteorological Department showed that relative humidity (RH) has been high during all the days of January as morning humidity levels on most days has been crossing 90%.Since the humidity has gone up, it has given rise to the uncomfortable feeling that comes in the wake of heat and perspiration, during the day as well as the night. Both days and nights are slightly warmer because humidity has pushed up the ‘heat index’.The normal humidity levels for the current winter for Shivajinagar usually range from 82% to 85% during the morning while the normal level for evening is around 35%.City-based working professional Deepa A said, “The weather currently is making me feel stuffy and sweaty. The air seems humid during the day as well as the night. Travelling around noon during winters should be pleasant but not nowadays, when it is humid and uncomfortable.”Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD Pune told TOI that the city and parts of state are seeing some moisture incursion due to the prevailing wind pattern. “Southcentral Maharashtra is under the influence of easterly and southeasterly winds causing a slight moisture incursion, while north Konkan and north Madhya Maharashtra are experiencing northeasterly winds. The interaction between the two wind flows is resulting in partial clouding especially in the early morning and late evening hours, which not only keeps night temperatures high but also the air marginally humid,” he said.Humidity isn’t a typical winter phenomenon, but has been experienced since the start of the season due to various weather systems pumping in moisture. The unusual amount of moisture has also been responsible for the isolated haze in parts of Pune in the early morning on many days.

Title: Pune: PCMC demolition drive a ‘farce’, say Wakad residents
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The civic body undertakes anti-encroachment drive along the Dutt Mandir Road in Wakad on Thursday

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: A drive was conducted by the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) to remove encroachments along Dutt Mandir Road in Wakad on Thursday.

However, the civic body’s action did not go down well with the local residents who dubbed the drive as “farce”.

Speaking to TOI, Sudesh Raje, president, Pimpri Chinchwad Housing Societies Federation, said, “Only two JCBs were used to remove hoardings and other minor structures on the civic land. The PCMC did not take any action to acquire the land which is in its possession for road widening. This shows that today’s demolition drive was just a farce ”

Another resident, Avinash Takte Patil, said, “The demolition drive was not conducted against the unauthorised stalls at the chowpatty near Ambedkar colony along Dutt Mandir Road.”

The 2km-long Dutt Mandir Road extends from near Dange chowk on Sangvi-Kiwale BRTS Road to Wakad municipal school chowk on Nashik phata-Wakad BRTS Road.

Though the development plan mentions the width of the road as 45 metres, its breadth is just half in reality. Around 10 to 20 housing societies and various commercial complexes are located along this main road in Wakad due to which there is heavy movement of traffic.

Many stalls have come up along the road on open land. As vehicles are parked on the road most of the time, they cause obstacles to free flow of traffic. So, there are long traffic snarls during peak morning and evening hours.

Shirish Poredi, spokesperson, engineering department, PCMC, said, “Farmers had sold their land to builders, who while getting permission for construction of residential and commercial projects, had handed over the land to the civic body and received transfer of development of rights (TDR) in lieu. Encroachments had taken place on the land handed over to the PCMC which were removed during the demolition drive.”

Satish Ingale, executive engineer, building permission and unauthorised construction control department, said, “Action was taken on a 20,588 sqft area along Dutt Mandir Road. Four tin sheds, 12 ottas (platforms), 3 stalls, 1 gate, 1 staircase, 25 boards and 8 compound walls were removed in the daylong drive. Police personnel, and civic employees participated in the drive.”

Title: College student sent in cop custody in assault case
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The 21-year-old college student arrested on the charge of assaulting a casual worker in Dhanori was sent in police custody till February 1 on Thursday, while six teenage boys detained in the case were sent to observation home.

The alleged assault took place at Munjaba Vasti in Dhanori shortly after midnight on Tuesday, following which the casual worker, Sagar Mahadev Bhalerao (24), succumbed to his head injuries at the Sassoon General Hospital.

Senior inspector Arun Avhad of Vishrantwadi police station told TOI, “After studying their age documents on Thursday, the teenagers were produced before the juvenile justice board, which sent them to the observation home. Jagdale was produced before a city court, which remanded him in police custody till February 1.”

As per the Vishrantwadi police, the college student and the teenagers assaulted Bhalerao, a resident of Munjaba Vasti in Dhanori, while he was walking to his house. “Bhalerao allegedly abused Pritam Rajkumar Jagdale, the college student, for riding his motorcycle close to him and also threatened him,” police said.

One of the detained teenagers was riding with Jagdale at the time of the assault. Infuriated over the way Bhalerao reacted, Jagdale challenged him and told him to meet him at the nearby chowk. On the way to the chowk, Jagdale and his minor associate phoned the other boys, who gathered at the chowk. As soon as Bhalerao reached there, they launched a brutal assault on him. One of the assailants attacked Bhalerao with a bicycle chain, another hit him with a stick while the others rained kicks and blows, the police said.

Senior inspector Avhad said the police would search for the weapons used in the crime, including the bicycle chain and wooden sticks.

Later in the morning, police detained the boys and arrested Jagdale. “Further investigation is under way, the police added.

Title: Tribal activists demand more Navodaya schools in state
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Despite being a hotbed of Maoist violence, Andhra Pradesh has the lowest number of Jawahar Navodaya Vidyalaya schools in the country, rue tribal activists.

According to tribal activists in the state, there is dire need for more Navodaya schools in Agency areas that have been affected by Maoist activity for years. They say that repeated pleas to authorities to set up more such schools have gone unheard.

Tribal activist G Ram Gopal said that Andhra Pradesh has only 13 Navodaya schools. A proposal to set up a Navodaya Vidyalaya in Visakhapatnam Agency was rejected recently, he said.

“We still do not know why the proposal was rejected. The land has been made available,” he added. Gopal informed that the number of Navodaya schools in the state is lower than that in Odisha and Madhya Pradesh. He blames the state leadership for being unable to promote quality schooling in areas that have suffered due to Left-wing extremism.

Meanwhile, according to a letter from Navodaya Vidyalaya Samiti (of the Union MHRD department), the proposal was rejected because two Navodaya schools cannot be set up in the same district.

In the letter to the assistant commissioner, authorities of the Navodaya Vidyalaya Samiti pointed out that there is already a Navodaya school which has been running since 1987-88.

Tribal leaders argue that the case for a separate such school in the Maoist-affected areas was not made properly. Officials of the Integrated Tribal Development Agency (ITDA) said that on their part, they had identified 30 acres land in Chintapalli.

They said that they could only facilitate land and infrastructure only after the school is sanctioned and pointed out that their role is limited to providing infrastructure.

Now, tribal leaders have approached MPs from Araku and Visakhapatnam to take up the issue.

Title: PCMC told to revise edu panel’s ‘vague’ proposals
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: The standing committee has directed the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation to revise education committee’s seven “vague” proposals before sending them for approval again.

Vilas Madigeri, chairman of the PCMC standing committee, said, “These proposals are vague. They lack the number of students who will benefit and the cost of material like tablets. Besides, the tender process has not been completed so we do not know the cost at which the material is to be procured.”

One of the proposals had sought standing committee’s approval for providing tablets to Std V-VIII students of 12 schools for improving their educational quality. “Other proposals include creating e-classrooms, distributing scouts and guides’ uniforms, jackets and copper water bottles to civic school students, besides providing them one egg and one fruit in the mid-day meal scheme and introducing a pilot project in primary schools for teaching classical music,” he added.

Manisha Pawar, chairperson, PCMC education committee, said, “The proposals aimed at providing best of education material to civic school students.”

Vitthal alias Nana Kate, opposition leader, PCMC, said, “Such proposals must be approved at the beginning of the fiscal to ensure smooth roll out of the scheme. But the civic administration and the ruling party lack proper planning.”

Maruti Bhapkar, social activist said, “The education committee should have sent these proposals and got them approved at the beginning of the current fiscal or academic year.”

Title: Maharashtra: Deccan drifter John Baba in hospital after brutal assault
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A 50-year-old drifter, known to many residents and business persons on Prabhat Road and Deccan area as ‘John Baba’, was found brutally assaulted and injured on the Riverbed Road early on Thursday morning.

Senior inspector Deepak Lagad of the Deccan Gymkhana police station told TOI, “John Baba is from an educated family. Nevertheless, for unknown reasons, he started staying on the pavements and worked as a waiter at prominent restaurants in the area. Later, he gave up the job and started begging. He is a graduate and would often converse in English with local traders, restaurant customers, and others. John also has a penchant for crisp, clean branded clothes.”

The police are trying to locate John’s relatives. As of now, he has been admitted to Sassoon General Hospital and doctors said he is out of danger.

Lagad said, “The assault took place under Sambhaji Bridge on the riverbed road around 12.30am. Usually, the area remains crowded at the time owing to the eateries and tonga operators active in the stretch. Unidentified assailant(s) attempted to smash John’s head with a brick. Local traders and a police patrol team rushed to the spot on hearing his screams.”

“We have registered a case of attempt to murder although the motive behind the crime is yet to be established,” Lagad said.

Local businessman Manpreet Singh said, “John is a good human being. He greets everyone with a smile. The residents of Prabhat Road know him very well.”

“Some people from Prabhat Road and Fergusson College Road informed us that he belongs to a good family and he used to stay in a house on Prabhat Road. But his past is obscure,” Lagad said. “We have appealed local residents to come forward and help the police track his relatives,” he added.

According to the police, John Baba and two others, including a scrap collector, had been staying under the bridge. “John did not have any addiction. He would buy tea and snacks from the local shopkeepers instead of begging for food. He used to seek alms from passers-by,” Lagad said. One of the two men who used to stay beneath the bridge has been missing for the last two days, the police said.

Title: ‘From Akbar to Narendra Modi, religion has played role to woo masses’
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Supriya Gandhi at a session

The first day of Jaipur Literature festival witnessed a very interesting and relevant discussion: The use of religion by Mughal emperors and modern-day politicians to woo the masses.

Speakers Manimugdha Sharma and Supriya Gandhi discussed Mughal rulers Akbar and Dara Shikoh and their policies in one of the sessions.

Manimugdha, who has written a book on emperor Akbar said, “Akbar praised the chant of Allah-Hu Akbar that indirectly glorified him and pleased the masses. Similarly, when Narendra Modi was campaigning in Banaras ahead of the 2014 Lok Sabha elections, his supporters chanted ‘Har Har Modi’ similar to ‘Har Har Mahadev’. So, religion and politics in this country can never be looked in isolation.”

William Dalrymple, who was in conversation with the authors, said Akbar out of curiosity or for political gain gave respect to every religion. So, will it be correct to say he was a secular ruler? Manimudgha disagreed to this. “The term secular is an aspect of modern world. We can say he was tolerant, but not secular,” he said.

Supriya Gandhi, while referring to her book, said Dara Shikoh like his predecessors conducted a lot of experiments with religion. He looked at religion objectively and tried to follow the footsteps of former rulers. “He was a philosopher and aspired to become a king, though for other political reasons he could not live his dream,” she said.

When Dalrymple asked that many historians blamed Akbar for using his predominantly Hindu army to capture kingdoms in south India, Manimugdha rightly denied any such strategy was used by the emperor.

He said, “At that time Akbar’s court and army were so intermingled that it wasn’t right to say he played with religion to force his authority. The army chiefs were fighting for their emperor and not for religion. In fact, Amber rulers were the first to accept the allegiance to Akbar and put an inscription at Amber fort praising him. So, they were loyal towards their rulers.”

Title: Nepali youth tries to enter IAF stn, caught
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Jaisalmer: The Air Force personnel on Wednesday caught a suspicious Nepali youth who tried to enter the sensitive Air Force station in Barmer. The accused was handed over to the police. He is being grilled by a joint interrogation committee.

Following a terror threat on the Republic Day, all sensitive Army premises and Air Force airports are being strictly guarded.

According to the information from police, the Nepali youth was trying to enter Air Force airport by dodging the personnel and was caught. During the interrogation, he showed an Aadhaar card which identified him as Mahesh Kumar, a resident of Faridkot in Punjab.

However, according to the sources, on strict inquiry, the youth revealed that he was a resident of Nepal. He had done his engineering and was going to Uttarlai Air Force station for a job, he added.

Uttarlai Air Force station is very sensitive and always remains on the target of Pakistan intelligence agency ISI.

Title: Goa: Political parties submit laundry list for grants
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The panel met with over 20 representatives of various political parties

PANAJI: The 15th Finance Commission headed by its chairman N K Singh, met with over 20 representatives of various political parties and local bodies here on Thursday during the panel’s three-day visit to Goa.

Both Congress and Goa Forward Party (GFP) stressed that the parameters used to allocate funds for Goa were flawed and needed a revamp.

GFP requested the commission for Rs 6,700 crore, the most while Congress and BJP sought Rs 2,610 crore and Rs 1,300 crore respectively.

GFP recommendations for higher devolution of funds was based on the state’s ecological and linguistic vulnerability. Congress also said that Goa was vulnerable, but with respect to climate change and rise in sea water levels.

“GFP demands the commission may sanction a one-time grant of Rs 6,000 crore for rehabilitating people affected by closure of mining and to provide them alternative employment till resumption of mining,” said GFP president Vijai Sardesai . BJP in contrast sought Rs 300 crore to assist those affected by the closure of mining.

BJP’s recommendations focused on mining, tourism, solid waste management and agriculture. “An amount of Rs. 250 crore may be allocated to undertake activities which shall boost tourism,” said state BJP president Sadanand Tanavade.

Congress and GFP said the influx of migrants and falling birth rates in the state had brought about societal changes and threatened Goa’s culture. In order to counter this, both GFP and Congress sought additional grants to help preserve local culture and identity.

Congress sought Rs 150 crore to implement the Goenche Daiz scheme which will benefit 80,000 traditional artisans, Rs 100 crores for conservation of ancient forts and heritage sites, Rs 5 crore for revival of Perani Zagor and Rs 5 crore to get UNESCO heritage inscription for Goa's Tiatr art form.

Title: YSRC leaders protest against ‘anti-growth’ TDP
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: YSRC leaders along with members of the women’s wing of the party took out protests across the city condemning TDP chief Chandrababu Naidu for allegedly blocking the capital decentralisation bill in the council.

Senior YSRCP leaders Malla Vijaya Prasad, Vamsi Krishna Srinivas and KK Raju took out protest rallies in different parts of the city. The protesters also burnt an effigy of the TDP chief alleging that he was against the development of Visakhapatnam city and district. Vamsi Krishna Srinivas in his address at the protest rally in Maddilapalem condemned the TDP MLAs of Visakhapatnam for doing injustice to the city.

The protest rally at Maddilapalem Junction was taken out under the aegis of women’s wing leader G Gowri. Lashing out Naidu, she said, “ He is a traitor as far as north Andhra is concerned. The TDP chief’s bias against north Andhra is quite obvious.” The women protesters also burnt an effigy of the TDP chief.

In the Visakhapatnam north legislative constituency, YSRCP leader K K Raju led the protests.

Title: Mahesh Kale wants youth to “discover” classical music
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Mahesh Kale during a media interaction on Thursday

PUNE: Lecture-demonstration format is not the best way to introduce youth to Indian classical music, said National Award-winning classical music exponent Mahesh Kale .

Instead, youngsters could “discover” classical music through a concert like Infusion, to be held in Pune on February 2, he said.

“The bandish Albela Saajan Aayo Re is known to today’s generation as one from the film Hum Dil De Chuke Sanam, and the search result on YouTube displays it on top. But if one looks carefully, one kind find a black-and-white video of Pandit Basavaraj Rajguru presenting the bandish sung in raag Ahir Bhairav. When youngsters discover it they can brag about to their friends. And that is what I want youngsters to do,” Kale told TOI after a media interaction on his latest venture.

Infusion will be held at the Ganesh Kala Krida Manch, a day after its show in Mumbai. It is the culmination of some “experiments”, a “beta test” of which he tried out at a recent concert in the city.

“I want to show to the youngsters that the essence of classical music lies in the way they listen to the playlists on their phones, as in the kind of influence that Indian classical music has on modern music,” Kale said.

The core of the two-hour concert will be classical music, but the presentation will be married to the “spontaneity” of Western music and other modern music. To that end, Kale’s show will also feature both Indian and western instrumentalists.

The show is neither a “western” music or Indian classical music concert. In fact, Kale doesn’t think that either needs to exist at the cost of the other.

“This will be a kind of concert where classical music is like the methi in a thaliepeeth. You will consume it without knowing anything about it,” he said, explaining the “bite-sized” approach to de-mystify classical music for youngsters.

Kale added that the upcoming concert may turn out to be the start of a series.

“It can be a part of a series of concerts in both India and abroad. I am part of a non-profit organisation in the US, so this can be scaled up to a larger series,” he added.

Title: NIE Newsmakers’ Meet offers police work insight
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Students at Pune police commissioner's office with (from left) DCP (crime) Bachchan Singh, joint commissioner ... Read More

PUNE: A deeper insight into the working of the police force and interaction with the senior officers marked the “Times NIE Newsmakers ’ Meet 2019-20” held in association with the city police and The Times Foundation at the police commissioner’s office on Wednesday.

Over 170 students from NIE member schools participated in the meet, titled “Knowing Your City Police”.

The forum facilitated a dialogue between the students and police officers. The panel of police officers comprised commissioner of police K Venkatesham, joint commissioner of police Ravindra Shisve, additional commissioner of police (crime), Ashok Morale, deputy commissioner of police (crime) Bachchan Singh and deputy commissioner of police (Zone- I), Swapna Gore.

A volley of questions on challenges in policing, cyber-crime, traffic issues and juvenile crimes, among others, was posed before the senior authorities. Warning students of the vulnerability in cyber space, Venkatesham said, “You should be very careful of what you are sharing on the digital space.” He, however, affirmed that the use of technology would help in effective policing, especially to keep a check on traffic violators.

“Films are anything but normal,” said Shisve on the portrayal of jails on the silver screen. He said a lot of emphasis was laid on reformative measures of the criminals and around 80-90% got reformed through engagement in skill-set building activities undertaken in the jails.

Earlier, the students visited the Bharosa cell that included units for women, senior citizens and child-care; and the SEVA (Service Excellence and Victim Assistance) cell. A weapon display was also organized to apprise students of the arms used in different combat operations.

In the morning session, Bachchan Singh briefed the students about the working of the Bharosa and SEVA cells. This was followed by a question-answer session. Singh said the police were adopting reformative measures for the juveniles under the CARE (Counselling and Reformative Education) programme. He also said the Bharosa cell institutionalized in January 2019 was an effort to address the grievances of the general public before resorting to the legal recourse.

“The SEVA cell acts as a centralized feedback centre that keeps a track of all the visitors at the police station and analyses whether the concerned issues are resolved after the visit,” he said. An informative session on cyber-crime and traffic regulation was conducted by assistant police inspector Ashwini Patil and police inspector Rajesh Puranik, respectively.

Title: Pune: Rush for birth certificates amid CAA fears
Content:
Students participated in a march at Savitribai Phule Pune University, protesting Citizenship Amendment Act (Fi... Read More

PUNE: The civic birth and death registration office in Kasba Peth is suddenly flooded with birth certificate requests from people in their 50s and 60s, especially from the minority communities.Officials said the sudden rush was predominantly driven by the fears arising out of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ) and the proposed National Register of Citizens (NRC).“We have been observing the rush for birth certificates mainly from the members the Muslim community since January, who were born in the 1960s or 1970s. When asked, about 55 applicants admitted that they were seeking the birth certificates to prove their citizenship in the wake of the CAA and NRC,” medical expert Kalpana Baliwant, head of the birth and death registration office of the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC), said.Among these applicants, those born before 1965 are directed to approach court. “As per the law, if there is no record of an individual’s birth, his/her family members will have to establish the birth in the court of law. We only give the kin or the person concerned non-availability certificate (NAC), which they can before the court. It is only after court’s direction that we issue birth registration to such people or their family members,” Baliwant said.Under the PMC’s digitisation drive, which took off in 2000, the birth and deaths of those registered with it have been digitised from 1965.Pune district collector Naval Kishore Ram told TOI, “There is no need to produce birth certificate as of now as the state government has not issued any guidelines on the same. We request people not to create panic.”The state government is yet to issue any guidelines on the NPR exercise, which is to start with the census drive in Maharashtra in the month of May.

Title: ‘No evidence to back charges’
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Vijayawada: The CID registered cases against former TDP ministers Prathipati Pulla Rao and P Narayana for allegedly intimidating and cheating a Dalit farmer in Venkatayapalem village in Guntur district on Thursday.

Speaking to few media persons in Mangalagiri, CID SP Mary Prashanti explained that they received a complaint from a woman farmer Pothuraju Bujji who claimed that both the ministers had allegedly purchased around 99 cents (almost an acre) of land from her by means of ‘threats’ and ‘conspiracy’.

Officials said they have registered a case under sections 420 (cheating), 506 (criminal intimidation) and 120B (criminal conspiracy) against both Pulla Rao and Narayana.

Apart from these sections, Prashanti also explained that since the complainant happens to be a Dalit, it would also attract relevant sections under SC/ST Atrocities Act.

In terms of allegations of insider trading , Prashanti explained that they found 797 persons who had white ration cards (falling under the poverty line) of having purchased 700 acres of land across five mandals in the capital region of Amaravati that is worth Rs 220 crore. Four teams have been formed to examine all the 797 white ration card holders in possession of these lands.

Meanwhile, reacting to the case filed against him, Pulla Rao addressed a press conference calling the charge ‘fake’ and ‘part of the ruling dispensation’s vindictive politics’. He also said he will drag all the officials involved in filing the fake cases against the opposition to the court.

“It is a clear cut case of political vendetta. The ruling party does not have any evidence to back their allegations of insider trading against us” Pulla Rao said. Pulla Rao worked as the civil supplies minister while Narayana was the municipal administration and urban development minister under the previous N Chandrababu Naidu’s regime.

Title: Pune: Paan stall owner held for abusing & charging at cop with stick
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Yerawada police on Wednesday arrested a paan stall owner on the charges of abusing and charging at a constable with a stick over a dispute of not closing the shop at Siddharthnagar near the old Ramwadi octroi post around 1.30am.

Sunil Thorat (45) from Siddharthnagar was sent to the Yerawada Central Prison after a court remanded him in 14 days of magisterial custody.

Senior inspector Yunus Shaikh from the Yerawada police station said, “We have filed a case against Thorat under the Maharashtra Police Act for running the shop till late at night, around 12.30am.”

He said, “An hour later, a constable on night patrol, Dnyandeo Awari, found him conducting business again and told him to close the shop. The paan stall owner then picked up a dispute with Awari,” Shaikh said.

Thorat, in a fit of anger, started abusing Awari, the officer said. “He then picked up a stick, charged at Awari and started arguing with him,” he added.

Thorat was arrested after Awari lodged an FIR against him.

Title: Maharashtra: 15 lakh benefit from Sarathi helpline
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The civic body received 3.11 lakh complaints through various mediums in the past six years, of which 37.34% accounted for drainage-related issues.

The complaints were received from August 15, 2013, to January 15, 2020. Neelkanth Poman, chief information and technology officer, PCMC, said 15 lakh people contacted the PCMC using the Sarathi helpline alone in the past six years.

PCMC claimed of redressing 99.53% of the complaints. “The civic body has created a mechanism, in which the departments concerned take action in a time-bound manner to redress the complaints,” a civic official said.

Title: More sub-registrar offices in pipeline for Pune: IGR
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

PUNE: The state registration department plans to set up additional sub-registrar offices in places with a high volume of property registrations .

This is a bid to ensure the waiting time is reduced, especially in areas like Pune, Mumbai and Thane.

“We are carrying out a statewide review of the workload on these offices and the registration of documents from each office. There are several offices in Pune and Mumbai where the registrations are more and a detailed review will be taken,” Omprakash Deshmukh, who took charge on Wednesday as the state’s Inspector General of Revenue and Controller of Stamps (IGR), said. “A few proposals of new sub-registrar offices are pending with the government and should be sanctioned soon. Meanwhile, we are also stressing on e-registrations and will address issues related to online registrations,” Deshmukh said.

At present, the state has 517 sub-registrar offices. Pune has 27, Mumbai has 25 and Thane (including Kalyan) has 23, according to official data. Builders’ associations have made a demand to increase the number of these offices in these cities, especially in Pune’s Paud and Hinjewadi areas.

Currently, the concurrent jurisdiction of the sub-registrar offices in the district extends to villages on the boundaries of Pune Municipal Corporation and Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation, but a few villages in Mulshi taluka are not covered. There is a demand for a sub-registrar office in Mulshi taluka, for which a proposal has been sent to the government, Deshmukh said.

Credai-Pune Metro president Suhas Merchant said said there was a need for more offices in Paud and Hinjewadi, where more than 5,000 units are sold annually. Registrations are “unreasonably” delayed at these offices due to the limited slots, poor internet connectivity and outdated hardware, he said.

Title: AP cops win national-level awards in tech and training categories
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Award winners with DGP Gautam Sawang (centre)

Vijayawada: The Andhra Pradesh police have won two national-level awards in technology and training categories, at the recently-held National Conference on Police Communication in New Delhi. The Remote Area Communication Enhancement (RACE) project being implemented by the Andhra Pradesh police was selected as the best communication system in the country.

Speaking to TOI, Deputy Inspector General (DIG) G Palaraju, who designed the RACE project, said that the main aim of the project was to establish communication with district and state headquarters from remote areas where no forms of communication are available. “Two-wheeler and four-wheeler based systems were designed for this purpose,” he said.

While the four-wheeler system is used to establish communication from remote areas when there is a law and order situation, during disasters and VVIP visits, the two-wheeler system is used to replace the discharged batteries of field officers’ radios during natural calamities and spot rectification of defective radios.

The AP police also received the award for best training in technological aspects. The training manuals created to use body worn cameras, drones, CCTV cameras, Locked House Monitoring System (LHMS), laser guns, breath analysers and various mobile applications were adjudged best in the country. NSJ Laxmi, deputy inspector general for communication, received award from Union minister of state for home, G Kishan Reddy. Director general of police D Gautam Sawang appreciated both the officers on Thursday for their contribution in developing the systems and winning the awards at national level.

Title: Pawan meets BJP president Nadda in Delhi
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Vijayawada: “The three-capital issue is only for the political gain of the YSRC. Neither Prime Minister Narendra Modi nor home minister Amit Shah have been informed about the issue,” alleged Jana Sena chief Pawan Kalyan who met BJP national president JP Nadda here on Thursday along with AP BJP co-in charge Sunil Deodhar and state president Kanna Lakshminarayana and explained the conditions prevailing in the state over the three-capital issue.

Later, addressing the media, Deodhar, said, “We apprised Nadda about the situation in AP and how both parties are marching ahead. We are going to take the fight to the streets against the anti-people policies of the Jaganmohan Reddy government and the backstabbing of the people by the TDP government. Both TDP and YSRC are rivals of the Jana Sena and BJP alliance.”

“Everyday YSRC spokespersons and leaders are spreading lies saying that they have already discussed and taken the consent of the Prime Minister about the three-capital issue. But neither PM Modi nor any minister from the Union government is aware of this move. I appeal to the people of Andhra Pradesh to not fall for the mind games of Jaganmohan Reddy or his spokespersons,” Deodhar said

Title: Jaipur: Facebook, WhatsApp staff in government panel to find alternative to internet ban
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: The district administration has included representatives of Facebook and WhatsApp as members of a committee’s technical working group which was set up to find an alternative solution to suspending internet services during unavoidable situations.

The committee, formed with the objective of protecting the common man's interests in the event of internet closure, will submit its report to the divisional commissioner of Jaipur, K C Verma, on January 29. The first meeting was held on January 8 under the chairmanship of Verma. During the meeting, it was suggested that instead of completely suspending internet services for a certain period of time in a particular area, an alternative system to shut down social media websites and mobile apps must be adopted. The next meeting of the technical working group will be held at mini secretariat on February 12 under chairmanship of Verma to discuss the report and its findings.

The meeting will include convenor of technical working group, Gulab Chand Jingar and deputy general manager of BSNL, police officers, representatives of Airtel, Vodafone, Reliance Jio, Facebook and WhatsApp. District election officer Joga Ram said 45 officers of PHED, who were issued showcause notices for negligence in election work, will have to update data of their subordinate officers and employees by Friday, else action will be taken against them.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Maoists call for boycott of local bodies elections
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: The Pedabayalu-Korukonda area committee of CPI ( Maoists ) gave a call to the public to boycott the local bodies elections, which will be held next month. The banned outfit alleged that the BJP, at the Centre, and YSRC, in the state, have been observing the anti-people policies.

Maoists pasted posters at Pedabayalu-G Madugula mandal borders in which they gave call to the people to drive out the YSRC government from the state. “The governments have been trying to suppress the people’s movements by setting up of more number of the police camps in the district,” they alleged.

The Maoists alleged that fake local bodies’ elections (ZPTC, MPTC and Panchayat) would not solve the problems of the people. Setting up of police camps or mobile towers are not signs of development.

After learning about the Maoists posters and their call for boycott of the elections, district police chiefs are taking extra measures for the elections and focussing on security measures.

Title: Criminal booked under MCOCA held after 5 years
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: City crime branch officials on Wednesday nabbed a criminal who was on the run for the last five years after being booked under the stringent MCOCA Act.

A team comprising senior inspector Arun Waykar, sub-inspector Hanumant Shinde and others nabbed Karan Muralidhar Chorghe (30) of Wangani in Velhe taluka.

The Pune rural police had invoked charges against him under MCOCA five years back. He was booked by the Velhi and Haveli police stations for various body and property offences, including murder, attempt to murder and also under the Indian Arms Act.

Waykar said that Chorghe was involved in robbery cases. “He was part of an organised crime syndicate. The other members of the syndicate have already been arrested by the Pune rural police,” he said.

Police said that Wangani village is a hilly area located close to the city and Chorghe made use of the topography to avert his arrest all these years.

A tip-off was received by the police that Chorghe was supposed to come to Katraj on his scooter and a trap was laid to catch him. Police have seized the scooter worth Rs 70,000.

He will be handed over to the Pune rural police for further investigation.

Title: Kota zila pramukh arrested for graft
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Kota: The Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB) arrested Kota zila pramukh Surendra Gochar on Thursday morning for taking bribe of Rs 25,000 through his personal assistant. The ACB on Thursday noon produced the accused zila pramukh before the ACB court in the city, which ordered to send him to judicial custody till February 4.

His PA was arrested on December 13 with the bribe amount and had claimed to have accepted the bribe on behalf of the zila pramukh and a clerk (LDC) of his office was also arrested a few days later. Gochar is from the Congress party.

Meanwhile, former state minister and Congress MLA from Sangod, Kota, Bharat Singh has demanded to immediately expel accused Gochar from the party. No national political party, both BJP and Congress, has ever shown the courage to expel their corrupt leaders and party members, Singh said and added, “The party should immediately expel Gochar and should show its commitment against corruption.” BJP also has taken no action against Kota UIT ex-chairman, who was last year arrested for corruption, he added.

Gochar was arrested from his official residence in the city on Thursday morning following order received on Wednesday from the ACB headquarters, said Jaipur superintendent of police, ACB, Kota, Chandrasheel Thakur. Gochar’s role in the bribery case was confirmed in the investigation by ACB inspector Gyanchand, he said. Personal assistant of the accused zila pramukh, Chandra Prakesh Gupta (57) was arrested on December 13, 2019 for having accepted the bribe of Rs 25,000 and in the interrogation, he claimed he had accepted the bribe amount on behalf of zila pramukh Surendra Gochar and junior clerk of his office Kamalkant Vaishnav, said the SP. At the time of the trap, the PA called the zila pramukh and the clerk separately and each of the two asked him to “keep the amount with him,” which they would collect later, he further said and added that later, the zila pramukh went absconding. However, he appeared on ACB’s call for interrogation, but could not respond satisfactorily. The accused clerk Kamalkant had fled away from the spot at the time of trap on December 13, 2019 but was arrested on December 16.

The three accused allegedly demanded the bribe amount of Rs 25,000 from sarpanch of Kaliyakhedi Gram Panchayat for the financial sanctioning of the budget for developmental works in two villages of the gram panchayat area and for not visiting the site for inspection.

Title: Pune: Cops bust sex racket in Bhosari mall, rescue six
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A team of Pimpri Chinchwad crime branch on Wednesday arrested four persons for running a sex racket from a spa at a mall in Bhosari and rescued six women.

Acting on a tip-off, the crime branch first sent a decoy customer to the spa. “After getting specific information from him, the crime branch team led by assistant inspector Deepali Marale raided the spa,” said an officer.

He said the team found six women in the spa. “The suspects had appointed them as therapists and forced them into prostitution,” the officer said, adding that the women were sent to a rescue home.

The four arrested persons are the 20-year-old owner of the spa and his three accomplices. A case has been registered against them with the Bhosari MIDC police.

They have been charged under Section 370 (buying or disposing of any person as a slave) of the Indian Penal Code and the relevant sections of the Prevention of Immoral Trafficking Act (PITA).

Title: PCMC to monitor sterilization of stray dogs via app
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The health department of the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation ( PCMC ) will monitor sterilization of stray dogs through a cell phone application from next month.

“The contractors will have to use an application to record details of the stray dog sterilization surgeries they perform. They will take photographs of the location from where the stray dog was caught so that it can be released there after the surgery. The photographs of the dog would also be saved on the application,” the veterinary officer Arun Dagade said.

The photographs of the surgery procedure and of the dogs released post-surgery at their original locations would also be saved in the app, he added. Each sterilized dog would be given a belt with a unique code number for identification.

He said on an average the civic body, through the appointed contractors, had sterilized 12,000 stray dogs in the last two to three years.

Residents were concerned about the stray dog population. A social activist Maruti Bhapkar said, “Packs of stray dogs are seen on roads. There is a need for an effective stray dog sterilization programme.”

A Pimpri resident Santosh Kale said, “Stray dogs are a nightmare for two-wheeler riders because they chase us when we return home late at night from office.”

Smita Shinde, a resident of Bhosari, said it was scary when a pack of stray dogs chased women and children carrying bags of food items from shops.

Title: 8 hurt, 2 critical as RTC bus rams container truck
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Vijayawada: Around ten people suffered ghastly injures—including two being in a critical condition— after an Express RTC bus rammed against a container truck near Medikonduru village in Guntur district on Thursday. According to Medikonduru cops, the incident happened at around 7 am when the RTC bus was heading towards Guntur from Macherla.

Passengers said that the bus was trying to overtake the slow-moving container truck at the narrow Medikonduru-Kurapadu road and when the two vehicles rammed each other. Soon, both vehicles lost control and fell into a gorge on the side of the road, leaving eight passengers injured.

Upon receiving information, the police reached the spot and rushed the injured to a local government hospital. Cops said that both the drivers are said to be in critical condition.

Cops registered a case under sections 304A of IPC (causing death due to negligence) at Medikondur police station. tnn

Title: Teachers write exam to be able to work in the US
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Vijayawada: Andhra Pradesh Non-Resident Telugu Society (APNRTS) conducted an online eligibility test for teachers interested in relocating to the US, at Potti Sriramulu College of Engineering and Technology in Kothapet area on Thursday. Ninety-six teachers took the exam took between 10 am and 12 noon.

Before the online test, a webinar was conducted by teachers who are currently working in the US, in which they shared their experiences. The teachers explained about the work culture, local accommodation, lifestyle and support given by the school administration. APNRTS president Venkat S Medapati visited the venue and addressed the participants about the Global Teachers Placement Program and other free services offered by the state government through their society.

He announced that in the first phase APNRTS, in association with Acclaim Global Education India Pvt Ltd (AGE), has placed 26 teachers from Andhra Pradesh in August 2019 at Ector County Independent School District and Kermit Independent School District, in Texas, USA. The test is being conducted on Thursday as there is a requirement of 50 Maths and Science teachers in the US.

Title: Rajasthan: 38 mandis to be connected with WiFi
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Chief minister Ashok Gehlot on Thursday approved proposals worth Rs 34 crore for connecting 38 agricultural produce mandis with WiFi and for development works in the mandis across the state.

He also approved independent status for five mandis in Behror, Kishangarhbas and Tijara (Alwar), Manohar police station (Jhalawar) and Sojat City (Pali).

Title: Delhi’s bad weather delays journey of 7 cabinet ministers
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Jaipur: At least seven cabinet ministers of the state government got stuck along with other Congress workers at the Jaipur airport for around two hours and experienced the woes of common passengers in their flights. They were to reach Delhi on Thursday evening to attend the wedding reception of the son of Avinash Pande, AICC general secretary and state in-charge.

According to airport sources, the cabinet ministers, including transport minister Pratap Singh Khachariyawas, sports minister Ashok Chandana, PHED minister B D Kalla and agriculture minister Lalchand Kataria along with RCA president Vaibhav Gehlot were to board a flight which was scheduled to take off at 6.20pm on Thursday.

“The flight got delayed due to bad weather at the Indira Gandhi airport in Delhi. Finally, the flight took off at 8.50pm. The flight got delayed due to heavy fog in Delhi,” said Jaideep Singh Balhara, director, Jaipur airport.

When contacted, Khachariyawas, who reached Delhi at 9.45pm, said, “This is very unprofessional approach by the airlines. We all were late.”

Most of the ministers and Congress workers were annoyed with the unwanted delay as they were off to attend the wedding reception.

Title: Pune: Anti-ragging gathering held
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The meeting of the anti-ragging committee of the Cummins College of Engineering for Women was held recently under the chairmanship of Madhuri Khambete, director and principal of the institute.

“It is the responsibility of senior students to guide freshers. All the senior students must ensure that no ragging takes place on the college and hostel premises,” Khambete said, adding that not even a single case of ragging took place in the college.

Anti-ragging committee coordinator Vaishali Salgar and other members were also present during the meeting.

Title: Jaipur airport to offer free healthcare to passengers
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Jaipur: With the number of flights operating from Jaipur constantly increasing, the Airports Authority of India has signed an MoU with a private hospital to provide free healthcare to passengers in need of treatment.

The hospital will provide round-the-clock medical services with the help of two doctors, nursing staff and emergency care services at the Mahatma Gandhi Hospital Medical Inspection Centre inaugurated on Thursday. District collector Joga Ram, Jaipur airport director J S Balhara, founder chairperson, Mahatma Gandhi Hospital Dr M L Swarankar, were present on the occasion.

Joga Ram said that the number of international flights and passengers has increased over the years. Medical Centre is an essential requirement to handle any kind of emergency. Dr Swarankar said that advanced life support ambulance will also be available to handle first-aid and complex emergency cases. In case of critical care related cases, patients can be shifted to the hospital.

At the airport, the hospital will provide free consultation, emergency treatment, ambulance and basic investigation services for the Airports Authority, Central Reserve Police Force, airlines’ staff and family members. Balhara said that 72 flights are landing every day at Jaipur airport. About 20,000 people are coming here everyday.

Title: Pune: Mayor to go live on Facebook once a month
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Murlidhar Mohol (C)

PUNE: Residents of the city can now directly interact with Pune Municipal Corporation mayor Murlidhar Mohol live on Facebook on fourth Saturday of every month.

The first session will be held on January 25 at 7 pm

A press statement issued by the mayor’s office said that Mohol will interact with citizens through his FB page.

Citizens will be able to ask question and raise their concerns, officials said.

The project aims at giving a platform for direct interaction with the chief of the municipal corporation.

It is for the first time that such an experiment was being carried by the mayor’s office, officials said.

"A large number of citizens use social media. This can be put to good use and a direct dialogue with citizens can be established. The citizens can offer their views and ask questions," he said.

Mohol added that going live on Facebook was a better option considering the geographical and demographic expanse of the city.

“Priority will be given to queries pertaining to the city's development. Citizens should raise questions of public concern," he added.

Title: Delhi elections 2020: Parties look to seal win with 'Look-East policy'
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Poorvanchalis Manoj Tiwari, Kirti Azad and Sanjay Singh have been entrusted with the task of spearheading the ... Read More

NEW DELHI: The distribution of party tickets for the assembly elections has been marked by an unprecedented bow to the influence of the Poorvanchali population by all three major parties.

Bihar-based parties, Rashtriya Janata Dal and Janata Dal (United), are beneficiaries of this politics, with Congress allotting four seats to the former and BJP setting aside two for the latter. Congress and BJP, playing catch-up with Aam Aadmi Party, are mindful of the fact that chief minister Arvind Kejriwal’s party enjoys considerable support among the Poorvanchalis, who make up, according to varying estimates, around a third of the electorate.

Complete Coverage on Delhi Elections

There are projections that at least 25 of the 70 assembly seats in the capital can be swung by the Poorvanchali voters, that is, people who have migrated from Bihar and eastern UP and settled in Delhi. AAP has wooed the community with a slew of benefits and, in the seat allotments too, given it ample representation — 12 seats, to be precise (the same as in the previous assembly election).

For the 2020 polls, AAP has fielded Vinay Mishra, son of Delhi Congress’ Poorvanchali face Mahabal Mishra, from Dwarka where the party dropped its sitting MLA, Adarsh Shastri, who has now been fielded by Congress from the area. In Timarpur, it has dropped sitting MLA Pankaj Pushkar in favour of Dilip Pandey. And while the party has snubbed 15 MLAs from the previous winning team, only one of them — Shastri — is from Poorvanchali background.

While replacing its former Delhi Cantonment MLA, Karan Singh Tanwar, BJP, too, has gone for the chief of its Poorvanchali wing, Manish Singh. It has fielded Kaushal Mishra from Seelampur from where Sanjay Jain contested in 2015 .

Congress has picked Poonam Jha Azad, wife of campaign committee chairman Kirti Azad, for Sangam Vihar. Another Poorvanchali, Pradeep Pandey, will fight for Rithala seat on a Congress’ ticket.

Delhi’s demographics have changed dramatically in the last few decades. In the search of greener pastures, many people left their homes in Bihar and Uttar Pradesh and settled in the economically promising capital, mostly in the trans-Yamuna areas falling under the East Delhi and North East Delhi Lok Sabha constituencies. Over the years, their base has spread to localities in West Delhi and South West Delhi segments too.

BJP was the first to acknowledge the emergence of this powerful voting block when in 1993, it propped up Lal Bihari Tiwari as its party candidate for the assembly polls. Tiwari went on to win the East Delhi parliamentary seat thrice, the first time in a bypoll in 1997. But the saffron party failed to build on its first-mover’s advantage because of resistance from the firmly entrenched Punjabi and Vaishya groups.

Congress was relatively slower off the blocks. Brought into the picture late, Mahabal Mishra, its Poorvanchali face, used his “extra-organisational” intervention to secure the West Delhi seat for Congress in 2009.

The failure of the established players in 2015 state polls, however, helped Kejriwal run away with the loose ball as AAP won 67 of the 70 assembly seats. All 12 of its Poorvanchali candidates were triumphant.

While the Poorvanchali community includes people from different castes and religions, their roots unite them in their adopted land. A large number of them belong to the working class and live in unauthorised colonies. Predicting their voting behaviour is risky, say analysts, but a majority of them have common election issues.

Congress has also appointed Kirti Azad, who has served as a three-term MP from Bihar’s Darbhanga, as the chief of its campaign committee. AAP’s Sanjay Singh, a Rajya Sabha member, who hails from Sultanpur district of UP, is the campaign committee chief of AAP.

BJP named its biggest Poorvanchali face, Bhojpuri star Manoj Tiwari, as the chief of its Delhi unit in November 2016, months before the city voted in the municipal election. Despite a strong anti-incumbency factor, BJP retained all the three corporations comfortably. The party, which is yet to announce its CM’s face, is contesting the assembly polls “under the leadership” of Tiwari, in a clear bid to woo the “Eastenders”.

The changed stance of the political players reflects the self-confidence of the community, which until a decade ago, was not so assertive and, in fact, was frequently derided by society at large. Today, the community’s cultural festivals are celebrated in a grand manner as politicians try to win them over to their side.

Title: Goa: 'Government no longer accountable to people'
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Vijai Sardesai

PORVORIM: The move to blackmail PWD minister Deepak Pauskar has given the opposition fresh ammunition to embarrass the government, with Goa Forward Party president Vijai Sardesai suggesting that citizens had stopped taking the state government seriously.

Addressing reporters outside the legislative assembly, Sardesai said the government, buoyed by its majority, had stopped being accountable to people. “When someone is extorting the minister…you have guys come here and being welcomed as ministers. There are policemen being beaten up by people. All these things have happened just in this month itself. One MLA, that too a lady, is being abused, and called Portuguese, and the ruling party doesn’t say anything about it,” said Sardesai.

He also hinted that BJP MLAs had links with the drug syndicate in the state, which would explain why the government was shying away from questions linked to the death of three youth at the Sunburn Klassique music festival last month. “Three people die at Sunburn, and then a question on the drug menace goes missing. Is that not a link? I was not on Micky Pacheco’s committee, otherwise I would have said that this is a political-drug mafia nexus. The needle of suspicion points towards that nexus,” said Sardesai.

He also said the government, from the MLAs to municipal councils, had ceased to be accountable for utilisation of taxpayers’ money and policy decisions. Recent statements made by the ruling side that the Margao outline development plan (ODP) would be reworked, showed that the BJP had scant respect for norms, he said.

“I don’t know if the Town and Country Planning Act, allows for the ODP to be reviewed after notification. The government has to go by the act. The government can come out with a modification or amendment to the act, if it wants to ‘re-work’ it” said Sardesai.

Title: Education directors’ Monday presence in office now a must
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

PUNE: State education commissioner Vishal Solanki has instructed all senior officials in the department to be present in their respective offices every Monday to hear the visitors’ concerns.

Solanki’s instruction comes in the wake of several instances of visitors directly approaching the commissioner with their grievances after not finding the education directors and other senior officials in their offices.

The commissioner said he has received several complaints from visitors, parents, representatives from various institutes and also students about the “perennial absence” of the senior education officials. “We have now instructed the officers to ensure their availability in office on Mondays. No visitor should go back without their queries being solved,” Solanki said.

Kuldeep Ambekar, president of Student Helping Hand, an association of pupils, said, “Instances of the visitors being told by the junior officers in the department that a director is out for some meeting, inspection and programme are common. All education offices receive visitors since morning till 5pm every day.”

The visitors have taken up with Solanki instances about officers not meeting them or not being found in seat. Many of the visitors reach Solanki’s office after failing to get answers to their respective queries. “The visitors’ issues need to be resolved on a priority basis. If any officer has to attend an important meeting or a programme, he or she has to take prior permission,” Solanki said.

Besides the education commissioner’s office, Pune has state headquarters of the primary education, secondary education, Maharashtra State Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education, Maharashtra State Council of Examination, Maharashtra State Council of Education Research and Training, Maharashtra State Textbook Bureau (Balbharati) and the directorate of Minority and Adult Education departments, among others.

Title: International Baccalaureate pupils set up model Lok Sabha, UN committees
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

PUNE: A model Lok Sabha discussed social topics such as dowry and illicit human-trafficking , whereas the United Nations Committee for Scientific and Technological Development, modelled on the UN committee, discussed how artificial intelligence was proving to be a threat to cyber security, among others, at 'Unearthing Reality' — a two-day conference held in the city over the weekend.

The conference, titled 'Unearthing Reality', was organized and hosted by Victorious Kidss Educares (VKE) at Kharadi.

Students, from 12 International Baccalaureate (IB) schools and also those affiliated to other boards in the city, discussed global and national issues at this Model United Nations (MUN) conference held in the city. The president of VKE, Robbin Ghosh said, over 80 participants deliberated, discussed, disputed and debated over problems that the world faces today, such as, money laundering, drug trafficking and crypto currency as mediums of terrorist financing.

MIT Gurukul IB School, St. Anne’s School, PICT Model School, Orchid School and Lexicon International School, among others, participated.

Title: Plenty of unfinished biz, who’ll stitch a win in Gandhi Nagar?
Content:
The constituency hasn’t had an MLA after Anil Kumar Bajpai, elected in 2015 as an Aam Aadmi Party nominee join... Read More

NEW DELHI: The voters of Gandhi Nagar assembly constituency in east Delhi have some complaints , but don’t have someone they can pin the blame on. For eight months, the constituency hasn’t had an MLA after Anil Kumar Bajpai, elected in 2015 as an Aam Aadmi Party nominee, joined BJP ahead of general elections last year and was disqualified under the anti-defection law.The constituency is known for being home to the biggest readymade garments wholesale market and has an interesting mix of Muslim, Sikh and Hindu communities. For 17 years it remained a Congress domain until Bajpai wrested it in 2015. The constituents claimed that development projects in the area began after AAP assumed power, but all work was put on hold after the MLA joined BJP.Complete Coverage on Delhi ElectionsRavinder Singh Chachhi, a resident of West Azad Nagar, said that Gandhi Nagar was identified as the first places in east Delhi for the installation of CCTV cameras. “Around 60 points were identified for the cameras. Construction of roads was also supposed to start. But we are clueless about the status of these projects,” said Chachhi. “We approached the MLA of neighbouring Krishna Nagar for help but to no avail.” Revamp of the ageing sewerage was among the other projects announced but not implemented, said Chachhi.Bajpai himself claimed to be the first legislator in Delhi to utilise Rs 11 crore of MLA local area development funds in 2019-20 for development work in his constituency. “I not only arranged took up drains and road reconstruction, but also development of parks. We identified 2,872 places for CCTV installation and 29 Wi-Fi hubs, but these were put on hold when I shifted to BJP,” said the former MLA.Last Tuesday, TOI saw road construction under way in various places, including Jheel Chowk and Azad Nagar. But also visible were massive encroachments on the roads, poor sanitation and unregulated traffic. Despite the Supreme Court’s explicit directions regarding the loading and unloading of merchandise during non-peak hours, there were goods vehicles and tempos parked outside Gandhi Nagar shops in the afternoon. To add to the chaos, shop owners had taken over large spaces on roads to display their wares.“We are fed up of the encroachment on roads. It has multiplied in the past five years,” said Shankar Nagar resident Kamal Bhasin. He also said that in the run-up to assembly polls, road work had been taken up in his locality. “But a lot of it is a waste of money because in some places just repairs could have sufficed. The money could have been better utilised on improving sanitation,” said Bhasin.People living in West Azad Nagar listed water supply and sewage among their woes. “Entire Azad Nagar gets poor-quality water and we are forced to use bottled water,” grumbled Pankaj Akhil. “The residents complained to the former MLA a number of times. And though officials visited our area after the complaints, the quality of water did not improve.”In the trader community, there is an undertone of surliness against the sealing of shops for violation of norms. “We are mostly supporters of BJP, but the party and its leaders have tried to distance themselves from the issue by blaming the AAP government for not amending the Master Plan Delhi. People aren’t convinced and may express their disappointment during the voting,” confided a Gandhi Nagar trader.In Old and New Seelampur, dominated by the Muslim community, the ruling party gets a thumbs up. “AAP is doing its best to help poor people through rebates in power and electricity bills. Sanitation isn’t good, but that is the responsibility of MCD,” said Anees Rehman in Old Seelampur.

Title: CM Pramod Sawant meets secretaries for budget inputs
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Goa CM Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: Chief minister Pramod Sawant on Thursday held a pre-budget meeting with the chief secretary and secretaries of state and directed them to come up with development programmes.

The meeting was also attended by police officers, Indian forest service and officials of the state government. Sawant told TOI that the meeting was called to plan development programmes for the coming financial year. “I am doing a budgetary exercise. I have held meetings with MLAs, ministers and will have meetings with industries and stakeholders, heads of corporations, etc. The budget preparation has to be done properly,” he said.

Sawant said he is taking inputs from every department about its schemes, how much it has been implemented and whether it needs to be revised. “I have alerted all departments about the budget,” he said.

He added that he has asked secretaries to check how many central schemes have been implemented in the state and how many have benefitted. Sawant asked secretaries to give ministers inputs in planning new schemes. He also asked secretaries to give suggestions department-wise.

On Wednesday, Sawant had held a meeting with BJP MLAs and cabinet ministers to discuss inputs for the state budget.

Title: Man intrudes into nurses’ dressing room in govt hosp
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Tirupur: An unidentified man was found in the dressing room of nurses at the Udumalpet government hospital here on Wednesday night.

While the medical staff, along with security personnel, had caught him and brought him out of the dressing room, he managed to escape.

Nurses and paramedical staff of the hospital staged a protest on Thursday, demanding stern action against the man who intruded into their dressing room. More than 80 nurses are working with the Udumalpet government hospital.

Seeking his arrest, they said the miscreant wouldn’t have entered their dressing room if there was enough security apparatus. Murugan, chief medical officer, Udumalpet government hospital, talked to the protesters and promised to take appropriate action in the issue. He said the hospital administration would try to identify the culprit with the help of CCTV cameras installed on its premises. “We will also lodge a police compliant,” he said.

Title: Jaipur: More cameras to enhance traffic surveillance system
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

File pic of a traffic control room with real-time updates in the city

JAIPUR: With a cost of Rs 6.6 crore, the city traffic police are preparing an “integrated traffic management system (ITMS)”, a technology-based system that will automatically detect traffic violations such as speeding with the use of traffic surveillance cameras, automatic number plate recognition (ANPR) cameras among others, to improve mobility, discipline and safety on city roads.

According to the proposal, Jaipur police will identify 11 places in the city where the system will be installed. It will generate e-challans.

The police said that the upcoming system should be designed in such a manner so that it should have an option of integration with the existing ITMS/ANPR infrastructure present with the Jaipur traffic police , so that the whole system might function under single command and control structure.

In 2019, the existing ITMS helped the traffic police in issuing notices to 52,994 traffic rule violators and in collecting Rs 1.22 crore as penalty from them. For the purpose, the Jaipur police commissionerate on Tuesday invited expression of interest from eligible agencies for the proposals to provide design, development and commissioning of ANPR (ITMS) system at 11 entry and exit points in Jaipur city. The estimated cost of the project is Rs 6.6 crore.

According to the officials, the objective of the project is to perform ANPR on all the vehicles passing through the chosen 11 entry and exit points of the city and generation of alerts based on ANPR. Also, it will detect speed violation and other traffic violations. If someone would be found violating the traffic rules under the technology-based system, it will automatically generate e-challans for the violations. It will also provide a web-based interface so that owners and drivers will be able to check if they have a pending violation on their vehicle and pay the amount of penalty accordingly.

The system will also provide video feed to command and control centre. The system will be designed to work round the clock and it will be able to capture the number plate in night with the help of IR illuminator against the head light glare of the approaching vehicle.

Title: 1,000kg marijuana seized in Jaipur
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: In one of the biggest drives against narcotics, city police seized 1,000 kg of marijuana worth around Rs 2 crore which was being transported in a mini truck and arrested five persons. All the arrests were made on Tuesday. While two — Chandan Kumar and Munnu Kumar Yadav — were held for transporting the narcotics, three persons, all residents of Nagaur, were picked up as they were supposed to receive the consignment.

Additional commissioner (crime) Ashok Gupta said the accused had a deal of selling it for Rs 40 lakh to their clients.

Police came to know that the accused were getting supplies from Manipur, Bengal and Odisha. While carrying out investigations, police found that Tulsi Ram, Om Prakash and Subhash Meena, all residents of Nagaur, were involved in supplying drugs in Jaipur and western Rajasthan. Following a tip-off that the drug smugglers were planning to supply marijuana in Nagaur, the Criminal Intelligence Unit (CIU) teams on Tuesday kept a close eye on toll plazas on Agra-Jaipur highway.

They also kept tabs on vehicles on highways in Dausa, Manoharpura, Kaithun, Bagru and Sikar road. Finally, the police managed to arrest Kumar and Munnu, residents of Kaimganj in UP and Buxar in Bihar, respectively.
