Title: Now, test Sanchi milk purity at Dugdh Sangh premises
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Dugdha Sangh premises

BHOPAL: The Bhopal Dugdh Sangh (Bhopal Milk Federation) has decided to allow its consumers to test purity of the Sanchi brand of milk on its premises itself. Divisional commissioner Kalpana Shrivastava has directed chief executive officer Dr K K Saxena to arrange on-the-spot testing of milk on Sanchi plant premises for consumers.

She said that the public awareness programme has already been undertaken by the federation under which consumers are being motivated to test quality of milk at their home itself under the campaign “Khud Parkho Khud Jano” (Test it yourself, know the quality yourself).

Under the campaign, a “Sanchi chariot” is visiting different places of the city to create awareness on how purity of milk and milk products can be tested by consumers themselves. Bhopal Dugdh Sangh has also issued a phone no. for people to register their complaint if they receive substandard/adulterated milk. The phone number is (0755)- 2481995.

The chariot will remain on city roads till January 31. It will visit Karond chowk on January 24, Bairagarh township on January 25, Lal Ghati area on January 27, Jehangirabad on January 29 and Sindhi Colony on January 30. The Dugdh Sangh personnel will interact with people and test the quality of milk brought by them, so that credibility of Sanchi brand could be enhanced.

Shrivastava, who was presiding over a review meeting on steps being taken by Bhopal Dugdh Sangh to ensure supply of quality milk to consumers, said that tallying the quality report of milk which reaches the plant with that of the report taken at the milk chilling plants (from where it is sent to Bhopal) has reduced the possibility of its adulteration to zero.

The divisional commissioner, however, cautioned Dr Saxena that strict quality control should be a continuous process and no leniency should be allowed to creep in the task and any employee/officer involved in activities detrimental to the prestige of Sanchi brand should not be spared.

She said that dues of those supplying milk to Bhopal Dugdh Sangh should be cleared every week rather than 20 days and vehicles engaged in milk distribution should not be allowed inside the premises without proper washing and cleaning. Quality and any possible adulteration in milk should be tested from all the tankers arriving at the plant till 10 pm.

Besides, the federation’s step like formation of 10 mobile teams, which is visiting places adjacent to Bhopal to enhance the collection of milk, bid to revive the milk committees which have become defunct, forming new committees and motivating people to rear milk-giving cattle are also bearing encouraging results, she said.

Title: Demolition of Tirupur flower market begins
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Tirupur: Amidst protest from a section of vendors, the city corporation on Thursday began demolition of Tirupur flower market on Eswaran Koil Street near the old bus stand.

The market is being demolished to construct a new one at a cost of Rs 4.47 crore under the smart city mission. A city corporation official said, “The new complex is likely to be ready in 11 months from the date of commencement of work.”

He said the demolition drive was carried out with police protection as they were facing opposition from a section of venders, who had been seeking an assurance on allocation of shops in the new complex. “We sought police protection to avoid any untoward incident. Shops would be allotted only based on tender process.”

The market was started around 90 years ago. There were 98 shops in the market and they were engaged in both wholesale and retail businesses. The official said the flower market was included in the smart city mission with an idea to redevelop the same. “We had allotted the vendors temporary shops in Cotton market complex on Palladam Road. Fearing that they would lose their shops, the vendors, however, started to oppose the project.”

The official said priority would be given to the existing vendors, but allotment of shops would only be done through tender process. The vendors, however, said the temporary flower market complex was filled with sewage.

Title: Infant dies as she falls into bucket filled with water
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPUR: A 15-month old baby girl died on Wednesday after she accidentally fell into a bucket that was filled with water at Angeripalayam in the city.

The Anupparpalayam police identified the deceased as Kanishka, daughter of S Kannan-Pandiyammal couple, of Avinashigoundampalayam . At the time of the incident, a police officer said, Kannan had left for his work and only Pandiyammal and the baby girl were in the house. Kannan is employed with a knitwear unit.

“Pandiyammal was cooking inside, while Kanishka was playing in front of the house, where they had stored water in many plastic vessels. When the girl couldn’t be seen, her mother came out of the house and found her struggling for life in a bucket full of water,” the officer said.

The baby girl was immediately taken to a nearby hospital, where doctors declared her brought dead. The Anupparpalayam police have registered the case under Section 174 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC).

Since the deceased was an infant, police gave the family a no objection certificate, so that there was no need to conduct postmortem.

Title: Pay me Rs 2L/month, I’ll fix railway systems, scamster tells RPF
Content:
File photo for representation purpose only

NEW DELHI: In an interesting twist to the multi-crore rail e-ticketing racket , its mastermind has reached out to the Railway Police Force (RPF) chief claiming “huge gaps” in the transport behemoth’s IT security system.The main accused, Hamid Ashraf, who is in Dubai, has claimed that nabbing him or some people won’t put an end to such rackets as others can develop similar ‘illegal’ software and use them by taking advantage of the security loopholes in the IRCTC ’s system.RPF is working on a strategy to catch Ashraf, after the recent arrest of another key player in this racket Ghulam Mustafa. Ashraf had fled the country after jumping bail in 2016. He was arrested in a similar rail e-ticketing fraud when he was in Class XII.In a series of WhatsApp broadcasts, Ashraf claimed that he had repeatedly flagged loopholes in the IT security system developed by government-owned Centre for Railway Information Systems (CRIS), which IRCTC uses for ticketing. “The agencies did not take measures to plug the loopholes and so how can you hold me responsible? People did not pay heed to the details I had shared with them; all of them thought I was mad,” he said in the text messages addressed to RPF director general Arun Kumar.From the messages, it appeared that Ashraf reached out to RPF DG after his press conference where he said that the money was suspected to be used for terror financing . “If you give interviews to TV channels like this, no one will marry me,” he said.Pointing out that the government agencies were unable to fix “such a security issue” even after he shared details through “more than 500 emails and WhatApp messages”, he said this had raised serious questions about their ability to deal with critical cyber security issues.“We are concerned about any lapses that can be exploited by criminals and anti-national elements. We have been flagging this issue and have urged the departments concerned to take measures,” an official said.In his messages, Ashraf, who is believed to have been trained by an IT expert, has offered help to the railways, IRCTC and CRIS to secure the system. “Give me a chance, I will secure the IRCTC system and CRIS. Arresting me won’t help as there will be 10 more to come out with such software... I am not guilty or wrong so I am posting these details,” he said. The accused even went to the extent of saying that the railways can hire him at Rs 2 lakh monthly salary as an ‘ethical’ hacker as IT giants do.Claiming that he has deactivated and withdrawn the illegal software that he had sold to many, he said, “I want this tension to end so that I can enjoy my life with my girlfriend…Sir, please bachha ko maaf kardijiye. Life mein dubara railways ke software nehin banaoonga. (Please excuse me for this. I will never develop any such software for railways).”The accused listed out several steps that the railways, IRCTC and CRIS could take to ensure that none can bypass IT security system.“You allow two tickets in a day per IP address. Similarly why don’t you fix only one IRCTC ID that can be logged on to the system per IP address. People log into the system with 50 IRCTC IDs generated from one IP address and until you address this, common people will keep suffering,” Ashraf said.On in the issue of bypassing of Captcha and OTP, he claimed that he had sent the details about the bug used for this to banks and IRCTC.

Title: Odisha begins process to acquire 3k acres of land for Haldia Petrochemicals
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Within six months of the Naveen Patnaik-led high-level clearance authority clearing Haldia Petrochemicals Limited’s (HPL) proposal to set up a petrochemical complex in Odisha, the state government has began the process of acquiring 3320.21 acres of land in Baliapal block of Balasore district for the same. Odisha Industrial Infrastructure Development Corporation (Idco) was given the nod to acquire land during a meeting in the last week of December.

Once complete, the Rs 78,225 crore project is expected to generate employment for around 10,000 people. HPL would set up a hydrocarbon processing complex comprising a light crude oil refinery, aromatics complex and ethylene cracker units.

It was during the second Make in Odisha conclave in November 2018 that the West Bengal-headquartered HPL had initially expressed its intent to invest in the state. The company had made the biggest greenfield investment intent during the business summit.

Official sources said land for HPL and downstream industries has been identified close to the proposed Subarnarekha Port developed by Tata Steel with an investment of around Rs 5,000 crore. Odisha Space Application Centre has helped in identifying land with the help of the advanced differential global positioning system.

“We will soon start the process of acquiring land with the revenue reconciliation exercise. Subsequently, public hearing will be held before land is acquired,” said a senior Idco official. It is learnt that Idco has been told to complete the land acquiring process within 12 to 18 months.

The government is looking to tread cautiously on the contentious issue of acquiring land given that it had faced severe opposition in the past. A mega steel project by South Korean company Posco had failed to take off owing to land hurdle, damaging the state’s attempt to project an investment-friendly image.

Of the 3320 acres identified for the project, around 900 acres belong to private property with 700 acres falling under forest land. It also has 800 acres of government land, around 300 acres of Bhoodan land and other categories of land. As many as six revenue villages could be affected because of the land acquisition process, sources said.

Bhoodan land is land acquired by way of donation under the Bhoodan movement initiated by Acharya Vinobha Bhabe. Under the Orissa Bhoodan and Gramdan Act, 1970, such land can be used for landless people or for a community purpose.

Under forest conservation law, forest land can be diverted for industrial projects by paying the net present value of the land (rate depends on density of forest) for compensatory afforestation. Government authorities hope there would not be much of a hurdle in this regard given that the patch of land chosen has no eco-sensitive zone or sanctuary.

“After diversion of forest land, the project proponent will seek necessary forest and environmental clearances to set up industrial unit over the land,” said an Idco official.

To acquire private land, a mandatory social impact assessment would be done. As part of the assessment, public hearings would be held in affected villages. The government hopes the villagers would be favourable disposed towards the industry as they will be duly compensated.

State industries department sources said the petrochemical complex has huge potential for creating downstream industries with enormous employment opportunities. Odisha at present has Indian Oil Corporation Ltd’s 15 mtpa (million tonnes per annum) oil refinery at Paradip while its expansion to 25 mtpa has already been approved. To seek investment in chemicals, petrochemicals and plastics sectors, a petroleum chemicals and petrochemicals investment region is also being developed near the IOCL plant.

EoM

Title: Festival to shine light on struggles of blind people
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The Muzzgamchem Fest will be held on February 2

PANAJI: Come February 2, the premises of the National Association for the Blind (NAB) will host a unique community festival, the Muzzgamchem Fest.

The event aims at highlighting the struggles faced by the blind and those with limited sight. The organisers also want to educated people about the work done by NAB.

Interestingly, in the run-up to the festival, NAB will host an array of workshops for the public, including handicrafts prepared by the blind, at its premises at Santa Cruz from January 27 to February 1, from 10am to 12.30pm.

“All learnings from the workshops, right from playing of the traditional ghumot to food and handicrafts will then be presented at the festival,” said Marius Fernandes, who initiated the concept of community-organised festivals in Goa 20 years ago.

On the festival day, the opening event will be the Muzzgamchim Pasoi (walk), which will start at 11am, from the Santa Cruz church. “Santa Cruz-based historian Sanjeev Sardesai will take participants across four historic landmarks in the village and narrate the history of each one,” Fernandes said. Those participating in the walk are requested to come with one musical instrument each. “After the heritage walk, we will play music and lead the procession to the NAB premises, where the Muzzgamchem Fest will start at 11.45am,” he said.

At the festival premises, participants will be treated to performances by troupes from Kala Academy’s theatre department, students of two special schools, Lokvishwas Prathisthan and Sanjay School, and students of Goa College of Art.

An added attraction will be a ‘Make in Santa Cruz’ market. “Vegetables and fruits grown by Santa Cruz locals and salt from the village salt pans will be sold there. There will be live demonstrations by locals on how to prepare traditional sweets. Like the other community festivals, there will be no sponsors, no chief guest and no alcohol, to help keep it a community and traditional affair,” NAB’s Richard Pinto said. A skills workshop on how to pluck coconuts using a machine invented by a local will also be conducted for interested participants.

“The Goa branch of NAB was started in 1983 and the Santa Cruz centre is operating from the premises of a government primary school building provided to us by the state government. We started boarding facilities here 10 years ago. The children go to the local Santa Cruz High School and some of our older students study at Dhempe College. The children are tutored by trained teachers. They return to their homes during the vacations. We want people to come and see that these children can do anything that you and I can. They have even been trained to travel on their own by public transport to college,” NAB president Rozendo Mendonsa said.

Title: Everything falls in line for integrated bus stand at Vellalore
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The work on integrated bus stand at Vellalore is all set to begin on Friday. While the state government had announced the project almost six years ago, it was only recently that the city corporation issued work order to the successful bidder.

A source with the city corporation said, “Three bidders had participated in the tender process and the project was awarded to Erode-based P&C Projects (P) Ltd. The work order was issued to the firm on Monday and it is expected to start the construction work tomorrow (Friday).”

According to the source, the project would cost Rs 164.81 crore and the construction would be completed in 24 months from the date of commencement of work.

While 60 acres have been allotted for the project, close to 30 acres would be used to park buses. “We are planning to move the mofussil bus stands at Ukkadam, Gandhipuram and Singanallur, and the omni bus stand at Gandhipuram to Vellalore.”

The new bus stand will have a capacity to park a total of 140 mofussil buses at any given time. In addition to this, there will be close to 33 platforms to park town buses.

“It will also house a parking facility with a capacity to accommodate thousand vehicles and multi-storeyed buildings with eateries, ATMs, information centre, restrooms, office space and shops. The buildings would be rented out to make the bus stand self-sufficient,” the source said.

He said they would conduct yet another study before the completion of construction work to take effective measures to reduce traffic congestion in the city.

Shortly after the project was announced by the former chief minister the late J Jayalalithaa in 2014, the civic body had conducted a feasibility study and prepared a detailed project report. While the project was later included under the area-based development component of the smart city mission, the urban development ministry refused to grant approval for the same. The project was then handed over to the National Highways wing of the state highways department.

As the highways department was conducting the pre-feasibility study, chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami announced in the assembly plans to construct the integrated bus stand in the city to manage the increasing traffic congestion. Subsequently, the highways department dropped the project and the city corporation took it under its wing.

Title: New snake eel species named after ZSI head
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Berhampur: Director of Zoological Survey of India (ZSI), Kailash Chandra, has received the ultimate honour of animal taxonomists — he has had a new species named after him.

The latest entrant to the fish world is a new species of snake eel, which has been called Ophichthus kailashchandrai sp. nov. to honour Chandra’s contribution to animal taxonomy.

The term ‘sp. nov.’ or ‘species nova’ is used when a binomial name is being published for the first time.

The new kind of snake eel was discovered by scientists of the Estuarine Biology Regional Centre in Ganjam’s Gopalpur-on-Sea in the Shankarpur fishing harbour in West Bengal. “At least three specimens were collected from the Bay of Bengal around five years ago. The findings stating the discovery of the new species were published in peer-reviewed international journal, Zootaxa, in January,” said Anil Mohapatra of the Estuarine Biology Regional Centre, one of the four authors of the article.

“We have been examining the three specimens for a long time, and after comparing them with their congeners (species within the same genus), we were able to establish this as a new species,” he explained.

The ZSI director said he was thrilled to have a fish named after him, particularly as it is very difficult to discover new fishes in the Bay of Bengal.

“First of all, I thank Mohapatra and his team for naming the new fish species after me. It’s very difficult to discover fish species from the vast Bay of Bengal,” Chandra said over phone from Kolkata, where the ZSI is headquartered. “It would have been even better if the species was named after fish scientists who have dedicated their lives to the science,” he added.

The Ophichthus kailashchandrai sp. nov. is distinguished from its congeners by having its dorsal-fin origin at the posterior third of the pectoral fin, preanal length of 2.6-2.8 in TL (Total Length — length of a fish measured from the tip of the snout to the tip of the longer lobe of the caudal fin), uniserial maxillary and mandibular teeth and vertebral count (predorsal vertebrae 14–15, preanal vertebrae 54–55, and total vertebrae 180–182).

The snake eel species varies from 420mm to 462mm in length, and the specimens were collected from the harbour at a depth of around 50metre using trawl nets. The colour of the new eel is light brown while its eye rim is white. The head pores are located within the white rims. The ZSI scientists, however, said there was a lot still to be discovered about the species.

The other authors of the article are Dipanjan Ray of Bajkul Milani Mahavidyalaya, Purba Medinapur, West Bengal, Swarup Ranjan Mohanty of the Estuarine Biology Regional Centre, and Subhendu Sekhar Mishra of Marine Fish Section, ZSI, Kolkata.

This is the fifth eel species discovered by scientists of the Estuarine Biology Regional Centre in the past three years. The others are Gymnothorax odishi, Ophichthus johnmccoskeri, Gymnothorax andamanensis and Gymnothorax smithi.

Title: Centre approves national school of planning, architecture at a cost of Rs 338 cr for Puducherry
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Puducherry: The Union human resource development ministry has approved setting up of a National school of planning and architecture ( SPA ) at a cost of Rs 338 crore in Puducherry, said agriculture minister R Kamalakannan, who also holds the portfolio of education.

Speaking to the media in the presence of secretary (education) A Anbarasu and director (school education) P T Rudra Goud, Kamalakannan said the government will initiate efforts to demarcate 50 acres of land on Pondicherry University campus for the school. He said the school, which is a premier higher education institution like National Institute of Technology and Jipmer, would specialise in education and research in the fields of planning and architecture. Presently SPAs are located in Delhi, Bhopal and Vijayawada. Puducherry will be the fourth centre with an SPA, he said.

He said the government has also launched efforts to establish a National Institute of Fashion Technology in 2020-21. Preliminary work for the project has been completed and the government will soon finalise the site for the project.

Similarly, the government proposes to set up a National Institute of Electronics and Information Technology (NIELIT) at Women’s Polytechnic College and Pondicherry Engineering College (PEC).

A committee from the institute inspected the site at the polytechnic college and PEC on December 3 last year.

He said the government has established a branch of central footwear training institute at Karaikal in September last year. Three batches of students have completed certificate and skill development courses in footwear manufacturing at the centre so far. The students, who could not clear Class X and even dropouts can join the courses offered by the centre. All courses are free of cost, said the minister. He said the government will establish Puducherry technological university, the first state university in the Union territory. The government passed a bill in this regard in September last year and sent it for approval of the President in October last. He said the government will get the approval soon.

Perunthalaivar Kamarajar Institute of Engineering and Technology in Karaikal will be promoted as a non-conventional multi-disciplinary institute and introduce new courses viz., agricultural engineering, aerospace engineering, marine engineering, petrochemical engineering and biomedical engineering in collaboration with other institutions.

The government has proposed to establish an engineering college at Yanam, which will offer innovative courses like robotics and automation, geo-informatics, 3D animation and graphics, digital techniques for design and planning and computing in multimedia among others.

Title: Chairman has no power to refer bills to panel: Buggana
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Amaravati: Finance and legislative affairs minister Buggana Rajendranath on Thursday blamed opposition TDP of hatching a conspiracy to stall the passage of the two key bills in the assembly. “The council chairman’s decision to refer the bills to a select committee was part of TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu’s conspiracy. The chairman has no such discretionary powers under Rule 154. In fact, proper procedure has not been followed to refer the bills to the select committee,” he alleged.

As per rules, government business should be prioritised, he said, adding that opposition leaders raised Rule 71 which is a special provision to discuss government policy and for the legislative council to give its opinion on it. “This rule was not in any state’s constitutional procedures but under some special circumstances a few years ago, Rule 71 was included in the AP legislative council,” added Buggana.

Naidu was present at the council gallery during discussion on the bills and was sitting quite opposite the council chairman while he was reading out the note, Buggana said. “The state government is spending close to Rs 60 crore annually on the council which amounts Rs 5 crore per month. The members are supposed to give suggestions, not block the government’s work. If the council is meant to block the government’s work, there is no meaning of having assembly sessions,” he added.

Municipal administration minister Botcha Satyanarayan said Wednesday was the “most disastrous day” in the history of state legislative council for the shameful conduct of TDP members. He rubbished the allegations of TDP members that the ministers were in an inebriated condition during the debate. “TDP is spreading such false news to cover up its unethical action in the council,” he alleged.

Agriculture minister Kurasala Kannababu too criticised the opposition leaders’ behaviour. “Yanamala Ramakrishnudu alleged that all ministers had come drunk to the council. A TDP MLC even asked for usage of breath analyser on the members while entering the assembly. This is nothing but breach of our privileges,” said Kannababu. He also requested the speaker to summon those who made derogatory comments against ministers and legislators and initiate action.

Title: Goa realises rules do not allow it to import bitumen
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

PANAJI: During the post-monsoon period in 2019, the state government came under severe criticism for the pathetic conditions of several road stretches, as citizens pointed out to the risk of fatalities it poses. In the face of this criticism, PWD minister Deepak Pauskar had said that the state government is planning to import bitumen from Iraq and Iran. Pauskar’s reasoning was that the bitumen — a byproduct of petroleum — available in these countries was of better quality and would help in making better roads.

But, PWD officials said that after Pauskar made the statement, he was informed that the proposal could not materialise as central government norms disallow the direct procurement of bitumen from other countries. The guidelines require that bitumen be imported through public sector undertakings like HPCL and BPCL.

“The minister was told that HPCL and BPCL already procure bitumen from the Gulf and that they have their own standard testing procedures to ensure consistency in quality. As such imported bitumen is proven to be of sufficiently good quality, the proposal does not stand,” a PWD official said.

Undertakings like HPCL and BPCL procure the raw material, manufacture bitumen and market it in various grades.

Title: MP Renukacharya: Anti-nationals should be shot
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Karnataka revenue minister R Ashoka

BENGALURU: After Honnalli legislator MP Renukacharya , Ballari City MLA Somashekara Reddy and deputy chief minister Govind Karjol, it appeared the turn of revenue minister R Ashoka to show the BJP in poor light with controversial and provocative comments against a minority community. This, despite a gag order issued by state BJP president Nalin Kumar Kateel.

Responding to questions on the Mangaluru International Airport bomb scare incident and how the main accused would have been treated had he been a Muslim, Ashoka on Thursday said "all anti-nationals must be shot dead". Meanwhile, Renukacharya, also a political secretary to chief minister BS Yediyurappa, continued his tirade against Muslims, insisting the government will not extend any "special package" to the community.

Soon after garlanding the statue of Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose on the birth anniversary of the freedom fighter, at Vidhana Soudha on Thursday, Ashoka said: "All those who are singing the tune of Pakistan and indulging in anti-national activities, be they Hindu, Christian or Muslim, must be shot dead."

Asked to respond to former chief minister HD Kumaraswamy’s accusation that the entire Mangaluru bomb incident was stage-managed by the BJP government to divert attention, Ashoka said the JD(S) functionary "must measure his words" and not speak "like a film director who can project the police as villainous all the time".

"Kumaraswamy is a former CM. When in power, police were his closest friends, but now that he is not in government, the same police are villains," Ashoka said.

The minister reiterated the government’s stand — first floated by home minister Basavaraj Bommai —

that Aditya Rao, the main accused in the Mangaluru bomb incident, is "mentally unstable" and needs to be medically examined.

Renukacharya, meanwhile, justified comments made on Wednesday that the government will not offer Muslims "a special package".

"When they [Muslims] need development funds, they come to us and seek special packages. Once they get funds, they then vote for Congress or JD(S) in elections," Renukacharya said on Thursday. "We do not need people with such double standards. I will apply pressure on all ministers in the cabinet and even the chief minister to ensure they do not allocate any special package for the community."

Title: Kolkata: Cross, letters stolen from Sonika Chauhan’s grave
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

A cross and brass letters from Sonika Chauhan’s grave have been stolen

KOLKATA: The grave of model Sonika Singh Chauhan , who died in an accident on Rashbehari Avenue early on April 29, 2017, when she was travelling in actor Vikram Chatterjee’s car, has suffered multiple incidents of desecration, the recent being last week.

The accused had removed brass letters and a cross from Chauhan’s grave around 1am on January 17, stated the complaint by A K Biswas, secretary of the office of the Christian Burial Board, which maintained the Lower Circular Road Cemetery .

Police are certain local drug-addicts had stolen the brass letters and cross to fund their daily fix. These drug-addicts had probably desecrated the grave even earlier, police said.

It was the gardener who first noticed the theft and alerted the security-in-chief, who in turn, called up different people, including Chauhan’s family. The relatives visited the spot. A case was registered at the Beniapukur police station under section 427 of IPC (mischief). “A complaint dated January 17 has been received from A K Biswas that unidentified persons desecrated the grave top of Chauhan by removing brass letters and cross,” an officer from the Beniapukur police station said.

The official complaint from the Christian Burial Board stated: “This is to inform you that the grave, which contains the mortal remains of Chauhan, located on the left side of second pathway, have been vandalized once again.” The complaint added that when the grave was earlier desecrated, the board had taken certain precautionary measures. “This is to assure you that we have intensified our patrolling with regular vigilance…,” stated the complaint, which went on to urge the police to introduce their own watch at the cemetery. “Please treat this intimation as FIR to arrest the culprit by organizing regular patrolling on day-to-day basis at this heritage cemetery,” the complaint said.

Police said they had already recorded the statements of the gardener and the security-in-chief.

Title: AP Capital News: High court posts Andhra Pradesh capital shifting cases to February 26
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Even as the legislative council referred the bill on shifting of the capital to the select committee, the high court on Thursday said it would hear all petitions connected to the issue on February 26.

The high court directed the state government to file counters in all matters within three weeks. While declining to give interim directions against shifting offices in the meanwhile, as urged by petitioners, the high court asserted that if the petitioners made out a case of such shifting, the government and individuals responsible would be made to pay for the expenditure incurred.

A special bench comprising Chief Justice J K Maheswari, Justice A V Sesha Sai and Justice M Satyanarayana Murthy was constituted to hear petitions challenging moving the capital. The court hall was jam-packed given the importance of the petitions. YSRC general secretary V Vijay Sai Reddy and TDP MP Kesineni Srinivas attended court.

Arguing on behalf of farmers, senior counsel Ashok Bhan raised the issue of the money bill and claimed its introduction was illegal as it violates provisions of Article 207 of the Constitution. Bhan argued that as the bill has special provisions of drawing funds from the consolidated fund, it had to be recommended by the governor of the state. But that did not happen in the case, making it illegal.

Contending the argument, designated senior counsel representing the government Mukul Rohatgi said the definition of money bill was clearly given in Article 199 (1) of the Constitution and the present bill does not come under Article 199 as it is not a taxation bill, but an infrastructure bill. He argued that the bill was introduced as an ordinary bill in both the Houses.

The chief justice suggested that as the bill had not been passed by the legislative council yet, it would not be appropriate to take up the hearing now. He asked the advocate general S Sriram about the status of the bill in the council.

Replying to the bench, the advocate general said the bill had been referred to a select committee by the chairman. According to the constitutional process, the select committee will revisit the contents of the bill and make suggestions or amendments if required. In case of amendments, the bill will be sent to the assembly again.

Continuing his arguments, Ashok Bhan said the state government should be pulled up for contempt of court for not giving farmers the opportunity to submit their grievances to the Capital Region Development Authority (CRDA) as directed by court, based on which the high power committee submitted a report to the government, following which the decision to shift the capital was taken.

As the chief justice suggested to take up the hearing after three weeks, Bhan requested the bench to give interim directions not to shift any office in the meanwhile. He said oral directions are being given to the officers to shift their offices. However, the chief justice did not consider his request, but said if the petitioners make out a case on it, the court will hold the government and individuals responsible for the expenditure incurred on such shifting.

Directing the advocate general to share copies of the expert committee report to all the petitioners, the high court posted all the matters connected to the capital issue to February 26 and asked the government to file counters within three weeks’ time.

Title: Mormugao joint mamlatdar gheraoed over voter list
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

VASCO: Members of the Goa Pradesh Congress Committee (GPCC) gheraoed Mormugao joint mamlatdar Saiesh Naik on Thursday afternoon over the deletion of names from the Mormugao constituency’s voter list . They alleged that workers and municipal councillors owing allegiance to urban development minister Milind Naik were acting as booth-level officers by identifying and submitting names of non-BJP voters.

The joint mamlatdar, who is in charge of the constituency, assured that he would re-enter the names of voters that had been deleted if they satisfied him with proper documents. The GPCC, however, threatened to approach the Election Commission if proper action was not initiated.

GPCC convener Amarnath Panjikar alleged that about 1,400 non-BJP voters were being deleted from the voter list of the Mormugao constituency and about 750 new names were being added.

The joint mamlatdar, however, said that only 900 names were deleted and 282 new names were added. “The names were deleted after objections were raised and procedure was followed,” he said.

Title: Naidu praises MLCs, council chairman
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Amaravati: TDP supremo Chandrababu Naidu while interacting with party functionaries via a teleconference on Thursday showered praises on his party MLCs for exhibiting ‘exemplary fighting spirit’ and said council chairman MA Shariff has championed the cause of Amaravati farmers.

Naidu said victory in the council has instilled public faith in democracy again. “In fact, it was the spirit of the people who have been on the streets for the past 37 days that made our resolve stronger and helped us emerge victorious,” said Naidu.

He said the council chairman did not take any side while referring the bills to the select committee but acted as per the rules. He criticised YSRC functionaries, including the ministers, for abusing Shariff. Naidu alleged that the ministers have only stopped short of attacking the council chairman. He also condemned the behaviour of the ministers who tried to attack his son and MLC Nara Lokesh.

Refuting the charges that he was doing injustice to Rayalaseema region, Naidu asked YSRC leaders to study the history to know about who has done what. He said that he was proud to say that he hails from Rayalaseema region and had worked overtime to transform the region into an industrial hub. “I have taken several measures to provide irrigation water to the region,” he said.

Title: Cocoon production goes up by 20% in five years
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Coimbatore: The demand for cocoon is still high, despite its production going up by 20% in the past five years in the district, according to the district sericulture centre.

On an average 1.5 tonnes of cocoon is auctioned daily at the government cocoon market in the city.

“About 20 to 25 farmers sell their cocoon at the market daily. At times, the production goes up to 3.5 tonnes a day. Yet, the demand for cocoon has not been met,” an official with the district sericulture centre said. In Coimbatore, cocoon is produced at Annur, Narasipuram and Thondamuthur.

Pointing out that the state government usually comes up with new targets every year to increase the production, the official said this year the production target has been increased to 400 tonnes and that the centre had already met 75% of target.

The entire silkworm rearing cycle is just 28 days and farmers could earn on monthly basis. But due to lack of awareness, the official said, many farmers were not taking up the rearing process. Even though the quantity of silk thread produced from bivoltine silk cocoons is lesser than that of crossbreed yellow cocoons, most farmers produce bivoltine cocoons because of their ability to reflect the colour after dyeing. About 700–900 metres of thread could be obtained from a cocoon and a kilogram of cocoon is sold for Rs 440 approximately, he added.

“Until a decade ago, farmers will have to rear the silkworms from the day 1 during which the worms are prone to diseases and survival rate was low. A certain temperature should be maintained, and it should be fed four times a day. The leaves should be shred properly. But, now the rearing process is not complicated at all,” the official sad.

With the introduction of Chokki Rearing Centres (CRC), where worms would be reared till it attains the stage 2 before handing it over to the farmers, the entire process has become simple, the official said, adding that the state government has, also, been giving subsidies for setting up of shed, plantation and installing drip irrigation.

Title: ‘Religious nationalism in Myanmar warning to others’
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Social and political development in neighbouring Myanmar and its impact on India were discussed at the fest. Journalist Suhasini Haider and author of a book on Myanmar, Thant Myint-U, talked about the rise of religious nationalism in the neighbouring country and growing influence of China in India.

When asked about the recent protest against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in India and religion-based politics, Thant gave the example of Myanmar.

He said recent violence against Rohingyas and rise of religious nationalism in their country should be considered as a warning for others as well. “I cannot comment on the Indian scenario, but can definitely say religious nationalism and isolation has further degraded the situation in his country,” said Thant.

Title: Naveen Patnaik announces new township for Cuttack, plan to decongest city
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Naveen Patnaik

BHUBANESWAR: Chief minister Naveen Patnaik on Thursday announced a development plan to decongest Cuttack city. The plan involves upgrading the existing ring road into a six-lane road and building a new township.

Naveen visited the land reclamation site on the occasion of Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose’s birth anniversary to review the development plan. State 5T secretary V K Pandian and works secretary Krishan Kumar briefed the chief minister.

The township has been proposed over 424 acres of land between Hadiapatha to Baliyatra ground on the Mahanadi river front in line with the existing Cuttack Development Authority (CDA) township.

“The reclamation of land from our lifeline Mahanadi has created a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to breath fresh life into the core of our ancient city. Every inch of the 424 acres will be utilized to add ecological, recreational, sporting, cultural, aspirational and technological value in the lives of the people of Cuttack,” Naveen said.

The chief minister said it will be the state government’s endeavour to prepare a decongestion plan for Cuttack with facilities like wider roads, better accessibility, public spaces, utilities, parks, modern urban infrastructure, parking and greenery.

The new township will be surrounded by a world-class river front. The state government plans to spend around Rs 1500 crore for the purpose.

The government will engage an international-standard city planner to prepare the plan. The government will also seek suggestions from the people before preparing the final plan, an official source said.

State urban development minister Pratap Jena said with the increase in population there is a need to create a new township with facilities like residential areas, space for official and commercial activities, convention hall, sports complex and tourism points. The 2011 census pegged the city’s population to around 6.01 lakh.

“The guidelines of the National Green Tribunal will be kept in mind while preparing the plan for the new city,” said a senior official.

EoM

Title: New bus stand unlikely to solve traffic woes: Activists
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

While the idea of integrated bus stand at Vellalore was conceived to reduce traffic congestion in the city by redirecting outstation buses to its periphery, activists and the public are doubtful of the project meeting its purpose.

K Kathirmathiyon, a member of road safety committee, said, “Developing infrastructure like access road is very important. The city corporation is yet to conduct a meeting with various stakeholders in this regard. If it focuses only on constructing the bus stand, it would have the same fate of the new bus stand at Mettupalayam which by and large remains unused.”

Citing the high court directions, he said the buses that ply to places within 55km radius of the city should be operated from Gandhipuram bus stand. “It means, buses to Tirupur, Mettupalayam, Pollachi and Sathyamangalam should be operated from Gandhipuram bus stand.”

Pointing out that the project was earlier proposed to be implemented by the National Highways wing of the state highways department, Kathirmathiyon also wondered whether the city corporation would be developing infrastructure that was mandated by the central government.

Devendran, a member of Coimbatore road safety association, said the new bus stand would cause a lot of inconvenience to the commuters. “At it is located on the outskirts of the city, traveling to the bus stand itself would be a tedious process.”

M Velankanni Raj, general secretary, Centre of Indian Trade Unions (CITU), said steps should be taken to reduce the traffic congestion in the present setup, instead of integrating all the bus stands at one place and causing inconvenience to the public. “Traffic congestion would only increase if the bus stand is moved to the outskirts of the city, as additional buses would be plied to ensure connectivity to the all the places from the bus stand. This would also affect the entire schedule of buses.”

Title: CAA ploy to divert attention from economic crisis: Arvind Kejriwal
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Kejriwal said if his party returned to power, his government would augment the primary, secondary and tertiary... Read More

NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal said on Thursday that if a visit to Shaheen Bagh by him could end the stir, he would have ended it in five minutes. When pointed out to him that people were suffering because of the road being blocked by protesters, the chief minister said that no inconvenience should be caused to people due to a protest, which, however, was everybody’s right.

Addressing a town hall with Times Now, Kejriwal accused the central government of bringing in the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) to divide people because it was unable to solve unemployment and economic crisis. “It is beyond my understanding that when the country is going through such a bad phase of economic downturn what the need to bring CAA was. If CAA and NRC are removed, people will return to their homes,” said the chief minister.

Complete Coverage on Delhi Elections

Asked whether he thought Hindus and Sikhs who escaped from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan and were staying in six different camps in the city should get citizenship, Kejriwal said for the sake of these six camps, the entire nation had been plunged in turmoil. When he was asked if the problems of millions of Hindus, Sikhs, Parsis and Christians were of no consequence to him, Kejriwal said he was bothered about the problems of millions of Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, Christians, Parsis and Muslims living in the capital.

Questioning the need for CAA, the CM said, “This has been done to divert attention from the issue of unemployment among members of these communities in the country... The uproar has been created because they do not have the guts to talk on economy and unemployment. This country is made of various religions and castes. Those who are trying to divide the country will never succeed. Better education, health, infrastructure, electricity and water — and not CAA and NRC — will take this country forward. People of this country are great, and they will not let divisions creep in.”

Kejriwal will be addressing several town halls till the end of the month. On Thursday, he elaborated on the work done by the Aam Aadmi Party government and the ‘Kejriwal Ki 10 Guarantee’ cards which are being distributed among people. In this card, Kejriwal has promised that all free public services being provided currently — free electricity up to 200 units, 20,000 litres of water per month and free bus ride for women — will continue for the next five years besides making other promises.

The CM apologised for the delay in some work like installation of CCTV cameras in buses. “In the past five years we have done a lot of work and the remaining work will be done in the next five years,” he said.

About his next plans for the next five years if his party returned to office, Kejriwal said his government will augment the primary, secondary and tertiary healthcare system. “More mohalla clinics and polyclinics will be built. Yamuna will be cleaned, and 11,000 buses will be procured,” he added.

Title: Goa government not sharing funds with CCP: Mayor
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The corporation has sought Rs 500 crore in funds

PANAJI: The Corporation of the City of Panaji has sought Rs 500 crore in grants from the 15th Finance Commission, which will be utilised for solid waste management , public transportation, environment protection and heritage conservation, said mayor Uday Madkaikar.

Madkaikar also informed the commission that the state government was not sharing any funds with local governing bodies.

“Earlier we used to get octroi. But with GST coming in, we have stopped getting octroi. In the last three years, we did not get a single rupee. We used to directly collect octroi from the fuel stations. But then the government took over that, saying they would give it to us. However, now that has also stopped. For the last three years, we have not received anything, and this is affecting us a lot,” said Madkaikar.

CCP had sought Rs 1,000 crore from the 14th Finance Commission, but received just Rs 15 crore. “We have asked a total of Rs 500 crore. They asked us why we want Rs 500 crore, and we showed them why we need that much money. The main thing is we need to clear Panaji’s garbage and we need to improve transportation. We also need money to develop a parking app,” he said.
