Title: Girl dies, parents accuse grandparents of murder
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Vijayawada: A 16-year-old girl, identified as Hema, died allegedly of high fever in Ibrahimpatnam on Thursday. A day after she was cremated, her father Likita Babu alias Krishna registered a complaint with the police accusing his parents Kunchala Sivaiah (65) and Tirupatamma (60) of killing Hema.

Police said that prima facie evidence indicated that the girl was suffering from fever before she died. But based on the complaint of Likita Babu, they registered a case of suspicious death.

Police said that Hema was raised mostly by her grandparents. Her father in intervals would often return to claim the child back and then again give the child back to his parents. Matters had come to a head when the women and child welfare department had to intervene and Hema was sent to stay in a hostel before she was sent to live with her grandparents again.

Title: Goa University starts MBA admissions for working professionals
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Goa University

PANAJI: Goa University has started admissions to its MBA (executive) programme for working professionals. The varsity introduced the programme during the last academic year. The special feature of this programme is that classes are held from Monday to Friday, from 6.30pm to 8.30pm, thus enabling working individuals to continue their education and strive for professional growth without compromising time with their family over the weekends, announced the university. Students must apply online by March 20, and classes are scheduled to begin April 1, at 6.30pm. “A group discussion and/or personal interview will be conducted to shortlist applicants,” GU said. The three-year-long MBA (executive) programme is divided into nine terms, and has an intake capacity of 30 students. The entire programme will consist of 76 credits, with each credit hour equalling 15 in-class working hours. “Tuition fees of Rs 1.5 lakh needs to be paid each year for the first two years, and tuition fees of Rs 50,000 for the third year,” said the university. “Academic courses are planned in the first seven trimesters, while the last two trimesters are designed for an industry project (that can be done in the organisation the participant is currently employed in). Faculty mentors will be allocated to each student participant,” the varsity said . The MBA (executive) programme for working professionals is designed to include learning through interaction with different stakeholders, using tools including case studies, role play, simulations and other such activities. “Opportunities are provided to learn through live projects in different courses,” said GU.

Title: Goa: New qualification norms for constituting pollution board
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

PANAJI: The chairman as well as member secretary of Goa State Pollution Control Board will both have to be well-qualified and experienced in environment-related studies.

However, an officer from the government or semi-government body or from the university, having the necessary qualification and experience could be appointed to these posts. With this, the chances of a politician occupying the chairman’s post will be very slim.

The environment department has proposed new guidelines for constitution of the pollution board as the Supreme Court had directed all states in 2017 to formulate guidelines for the purpose.

As per the guidelines, the chairman should have a master’s degree in science relating to envirnonment, or a bachelor’s degree in engineering in a discipline relating to envirnonment/doctorate in environment management, and experience from a recognised unversity or institution, and “excellent record of peer reviewed research publications”. He/she will also need to have ten years experience relating to environment protection, including in industrial pollution mitigation, water treatment or air pollution. He/she could be an officer from the state/public sector undertaking or university holding analogous post and possessing ten years practical experience relating to envirnment protection.

The member secretary will have to have a master’s degree in science relating to environment or bachelor’s degree in engineering in a discipline relating to environment. He/she could also be an officer from the state government or from the university, or any other statutory bodyholding a PhD in science related to environment.

Members representing local civic bodies will have to have bachelor’s degree in science or engineering, or at least HSSC in science/diploma in engineering.

Title: People from Jamia, Kashmir have come to Uttarakhand to disrupt peace: CM Rawat
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Uttarakhand chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat

DEHRADUN: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat said on Thursday that he had “got feedback that some people from Delhi’s Jamia Millia Islamia as well as from Kashmir had come to Uttarakhand with an intention to disrupt law and order situation in the state by provoking people.”

Rawat added that “such people will not be allowed to succeed and strict action would be taken against them.”

The CM was speaking on the sidelines of an event in the state capital. “People have the right to hold peaceful protests, but we will not allow people from Jamia and Kashmir to provoke people of Uttarakhand. We will not tolerate it at any cost.”

Rawat added, “Agar bahar ke log yahan aakar uksaane ka kaam karenge to humko sakhti karni padegi (If people from outside provoke people here, we will be forced to take strict steps.”

The protests over the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) in Uttarakhand have remained largely peaceful and limited to districts such as Dehradun, Haridwar, Nainital and Udham Singh Nagar. Political observers linked the CM’s statement with the ongoing protest against CAA-NRC at Haldwani, which has continued for the second day in succession.

Meanwhile, taking a swipe at CM Rawat for his statement, Congress state chief Pritam Singh told TOI, “In democracy, one has the right to protest in a peaceful way. I fail to understand how the government can stop a person from protesting in any part of the country.”

Singh added, “It appears that the CM’s statement was meant to create confusion and disrupt law and order in the state. If some so called anti-social elements had entered Uttarakhand, police would act against them. In fact, in that case, the CM should be telling people what action has been taken against the provokers.”

Singh added that “while the CM is silent over key issues such as deaths due to illicit liquor consumption, migration and lack of jobs, he does not shy away from making a statement on sensitive issue such as CAA and NRC.”

Meanwhile, DG law and order Ashok Kumar said that so far, protests have been peaceful in the state. “There was a protest in Haldwani on Thursday and we had inputs that some people from Jamia and Kashmir were involved in the protest there,”he said.

Kumar added that police is on alert mode. “I have directed DIG Kumaon and SSP Nainital to remain alert on the issue and keep a tab on people who are coming from outside to take part in the protests.”

Title: Raids at 43 blood banks throw up irregularities
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Drugs Control Administration officials cracked the whip on blood banks across the state on Thursday by conducting surprise inspections at 43 blood banks, including 13 government blood banks, where they found various irregularities.

The director general of DCA Kripa Nand Tripathi Ujela, in a statement, said that they found various irregularities like absence of medical officers, non-maintenance of calibration records of equipment and instruments, not performing quality control tests for blood components , improper maintenance of records and improper storage of blood and blood components. “Show-cause notices have been issued to all blood banks and once we receive their explanation, legal action deemed fit will be initiated against the violators as per the provisions of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act 1940,”he said Kripa Nand.

Title: Crop insurance: State moots loss and profit sharing model
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Nagpur: The state government is pushing what it calls the cap and cup model for Prime Minister’s crop insurance scheme. Launched during first term of the BJP government, the scheme is heavily subsidized by the Centre and state with farmers having to shell out only 2% of the premium.

Now, the state has come up with a proposal that if an insurance company suffers losses beyond a certain level, the government will intervene and share the burden. Also, if the profits exceed a specific level then it has to be shared with the government by the insurance company.

The scheme has, however, drawn flak from farmers’ groups who say it has only ended up with insurance companies netting in huge premiums with a little payout to farmers as compensation. This is because of the terms and conditions of the policy, the groups pointed out.

As the parliamentary standing committee on agriculture visited Nagpur as a part of its tour to study the insurance scheme in the state, government official also came up with the cap and cup model suggestion, said sources. The committee headed by Parvatagouda Gaddigoudar, BJP MP from Bagalkot in Karnataka, held a meeting on Thursday at a plush hotel which also led to severe criticism.

Under the cap and cup model, level of sharing the losses and profit can be kept at 20% or so on both sides, said a source. The plan is just at drawing board level. Further details like whether the sharing will be done by the state government or both state and Centre have to be worked out, the source said.

The state’s agriculture department has also mooted that crop insurance must be made voluntary. At present, it is mandatory for those who are availing crop loans. A section of farmers feels it is their money that is being used to pay the compensation for those in crisis-ridden areas like Marathwada, which is prone to losses.

As members of the parliamentary committee met farmers’ representatives, a common grievance was over the system of measuring losses by insurance companies. Farmers’ groups also made calls for doing away with the system of allotting areas to insurance companies and allowing all the companies to freely compete in a given market.

At present, specific areas are allotted to companies on the basis of bidding. Farmers, however, want the right to choose among all insurance companies, said sources.

“Crop insurance is the only scheme where there is no freedom of choosing the service provider because a specific company is allotted a given area. The point is valid and will be taken up,” said a source privy to the meeting’s proceedings.

There were calls to reduce the geographical area for calculating the losses too. In Maharashtra, a block of villages is considered as a single unit. So if only a village is affected by natural calamity, farmers cannot get the compensation if the entire block is not affected. This prevents many from getting the benefit of the insurance scheme. In Rajasthan, the unit has been fixed at panchayat level, this covers 2-3 villages and at times only one, a source said.

Navneet Rana, MP from Amravati and also part of the committee, said, “Insurance companies are earning almost Rs21 crore a day, but farmers hardly get anything in the name of compensation. The basic unit for measuring losses need to be brought down to village or panchayat level.”

Title: ‘Bizarre, shocking’, J&K student’s body react to CM’s Kashmir remark
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Dehradun: Taking umbrage to Uttarakhand chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat’s statement that Jamia students and Kashmiris are disrupting peace in the state, the members of Jammu & Kashmir Students Association asked the CM to focus on ensuring the safety and security of Kashmiri students “rather than issuing provocative statements”.

Terming the remarks of the CM as “bizarre and shocking”, spokesperson of the association Nasir Khuehami said, “What the CM has said is not acceptable and must be condemned in harshest words. We, the Kashmiris, are a peace-loving people and one shouldn’t use us for their political benefits.”

He further said it was “disheartening to hear such baseless and concocted statements from a democratically-elected chief minister of a state”.

“He must look to ensure and strengthen the law and order of the state rather than issuing such baseless statements,” he said, adding that the association urges all Kashmiri studying in Uttarakhand to desist from any activity that could disrupt peace. Notably, there are over 1200 Kashmiri students studying in various institutions across the state. Several Kashmiri students of the hill state had also faced a backlash after the Pulwama attack in 2019.

Title: Karnataka HC asks top cop to file report on Aero India fire accident
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Karnataka high court

BENGALURU: The high court on Thursday directed the Bengaluru city police commissioner to submit a status report on the investigation into the fire accident that occurred on February 23, 2019 at the air show at Yelahanka Air Force Station .

A division bench headed by chief justice Abhay Shreeniwas Oka fixed March 2 as the next date of hearing on a PIL filed by Wing Commander G B Athri (Retd) and social activist Geetha Misra.

The petitioners have sought the appointment of a one-man judicial commission to probe the mishap, where they claimed more than 300 cars were burnt. They said authorities had not taken sufficient precautionary measures while organizing such an event where huge crowds gather.

They also claimed that HAL, which was part of the team that organized the aero show, had said that no parking fee was levied on any of the exhibitors or visitors who had parked their cars in P4 parking area where the fire incident took place.

Title: Cooperative registrar stalls Sanjivani’s attempt to sell molasses cheap
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The factory was auctioning the molasses at Rs 2,550 per tonne, when their regular rate with Goa Dairy was Rs ... Read More

PONDA: The registrar of cooperative societies (RCS) has directed the Sanjivani Sahakari Sakhar Karkhana at Dharbandora to keep in abeyance the auction of around 1,000 tonne of molasses till further order. Admitting that the RCS has emailed the directive to the factory, a highly-placed officer at Sanjivani said that the very same body (the RCS) had earlier cleared the auction of the byproduct.

The officer, who did not want to be named, said they could not keep the molasses for a long time, and were in the process of auctioning it only after taking the permission from the RCS.

“As there was only one party that had responded to the tender floated by the factory late December 2019, we had to accept the bid— even though the rate quoted by them was very low, as compared to the rate finalised to Goa Dairy,” said the officer.

Molasses is a liquid byproduct that is separated from raw sugar when it is processed in the centrifugal machine. During the last crushing season of the factory, between December 13, 2018 and February 28, 2019, a total 1,088 tonne of molasses was generated, and the factory was attempting to sell it. However, as the rate of Rs 2,550 per tonne quoted by the firm that had won the bid, Siddhi Enterprises from Kolhapur, Maharashtra, was very low, the workers of the factory first raised their suspicions about the deal . Later, the sugarcane cultivators opposed the move as well.

Molasses is also used in preparing cattle feed and Goa Dairy has been purchasing it from the Sanjivani Sugar factory at a rate of Rs 9,500 per tonne. As a result, factory workers said, selling the molasses at such a cheap rate to the Kolhapur-based company, was just not justifiable.

After they raised suspicion over the deal, the RCS has directed the factory to keep the auction in abeyance.

The sugar factory official said that Goa Dairy does not have sufficient space to store large quantities of the molasses, and is therefore unable to purchase all the stock.

Dairy administrator Arvind Khuntkar said that they already have sufficient stock of molasses to last them until February. The dairy’s cattle feed plant uses around 120 tonne of molasses per month, and only has the room to store the stock required for three months.

Title: Lucky escape for 45 as fire breaks out at Hotel Crown Palace
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Hotel staff informed the fire department at 6.44 pm and three fire tenders were rushed to the spot

INDORE: Panic gripped Tukoganj area on Thursday evening when a fire broke out in second floor chimney of Hotel Crown Palace . No casualty was reported in the incident but the hotel's second floor was destroyed completely.

Hotel staff informed the fire department at 6.44 pm and three fire tenders were rushed to the spot. A dozen fire fighters were pressed into service and flames were doused in an hour. The hotel staff and guests were evacuated safely, said fire officials.

Some 45 people were there in the hotel when the fire broke out. Officials said thick smoke engulfed the hotel and people panicked but it was controlled in time and no injury was reported. Several videos of the incident also went viral on social media.

Sub-Inspector Keshav Singh Kushwaha said minor fire broke out in the hotel but no injury was reported. “We are collecting details from hotel staff and guests about the incident. We have not received any complaint the case yet”, he said.

Title: JD(S) to ride on anti-CAA sentiment
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

HD Kumaraswamy and Deve Gowda among top JD(S) functionaries at the party’s workers’ meet in Bengaluru on Thurs... Read More

BENGALURU: The JD(S) is looking to leverage anti-Citizen (Amendment) Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) and National Population Register (NPR) sentiment sweeping the country to revive itself and will hold protests in Bengaluru and New Delhi.

The Bengaluru protest is scheduled for Friday. At a meeting of party workers in Bengaluru on Thursday, party patriarch HD Deve Gowda and former chief minister HD Kumaraswamy urged the rank and file to participate in the rally to send out a loud and clear message to the BJP.

"The BJP has set out to make Muslims second-grade citizens. India has 40 crore Muslims, can these communal forces eliminate them all?" Gowda said in his address. "We should have the guts to launch a massive protest at Jantar Mantar. We should be prepared to go to jail in the fight against [Prime Minister] Narendra Modi and [Union home minister] Amit Shah."

Gowda said he will lead the rally in Delhi and urged secular parties to unite to take on the BJP. "It is important that regional parties, which share a secular ideology, unite on a common agenda and fight the BJP. Bihar, Kerala and Odisha have said they will not implement CAA. The sentiment is likely to spread to other states," Gowda said.

Kumaraswamy said not only Muslims but many other communities will also bear the brunt of BJP’s "divisive politics". "This pair of Hakka-Bukka [Modi and Shah] is not targeting Muslims alone," he said. "For them, all communities other than upper caste Hindus are inferior Shudras. They will treat even Lingayats, Vokkaligas and Dalits with the same contempt."

The former CM made a special appeal to Lingayats, who generally back the BJP, to stop supporting the saffron party’s caste-oriented politics. "You had appreciated my farm loan waiver scheme and promised support in the elections. But, the results were contrary to that," he said.

The JD(S) passed three resolutions including one to condemn the Centre for enacting CAA. The others were to protest against the Centre’s indifference to the floods in the state and the failed economic policy of the Centre.

Title: Prepare report in month’s time to curb migration: Uttarakhand CM to officials
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Trivendra Singh Rawat

DEHRADUN: To check the issue of migration from the hills, chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on Thursday directed all the government departments to prepare a report on work done in this regard in a month's time.

The chief minister also proposed to establish a ‘Migration Mitigation Fund’ to encourage locals to stay back in their native places and provide job opportunities.

For the areas lying close to the border, the CM said that officials should “make flexible plans, that are suitable to the needs of people living in these belts.”

"In such areas, the opportunities are limited and we need projects which are flexible in nature and can be easily done, and also provide financial stability to people,” the chief minister said.

Uttarakhand has witnessed large-scale migration in the last two decades with over a thousand villages left with no residents. Rawat pointed out that special projects have to be started in the identified villages to check migration and boost reverse migration in the hills.

Rawat also directed the officials of forest department and tourism department to “work as a team to come up with a strong eco-tourism policy.” The tourism officers were further told to come up with a mobile app which had district-wise information of a place’s flora and fauna, tourism spots, trekking routes, hotels and homestays.

“This will help tourists in exploring new and different locations in the state during their visit,”added the CM.

Title: Haldwani witnesses Shaheen Bagh-type protest against CAA, NRC
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representational Image

DEHRADUN: Hundreds of women and children are observing a 72-hour-long protest against CAA and NRC at Haldwani ’s Taj Chauraha.

While the protest at Taj Chauraha, which started on Wednesday will continue till January 24, another organisation, ‘Samvidhaan Bachao Manch’ will also hold a 72-hour-long protest in Haldwani from January 25 onwards.

Over 300 women and children, covered in blankets, blazers and shawls, sat on protest at Haldwani’s Taj crossing, braving the low temperatures and icy-cold winds. The protesters said that they were determined to register their voices of dissent against CAA and NRC which have been passed by Parliament recently.

Ekra Ali, one of the children at the protest site, said, “How can we sit at home at a time when our country is in danger? India’s secularism and Constitution is under threat by these laws that have been framed unconstitutionally,” she said.

Ruksara Begum, 50, added that “even though I am unable to walk properly due to knee pain, which has increased due to the extreme cold, I came to take part in the protest since it is for a rightful cause.”

Meanwhile, leader of opposition Congress’s Indira Hriyadesh reached the spot on Thursday to extend her support to the protesters. “I want to assure you that our party is with all of you in this fight,” she said.

The district administration meanwhile said that the protesters should have taken their protest to the designated ‘dharna sthal’ in the city rather than sitting at Taj Chauraha.

From Saturday, members of ‘Samvidhaan Bachao Manch’ will hold a 72-hour-long protest at Buddha Park. One of the protester said that they will also celebrate Republic Day at the same spot on Sunday.

Title: 1000 buildings stand in way of road projects
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: Over 1000 residential and commercial structures are coming in way of road development projects proposed under Indore Development Scheme (masterplan) 2021.

Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) has recently conducted a GIS survey and identified 1160 buildings in 48 colonies that will pose hurdles in development of five roads - MR-5, MR-11, MR-3, MR-9 and RE-2.

However, officials have not confirmed how many of these structures will be affected and said it would be decided only after a physical survey.

IMC commissioner Asheesh Singh, “These structures have been identified on the basis of a GIS survey and a physical verification of each one of these structures would be done. Once completed, we will start issuing notices and remove constructions. Their owners will be provided with TDR benefits.”

The proposed roads will be developed under town planning scheme. IMC will be able to impose ‘betterment charges’ on property located up to 500 meter with the roads after implementation of the scheme.

“Betterment charges will be collected along with property tax on fixed annual instalments for three years,” added Singh.

The civic body has also made provision for these projects in its annual budget, and officials are in process to obtain Rs154 crore loan from Housing and Urban Development Corporation (HUDCO) to develop the roads.

State government has also been given its nod for construction of four roads. However, approval of MR-9 Road has been put on hold because of Indore Development Authority’s (IDA) scheme – 171, which is coming in the way of this project.

Title: ‘BJP’s Mission 120+ still in place for 2024’
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Samir Mohanty

Title: Mumbai: Charkop building to serve as case study for self-redevelopment
Content:
The experience of Charkop Jin Prem society will be a case study for thousands of housing societies that want t... Read More

MUMBAI: November 6, 2019, was an ecstatic day for residents of Charkop Jin Prem cooperative housing society in Kandivli (West).Their gleaming new 14-storey tower finally received a “full occupation certificate”—permission to occupy the premises—from the building permission cell of Mhada , the state housing authority.What makes this project unique is that it was executed by residents themselves under the self-redevelopment scheme. No builder was involved. The planning, funding, selection of building contractor, right down to choosing the tiles and fittings was entirely done by the 28 society members.“We completed the project in two years,” said a beaming Manish Asgaonkar, secretary of Jin Prem society. On a recent afternoon inside his family’s new flat, Asgaonkar said taking the onus of redevelopment was not a cakewalk. Some junior level civic officials and engineers created obstacles, trying to fling non-existing rules at them and, at times, demanding speed money for building clearances, he alleged. “But ultimately, we challenged them and prevailed,” he said triumphantly.The experience of Charkop Jin Prem society will be a case study for thousands of housing societies that want to redevelop their properties but do not want a builder to step in. The model, where residents rebuild their homes without a builder, is still in its infancy, but slowing gaining momentum.With thousands of families left in the lurch by fly-by-night builders , a new model has emerged with architects, project management consultants, contractors and others taking full responsibility for successful execution of such projects.Last year, the state framed rules for self-redevelopment, granting incentives to societies that chose it.Jin Prim was Mhada’s high-income group (HIG) building constructed in 1991. Its residents, mainly Gujarati and Maharashtrian, occupied 1BHK, 418-square-foot flats. Over the years, the building was twice repaired for leakages and plastering. In 2014, the 22 flat owners and six shopkeepers decided to redevelop the five-storey building themselves and passed a resolution. They were also aware of several stalled redevelopment projects in the neighbourhood, which had been abandoned by builders.Under Mhada’s 33 (5) Scheme, the society redeveloped the property into a 14-storey tower with 53 flats, each a 3BHK measuring 705 sq ft. Three flats in the new building were handed to Mhada as its share under the scheme . Six more were sold to outsiders for Rs 85 lakh to Rs 90 lakh each. These six flats were sold at Rs 2,000 a sq ft less than the market rate. The remaining larger free sale flats were brought by society residents themselves, who paid a concessional Rs 60 lakh each. The project cost Rs 17.5 crore. “No bank loan was taken. We raised the money ourselves,” said Asgaonkar. Bhushan Desai, Mhada’s executive engineer (self-redevelopment cell), said it has offered 11 offer letters to societies keen on self-redevelopment.

Title: Roadside kid kidnapped, hit, police suspect sexual assault
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Mumbai: A six-year-old daughter of pavement dwellers who was sleeping between her parents under the Matunga flyover was kidnapped, hit with a brick and perhaps sexually assaulted by an unknown person late on Wednesday night. The child has been admitted to Sion Hospital where she is battling serious injuries.

What has baffled the police is that the child was kidnapped from under the flyover which a stone’s throw away from Matunga and Sion police stations.

On Thursday evening, Matunga police were in the process of registering a kidnapping and a suspected sexual assault case against an unknown person.

Sources said if it is medically confirmed that the child was sexually assaulted, police will register an offence under stringent sections of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act. Offences under the Act are non-bailable.

According to Matunga police, the child slept off between her parents under the Matunga flyover on Tuesday night. Around 4am on Wednesday, her mother rose to find her daughter missing. She immediately woke her husband and the two began to look for her.

Around 8am, a college student found the child lying injured behind an ashram at King’s Circle.

She alerted the police who rushed to the spot. The child’s parents too reached soon after. They rushed her to Sion Hospital where she is being treated.

Police said prima facie it appears the child was kidnapped for sexual assault and suspect the assaulter hit her with a brick in a bid to kill her and fled.

Matunga police have formed a special team to trace the suspect. “We have got blurred images of the suspect (from CCTV footage) and have launched a hunt for him,” said an officer of Matunga police.

Title: Highest ever! IET lad gets Rs 30.5 lakh job offer
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: Breaking the record for the third time this academic session, the highest placement package of Devi Ahilya Vishwavidyalaya (DAVV) turned out to be Rs 30.5 lakh per annum as the varsity concluded its last phase of campus recruitment.

A+ grade in National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC) seems to have boosted the centralized placement cell (CPC) and has helped attract over 70 organizations to the varsity for campus placement.

“While the centralized placement cell had been working efficiently in getting students placed, it is after the grade that over 500 students placed at these organizations,” CPS coordinator Dr Dr Suresh Patidar told TOI.

This year’s highest package of Rs 30.5 lakh was bagged by a student of Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET).

“Final year engineering students of IET from Computer Science and IT department have bagged the highest packages. Whereas two MCA students of IIPS also got a package of Rs 15 LPA,” said member of CPC, Nitin Nagar told TOI.

Over 1000 students of the varsity have received offer letters and some of the placement offers are still expected by the varsity.

Title: Nitish Kumar to PM: Please intervene in case of woman seer fasting for Ganga in Haridwar
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Nitish Kumar

HARIDWAR: Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar has written to Prime Minister Narendra Modi asking him to intervene in the case of Sadhvi Padmavati who has been on an indefinite fast at Matri Sadan ashram in Haridwar since December 15 last year to press for cleanliness and uninterrupted flow of the Ganga .

In his letter dated January 22, the CM expressed concern over the deterioration in Padmavati's health and underlined the need for getting her fast terminated early. He requested the PM that “meaningful initiatives should be taken on the issues raised by the sadhvi.” This was revealed by the water resources minister of Bihar Sanjay Kumar Jha who along with Nalanda MP Kaushalendra Kumar, reached the ashram on Thursday to lend support to the sadhvi's fast. Notably, Padmavati is a resident of Nalanda in Bihar.

Her chief demands include cancellation of all dam projects — under construction or proposed on the Ganga in Uttarakhand, maintaining a minimum of 50% regular water flow in Ganga as per an IIT expert study, and compliance of all orders of the National Mission for Clean Ganga regarding mining in Ganga and its tributaries. Padmavati is also demanding formulation of a Ganga Act as well as initiation of an active discussion involving Matri Sadan and other organisations working to protect Ganga.

Nalanda MP Kaushalendra Kumar while interacting with mediapersons termed Sadhvi Padmavati as “Nalanda's daughter”, adding that “people were with her as she wants that Ganga should flow without hinderance.”

Seers at Matri Sadan meanwhile said that the ashram felt particularly betrayed by the government which had promised in writing a ban on construction of all dams on Ganga as also on mining in the river and its tributaries when Brahmachari Atmabodhanand ended his 194-day fast in May last year. But the government went back on its promise, they alleged.

Title: State pays tribute to Netaji, Surendra Sai on birth annivs
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Bhubaeswar/Sambalpur: Rich tributes were paid to legendary freedom fighters Subhas Chandra Bose and Surendra Sai on their birth anniversary on Thursday.

Janakinath Bhawan, the birthplace of Netaji at Odia Bazaar in Cuttack, was decked out as hundreds of people from different walks of life visited the place to pay floral tributes to the leader.

Governor Ganeshi Lal and chief minister Naveen Patnaik on Thursday visited the Janakinath Bhawan, which has been converted into Netaji museum. They paid floral tributes to Netaji statue there.

Schoolchildren and visitors made a beeline for the museum on the occasion and got to know about the leader’s life through memorabilia displayed in various galleries. An array of activities, including sand art, blood donation camps and cultural programmes, were organised at the museum to mark Bose’s birth anniversary.

Members of All India Forward Block observed Netaji Jayanti in Bhubaneswar by garlanding his statue. They demanded the day be declared Deshprem Divas.

The 212th birth anniversary of Suredra Sai was observed in different parts of the state. In Khinda, which is the birthplace and located 40 km from Sambalpur, people from all walks of life gathered to pay homage to the son of the soil. A torch rally was organised at Khinda during the occasion. The rally originated from Khinda high school and culminated at the birthplace of Surendra Sai.

Similarly, several programmes were organised in Sambalpur to mark Surendra Sai’s birth anniversary. People, including members of political parties and cultural and social organisations garlanded the statue of Surendra Sai at Jail Chowk in Sambalpur. The district administration and Odisha Sanskrutik Samaj, a Sambalpur-based socio-cultural organisation, jointly organised a memorial meeting in the evening. Students of the various schools took out rallies.

Surendra Sai was born in a royal family on this day in 1809. He started a revolution against the British at the age of 18 only. Sai was captured by the British in 1840 and lodged at Hazaribagh prison. During the Sepoy Mutiny, his supporters broke the Hazaribagh prison in 1857 and freed Surendra Sai. And, he resumed his revolution against the British. “In 1864, Surendra Sai was again sent to Asirgarh Jail near Burhanpur, where he died on February 28, 1884,” said Deepak Panda, a writer.

The role of Surendra Sai in the resistance movement against the British colonialism is a turning point in the history of freedom movement in Odisha. “He fought a battle for self respect. Surendra Sai and his supporters fought against the British for 20 long years. Sai spent 37 years in prison,” said Panda.

Title: Tamil Nadu: With exams round the corner, errors in government textbooks raise concerns
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Teachers, who handle Classes XI and XII, say errors in government textbooks are yet to be notified. With just about a month to go for board exams, teachers said they were forced to point out corrections to the students without any official source material.

Teachers in the district said the Tamil Nadu State Council for Education Training and Research (TN SCERT), which prepares the content for the textbooks, had formed a review committee and asked subject resource persons from across the state to send in their inputs regarding the errors spotted in textbooks.

“We had sent reports more than two months ago to SCERT in Chennai. But so far there has been no official announcement regarding the issue. We have to now identify the errors to be rectified and ask students to correct them. With the students preparing to face board exams in March, this has caused a serious concern,” said a Class XII teacher, who is also a resource person from the district.

Teachers said there were logical, spelling and printing mistakes in the textbooks. For example, in the seventh chapter, ‘Differential Calculus’, of Class XII mathematics textbook, answers are given wrong.

Pointing out that some portions of the syllabus were heavy for the students, resource persons said those portions could be omitted. “The solution book, which was published recently, doesn’t have answers for these sections. We have not been officially announced about dropping the sections,” said the resource person.

A teacher, who has authored a chapter in Class XII mathematics textbook, said authors had compiled the errors and submitted them to SCERT. “The work is ‘under process’ at the council.”

When contacted, SCERT officials denied to respond, saying the principal secretary to the department of school education was the authorized person to comment on the issue. Attempts to contact principal secretary Pradeep Yadav didn’t yield any result.

Title: Delhi sends 30k doses of measles shots to Male
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

NEW DELHI: Responding to an emergency requirement in the Maldives , India on Thursday supplied 30,000 doses of measles/rubella vaccine to Male . While measles has been eliminated from the Maldives, four cases have tested positive in the last week and the local government suspects an outbreak.

Male had initially approached Denmark and also Unicef for the vaccine but both apparently said they would require at least four weeks to arrange and supply it. It was then that the Maldives government approached the Indian embassy on January 20.

"The MEA , working closely with the ministry of health, procured supply of 30,000 doses of measles/rubella vaccine from the Serum Institute of India, Pune, and delivered the consignment on January 23. This will suffice the immediate requirement of Maldives,'' an official source said here, adding that India once again proved to be the first responder in an emergency for Maldives.

The government said in a statement that India's swift response underlined that health remained one of the strongest pillars of bilateral cooperation between India and Maldives.

In 2015, India had responded to a water crisis in Male due to breakdown of the main RO plant . India airlifted water and sent supplies by ship, including an RO plant. In 2004 too, India sent assistance when a tsunami struck Maldives.

Title: ‘Unidentified person tweaks CM’s tweet on Bose’
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Dehradun: On the birth anniversary of Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose on Thursday, CM Trivendra Singh Rawat tweeted a tribute to Bose. But later in the day, the message was allegedly tweaked by unidentified persons and circulated on social media. The CM’s office issued a statement saying that the act was aimed at tarnishing the CM’s image and Dehradun SSP Arun Mohan Joshi has been asked to probe the matter.

Title: Tamil Nadu: T T V Dhinakaran condemns Rajinikanth’s remark on E V R Periyar
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Rajinikanth

SALEM: AMMK leader T T V Dhinakaran condemned actor Rajinikanth for his remarks about rationalist leader E V R Periyar ’s 1971 rally.

Talking to reporters at Salem on Thursday, Dhinakaran said that it was saddening that Rajinikanth has spoken about Periyar based on false information at 50th anniversary function of Thuglaq magazine.

“Periyar struggled throughout his life for the upliftment of Tamil people without any expectations. Rajnikanth should have avoided his speech about Periyar,’’ he said.

“Rajini’s remarks are condemnable,’’ he said.

Meanwhile, Ramanuja Jeeyar , the pontiff from Mannargudi, backed Rajinikanth.

He told reporters at Salem there was nothing wrong in what the actor spoke about Periyar.

Title: Odisha: Silk City jail soon to get food processing unit
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Santosh Kumar Upadhyay inaugurates the hospital

BERHAMPUR: A food processing unit will soon start functioning from the Berhampur circle jail . The construction of the Rs 1.03 crore building is nearing completion.

The unit will be operated by the jail inmates and they will get incentives for this, director general of police (prisons), Santosh Kumar Upadhyay, told the media here on Thursday. He inaugurated a 30-bed hospital building inside the circle jail.

At present, a weaving unit, tin trunk-making unit and a printing press are operating inside the circle jail and the inmates are working in the units. The incentives, which they earn by working in different units of the jail, will help maintaining their families outside the jail, he said.

Now the hospital is functioning in a ward with 10 beds in the jail while outdoor is functioning separately.

Of 30 beds in the proposed hospital, 10 are earmarked for women, he said.

Though two doctor posts, including that of a psychiatrist and a medicine specialist, have been sanctioned for the new hospital, it would initially run by the existing doctor. There are two other staffers — a male nursing orderly and an attendant. The hospital will cater to the needs of about 800 inmates in the jail.

At present, around 150 inmates visit the outdoor. Besides, serious patients are also treated in the hospital as the circle jail has declared it as a referral jail, an official source said.

“We are giving much stress on health of inmates and hygienic condition in the jails across the state,” he said. In the circle jail, he said, there is a need to maintain cleanliness of toilets. He also said the old buildings of the circle jail need repair.

The top police officer said sophisticated devices will be procured from abroad to monitor use of the mobile phones by the inmates from inside the jail.

Title: Kerala: 16 escape as fire guts houseboat in Vembanad Lake
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

As the houseboat caught fire the tourists were first shifted to a speed boat. But it sank near a sandbar and t... Read More

ALAPPUZHA: Sixteen people including 13 tourists (two babies and a child) from Kannur had a narrow escape after a houseboat caught fire near Pathiramanal isle in Vembanad Lake at Muhamma on Thursday. Muhamma police suspect either a short circuit or LPG leak from the kitchen as the cause of the accident.

“The incident took place around 1.15pm. Muhammad Fazal, 24, and Abdul Rasheed, 25, of Nellunni, Kannur, and their family and relatives boarded the double decker boat ‘Oceana’ from Kumarakom around 11.30am. The guest team comprised six women, four men, two babies and a four-year-old boy. Besides them, there were three boat crew members. As the boat reached near Pathiramanal, the kitchen part caught fire and it spread to the rest of the boat. Fortunately, there were sand bars nearby with just five feet of water. So, the tourists and the boat crews jumped onto them,” police said.

The state water transport department’s boat ‘S-54’, conducting service from Muhamma to Kumarakom witnessed the incident and came to their rescue. They shifted three women, one man, two babies and the boy to the main land. Though a speed boat had come to shift the remaining people, it sank near the sand bar. They were later shifted to Muhamma in another boat.

Muhamma sub-inspector Ajay Mohan said that no one suffered any injuries and all of them were shifted to Alappuzha Guest House.

Houseboat operators have demanded an exclusive fire station for the tourism sector but it is yet to materialize.

Title: Remembering Bijji and his folk tales
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Vijaydan Detha aka Bijji, the Rajasthani folklorist writer, would have been pleased if he was there at JLF on Thursday.

Author Vishes Kothari who translated Bijji’s work and released a book was part of a discussion at the fest.

He said the tradition of storytelling has always been a work of the poor. “Most of the oral traditions are followed by people from the most unprivileged background. Among those, women are the treasurer of the tradition who would sing hymns and songs while doing their daily chores. Men would work outside and women would keep the tradition alive. Dijji followed those people and recorded their stories,” Vishes said.

Chandra Prakash Deval, who was part of the conversation, said folk tales could create magic. “Folk tales should not be looked from the glasses of literature. The power of folk tales has been continuing for thousands of years. Hitopdesh and Arabian Nights are a few examples which are still prevalent. If a story is good, it will be remembered for generations to come. Dijji recognised and collected these stories from people,” Deval said.

Talking about Dijji’s work, Vishes said to keep the Rajasthani touch in the stories, he kept original words and phrases in the same language. “I had to convince my publishers about it. There are words that have different meanings in Hindi and Rajasthani. There are many traditions followed in Rajasthan that will lose its relevance if translated,” he added.

Title: In slums of Kalkaji, Arvind Kejriwal seeks votes for Atishi, AAP’s development work
Content:
Atishi said she was sure that the people of Kalkaji would vote to make Arvind Kejriwal the CM once again

NEW DELHI: A series of road shows attended by AAP national convener Arvind Kejriwal in south Delhi on Thursday culminated in the evening in Govindpuri , which falls under party candidate Atishi ’s assembly constituency, Kalkaji While seeking votes for the party candidates for Delhi government’s development work, the chief minister again urged the supporters of the rival parties to vote for AAP in the February 8 assembly polls. “I appeal even to the supporters of BJP, Congress and other parties. This is a different election (than the Lok Sabha polls) and everyone should come together to vote for the broom (AAP’s symbol),” Kejriwal said. “A sea of people had arrived in Kalkaji and the level of enthusiasm gives strength to the party,” he tweeted later.Atishi said the party was getting stronger in the area day by day with the blessings of locals. “I am sure people of Kalkaji will vote to make Arvind Kejriwal the chief minister of Delhi again,” she said.After beginning the evening leg at the Pul Prahaladpur Shiva temple in Tughlaqabad, Kejriwal reached the underbelly of Kalkaji around 5.40pm where Atishi was waiting to join the cavalcade. Starting from Gurudwara Baba Banda Singh Bahadur, the road show passed through a series of JJ clusters between Govindpuri and Kalkaji — Navjeewan, Bhoomiheen and Transit camps.With more than 25 slum clusters, economically weaker section people form a key vote bank in Kalkaji, besides Punjabis. The slum clusters — Priyanka, Gandhi, Nehru and Karpoori Thakur camps being the prominent ones — had remained a traditional Congress stronghold till AAP won them in the 2015 elections by defeating three-time MLA and current Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra. Two local leaders from Congress and BJP switched over to AAP in the chief minister’s presence.At Navjeewan camp, 60-year-old Kamala Devi was watching the road show passing by her jhuggi. She has received zero bills for both electricity and water in the past four months. “We are just an elderly couple with my son living on the top floor. We save more than Rs 1,500 every billing cycle. This money can be used in bad times,” she said.Rama Shankar (50), a rickshaw driver, said he had been living in the area since the time when Indira Gandhi used to be the Prime Minister. “Before every election, we have been promised pucca homes in place of jhuggis but nothing had ever materialised,” Shankar said.All through the hourlong show, Kejriwal, sitting in a chair on a specially designed open air jeep, and Atishi kept on waving at the residents. While hundreds of bikes and cars followed the jeep in Tu ghlaqabad, e-rickshaws dominated the scene in the narrow lanes of Govindpuri.

Title: Villagers condemn arrest of bull race organisers, block road
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Vellore: Tension prevailed in Vellakottai near Vaniyambadi in Tirupattur district after a group of people threw stones on the road on Thursday condemning the arrest of three bull race organisers who, according to police, failed to adhere to safety rules that resulted in the death of a bull a day earlier.

During the bull race at Kothakottai on Wednesday, a bull owned by R Raman, a farmer, died after falling into a well located near the finishing line. A police officer investigating the case said, “The bull race organisers did not adhere to prescribed safety norms due to lack of safety measures at the arena. After a commotion by the crowd that had gathered led to damage of public property, the Vaniyambadi taluk police arrested bull race organisers R Pazhani, M Shankar and M Boopalan and remanded them in judicial custody. Police have launched a search to nab C Annasamy, S Chinnathambi, and the bull owner Raman, who were absconding.”

Addressing the media, Tirupattur DSP Balakrishnan said, “The accused were arrested under Section 289 (negligent conduct with respect to animals), Section 429 (mischief by killing or maiming cattle, etc.), Section 337 (causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others), Section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of IPC, and under various sections of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act, 2017, and Prevention of Public Property Damage Act.”

Later, after a peace talk with police and revenue officials, the road blockade was withdrawn by the villagers.

Title: Parcels to New Delhi banned for 3 days ahead of Republic Day
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

SALEM: The Salem division of Southern Railway banned parcels (electronic or material based) to New Delhi ahead of Republic Day. The ban will be revoked after January 26.

Talking to media persons, the railway officials said that, security has been beefed up across the country. “As part of security arrangements, we have banned parcel services to New Delhi to prevent any untoward incidents,” the official said.

Usually, the parcels are sent to New Delhi and Nijamudin from Salem and its surrounding stations including Erode , Tiruppur and Coimbatore.

However, the railway officials confirmed that this ban does not cover essential commodities (groceries and amenities) as they will be sent to New Delhi as usual.

Title: It’s car-o-bar ahoy for tipplers in Chennai
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

CHENNAI: More than half the youngsters in Chennai who drink outside their homes do so in cars, carparks and on beaches as they can’t afford bars and pubs, says a recent survey. They also complain that they often don’t get their favourite tipple unlike in other cities.

The survey was conducted 45 days ago by the International Spirits and Wines Association of India (ISWAI), a representative body of multinational alcoholic beverage companies. Amrit Kiran Singh , ISWAI executive chairman, said in Chennai the survey covered 3,000 respondents comprising both men and women in the age group of 21 to 35 years. “We carried out the survey in seven top liquor selling states including Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Haryana, West Bengal and Tamil Nadu,” he said.

Among the revelations was that 48% of the respondents prefer to have a drink outside their homes. But since there were no affordable pubs, 44% drank in cars and parking lots and 10% in public places such as beaches.

“We have not come across a similar issue in Bengaluru as reasonably priced pubs are available there. In contrast, Tamil Nadu has unique rules such as the one that a pub must be attached to a hotel with a minimum of 10 rooms,” he said. This made services in the pubs expensive.

One of the main grouses of respondents was that their favourite brands were not available and if they were, they had to pay more. Besides, 79% 0f respondents said illegal sale of liquor after permitted hours and on dry days was prevalent in the city.

Amrit Kiran Singh said TN was facing acute shortage of popular international brands manufactured within India. “We met the Tasmac MD on Thursday with a representation to procure all varieties of IMLF manufactured in other states. It will bring revenue to the state, as well,” he added.

Title: CM announces Rs 2 lakh ex-gratia for kin of student who died due to wall collapse
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Dehradun: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on Thursday announced ex gratia payment of Rs 2 lakh to the family of a 16-year-old student who died after the boundary wall of a school in Rishikesh fell on him on Wednesday.

The CM also directed the secretary (education) to carry out an inspection of all the government educational buildings in the state and carry out renovation and repair work so that such incidents are not repeated.

On Wednesday, the wall of a government primary school situated on Pushkar temple Road had suddenly collapsed and three commuters got trapped under the debris. Later, the injured were brought to Rishikesh Civil Hospital where Ketan, a resident of Mayakund, was declared brought dead.

The CM also held a review meeting on Thursday in which the honorarium given to PTA teachers by the management of government non-aided private schools was disc ussed among other issues.

Title: BKV, SOS register easy wins
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

An interesting scene of the match held on Thursday

Nagpur: Bhartiya Krishi Vidyalaya (BKV) and School of Scholars (SOS), Beltarodi, registered comfortable victories in the Prahar Inter-School Handball Championship, on Thursday.

In the boys under-17 match, Bhartiya Krishi Vidyalaya Team A beat Prahar Military School 16-9. For the winners, Sanket Nale scored six goals while Pawan made four. Aniket and Aaditya scored two goals each while Navinya and Atharva struck one apiece.

In Under-14 category, SOS, Beltarodi, routed Prahar 19-4. From SOS team, Mandar emerged top-scorer with five goals while Mihir made four. Om and Aayush scored three goals each and Arnav and Vedant made two each.

Ace swimmer Anurag Khune of Raisoni College was the chief guest of the day.

Title: Parcels to New Delhi banned for 3 days ahead of Republic Day
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

SALEM: The Salem division of Southern Railway banned parcels (electronic or material based) to New Delhi ahead of Republic Day. The ban will be revoked after January 26.

Talking to media persons, the railway officials said that, security has been beefed up across the country. “As part of security arrangements, we have banned parcel services to New Delhi to prevent any untoward incidents,” the official said.

Usually, the parcels are sent to New Delhi and Nijamudin from Salem and its surrounding stations including Erode , Tiruppur and Coimbatore.

However, the railway officials confirmed that this ban does not cover essential commodities (groceries and amenities) as they will be sent to New Delhi as usual.

Title: Men who stole bike from police station in Kerala arrested
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Two people, who stole a motorcycle from Ollur police station in Thrissur district in Kerala , were arrested in the city on Wednesday night.

The Big Bazaar Street police identified the arrested as Kiran, 20 and Sibu, 40, of Vadakkencherry in Palakkad district .

A police source said the two had been roaming around the city on a motorcycle that didn’t have registration number.

“On Wednesday night, Big Bazaar Street inspector Velankanni Udhayarekha and team found the two travelling on the unregistered motorcycle on Oppanakkara Street. During check, the team found the vehicle’s lock was also damaged. The duo were then taken to the police station, where they confessed that they had stolen the bike from Ollur police station in Kerala,” the source said.

The city police alerted their counter parts in Ollur and they came down to the Big Bazaar Street police station on Thursday morning to take the two into their custody. “The stolen motorcycle was also handed over to the Ollur police,” the officer said.

Title: Conversation about female sexuality shouldn’t only be about consent but also desire: Elizabeth Gilbert
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Publisher Alexandra Pringle with Eat, Pray, Love author Elizabeth Gilbert at the JLF on Thursday

On her maiden visit to the Jaipur Literature Festival , American author Elizabeth Gilbert spoke about her writing journey from her bestselling memoir ‘Eat, Pray, Love’ to her latest novel ‘City of Girls’, published in 2018.

Gilbert spoke of facing a two-year-long depression after her first divorce. “I was fraught with shame. I had done everything you were supposed to do to be a good woman: gotten married and settled down, but I had a nervous breakdown because that life didn’t suit me,” she said. “And it made me physically, emotionally and spiritually ill.”

Gilbert also spoke of her dislike of the institution of marriage and how it resulted in her writing her next book ‘Committed’, just as she was remarrying. “I didn’t want to enter that institution again, so I spent time learning about the history of marriage,” she said.

“There is not a single sociological data at which single women don’t outperform married women — they live longer, they’re healthier, have more wealth.”

Gilbert went on to talk about creativity, as explored in her book ‘Big Magic’. “Art is making something more beautiful than it needs to be,” she said. “It’s our shared human encounter and we can’t be emotional or spiritually healthy without creating.”

Describing her last book ‘City of Girls’ as a “celebration of female sexual desire”, Gilbert spoke of how it questions the omnipresent literary trope of the “ruined woman”. The book was also written during the height of the MeToo movement in 2017.

“I don’t want the conversation about female sexuality to only be about consent. It places women in a passive role. What that takes away is the real aspect of female desire and longing.”

Title: Kerala government will bear expenses to bring bodies from Nepal
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Hospital staff watch as the bodies of the eight Indian tourists who died on Tuesday are transported into an am... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The bodies of eight Keralites, comprising two couples and four children from two families who died in a mountain resort at Daman in Nepal on Tuesday, are expected to be brought in Thiruvananthapuram and Kozhikode on Thursday and Friday respectively.

The embalmed bodies of five persons from the family residing in Chenkottukonam near Thiruvananthapuram will be flown from Kathmandu to New Delhi on Thursday morning and then to the state capital by an Air India flight late in the evening, it is learnt. According to the information provided to relatives, the bodies of the three persons hailing from Kunnamangalam in Kozhikode will reach Kerala only on Friday.

After the autopsy and the embalming procedures were completed by Wednesday noon, the bodies were moved to Tribhuvan University Hospital in Kathmandu.

The state government announced that it will bear the entire cost of bringing back the bodies, following an initial ‘miscommunication’ with the Indian Embassy in Nepal. “Indian embassy officials did not communicate to us in time that the embassy will not be able to bear the expense,” said a Norka official.

The initial confusion occurred as the deceased were on a leisure trip to Nepal, where visa is not required for Indians and there was no clarity whether they had tourist insurance coverage, the official said.

The transportation would cost anything between Rs 8-10 lakh, and the chief minister’s office intervened immediately after some news channels reported that the Indian embassy wouldn’t be bearing the expense. According to embassy officials, they were yet to receive a directive from the Union ministry of external affairs or the central government for providing financial assistance.

CMO then directed Norka department to bear the entire expense. Tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran expressed shock at the ‘disrespectful’ stand taken by the Indian Embassy.

“We need to take a humane approach in such situations. We shouldn’t push the bereaved families into deeper grief. Whatever assistance is needed to bring the bodies back will be borne by the state government,” said Surendran on Wednesday.

Title: One arrested with hooch in Haridwar
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representational Image

HARIDWAR: Police on Thursday arrested a man with 250 litres of hooch which was being smuggled from Bijnor district of Uttar Pradesh, once again accentuating how illicit liquor is being traded openly in the district and no lessons have been learnt from the hooch tragedy of last year that killed over 40 people.

Deepak Singh Kathait, SHO, Shyampur police station, told TOI, “We got information that hooch from Badarpur village of Bijnor district was being smuggled in a car. When we asked the driver to stop the car, he tried to escape. Our teams blocked the road and arrested him. Around 250 litres of hooch in packets has been recovered from the car. The liquor was to be delivered in Rishikesh and Raiwala area. The accused, Pramjeet Singh, resident of Badarpur village was arrested. Further investigation is going on.”

In a similar incident, police had recovered 1000 litres of raw material of hooch from the forest of Pathri police station a couple of days ago.

Title: Time not far when AI may be telling us about its novel at Jaipur Literature Festival: Marcus du Sautoy
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Marcus du Sautoy

The inaugural session of Jaipur Literature Festival kicked off with a keynote address on ‘The Arts, Sciences and Creativity’ by Oxford University professor Marcus du Sautoy and classical singer Shubha Mudgal. Sautoy began by talking about the stories that science can tell. “Science requires precision but also huge amount of imagination,” he said. “Mathematics in India used to be written in poetic form – mathematics was poetry and there is poetry in mathematics.”

Highlighting the important role of AI in our lives, Sautoy addressed the fear of this new technology taking over. “But we believe AI will never be able to do is match human creativity, after all isn’t it an expression of our inner soul,” he says. “But in this decade, it seems AI might show signs of creative acts. How long before we have a piece of AI telling us at JLF, telling us about its new novel? It’s not so far away.”

Sautoy also argued that literature can be a way to give empathy for humans. “Literature gives us a way to understand each other,” he says. “We are worried whether AI really understand us. We want AI to be our side, and I think it is through stories that we can find a pathway together as collaborators and not competitors.”

Mudgal spoke on art and creativity through a fable of a king who wanted to sculpt, but was told by a sage to first learn the basic of painting, instrumental and vocal music. “It illustrates the overarching significance of an interdisciplinary approach in the Indian tradition,” she said. “It illustrates the vast scope and many directions in which one can journey with the arts. Calling creativity “an exercise in extending the boundaries of your chosen discipline”, Mudgal ended the session on a melodious rendition of a Sahir Ludhianvi poem .

Title: Epics relevant even in this era, says ‘Bahubali’ creator
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Jayshree Periwal, who introduced the session on Mythology for Millennial with Meenakshi Reddy Madhavan and Anand Neelakantan, kicked off the discussion with the remark mythology is not science, but a way of life.

The session was essentially about ways of writing mythology in modern times and the relevance of these tales.

Neelakantan, who penned the famous Bahubali series said, “I rationalise what I write. There are no gods, no devils, no villains, no heroes in what I write. I essentially do not write about what’s good or evil, but more about the political scenario. There is no right or wrong, but a perception of what we try to get from history.”

While agreeing that epics are still relevant, Madhavan added, “Epics are relevant even now. The drama is still the same, but societies change.”

Both the authors expressed concern about the current scenario with references to ‘good days’ and ‘Hindutuva’, they agreed that there were no ‘godliness in their writings’.

Neelakantan said, “The aim is to take the message from history and books that we write are a part of convenience. Good versus evil is a western concept. Stories change with changing times and societies.”

Madhavan said, “I believe in living and adapting to things and what is in our head doesn’t mean that it is not real.”

The authors lamented that though they take inspirations from mythological characters, they add characters to their books as per the requirements.

Title: No big projects in PCNTDA’s draft budget
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: The Pimpri Chinchwad New Township Development Authority members approved its draft budget of 2020-21, with an outlay of Rs 640.82 crore, on Thursday.

The draft, outlay of which has also reduced by Rs 39.01 crore as compared to that of 2019-20, stayed clear of introducing any big development projects. Besides, it was perhaps the first time in the last 15 years that PCNTDA did not hold a press briefing to inform about the salient features of the draft budget.

It will now be sent to the state government for final approval.

Title: Delhi Weather: Another windy day and clear skies expected in Delhi
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Met officials expect clear sky on Friday, with shallow fog during morning hours (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The capital witnessed a pleasant day on Thursday with the minimum temperature settling at 9 degrees Celsius, one notch above the season’s average.

The maximum temperature was recorded at 20.2° C, a notch below what is normal for this time of the year. “There was shallow fog in the morning, with the visibility at 800 metres between 5am and 8.30am. After that, it was clear sky throughout the day with wind speeds of 20-25 km per hour. In some areas of Delhi, there were gusty winds of up to 35 km per hour,” a met official said.

Track the pollution level in your city

Met officials expect clear sky on Friday, with shallow fog during morning hours. Strong surface wind (speed to the tune of 20-25 km / hour) is expected during the day with the maximum and minimum temperatures to be around 20° and 9° C, respectively.

In terms of pollution, Delhi’s air quality was recorded in the ‘poor’ level, with an AQI of 211. This was a stark improvement from Wednesday’s AQI of 370, thanks to strong surface winds.

Data according to CPCB’s central control room showed Delhi-NCR’s average PM2.5 levels at 73.3 micrograms per cubic metre at 8pm on Thursday. The average PM10 levels, at the same time, were above safe standards at 139.2 micrograms per cubic metre.

According to SAFAR, strong surface winds are the main factor contributing to the betterment of AQI through high ventilation. “Westerly surface wind is likely to continue till Friday, with the AQI forecast to improve to the ‘moderate’ category. The air quality is likely to deteriorate on Sunday,” a SAFAR report stated.

Title: Pune: Man creates teen’s fake profile online, shares her morphed pictures
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A Solapur-based man was booked by the Dehu Road police on Wednesday after a woman complained that he had created a fake social media account of her teenage daughter and sent the girl’s morphed photographs to her family members.

The man was booked under Section 509 (word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman) of the Indian Penal Code and the relevant sections of the Information and Technology Act.

“The woman in her complaint allaged the man had created a fake account in her daughter’s name in October last year. He morphed the teenager’s photographs accessed after hacking into her original profile. He then sent obscene messages from the fake account,” an officer from the Dehu Road police station said.

The officer said the suspect had also sent some obscene messages and photographs to the complainant’s niece. “We have booked him for harassing two women,” he added.

Statistics released by the Pune police in recent years indicated that criminal offences involving misuse of popular social media sites accounted for 25% of the total cases of cybercrime being dealt with by them.

Title: We should speak against CAA to save country: Nandita Das
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Nandita Das speaks during the Jaipur Literature Festival (JLF) 2020 at Diggi Palace, in Jaipur (PTI photo)

Actor Nandita Das on Thursday joined the list of celebrities opposing the Citizenship Amendment Act. She endorsed the series of protests being held at Shaheen Bagh and other parts of country. While speaking with reporters at JLF, she expressed her urge as a ‘human being’ to speak against such laws while denying any politics behind the protests.

“I believe everyone should speak about it. In fact people are speaking. There are spontaneous protests all over country,” she said.

She said the youth and common citizens protesting against the Act are triggering ‘hope’ while the CAA with National Register of Citizens (NRC) pose a dangerous mix. She insisted the CAA went against the sentiment of equality and divided people on religious lines.

“People who have been here for generations and you are telling them this is not your country. This is upsetting,” she said.

The Manto director was at the festival to speak about her experience of directing a movie and writing a book. “It is not easy to get technical aspect in the movie and apart from direction, it was also an emotional experience for me. In today’s scenario in the country, Manto’s struggle becomes even more important and relevant. Now even the Bollywood fraternity is speaking about the ongoing situation in the country.”

She also appeared concerned on the issues of unemployment, economic slowdown and corresponding reports in foreign media. She felt India was being discussed as a country where people are being divided on religious lines.

She was delighted that few members from the film fraternity, too, have spoken against the Act. She, however, seemed reluctant to discuss the ongoing controversy between the actors supporting the Act and those against it.

Title: Kerala: Three SFI activists hit Pala SI, booked
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

A video grab of the SFI activists threatening the police officer in Pala

KOTTAYAM: Police on Thursday filed a case against three SFI leaders for assaulting a police sub-inspector in Pala .

A video of the incident had gone viral on social media since Wednesday. In the video, one of the persons, identified as a SFI leader, is seen shouting at the officer and asking him to leave the place. He is also seen trying to push the officer back.

The officer along with the driver of the police vehicle had rushed to the Government Polytechnic College in Pala after he was alerted of a clash between two groups on the campus. Tension had been brewing between SFI and ABVP activists on the campus since a few days.

P K Mani, the sub-inspector, was near the college when the violence was informed at the police station. He rushed to the spot immediately. Some SFI leaders, who were not students of the college, were seen threatening students at the college entrance. When the officer tried to intervene he was threatened and pushed by the SFI leaders. In the melee, he sustained some bruises on his hand.

Title: Wheat, gram sowing area rises in Maharashtra
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Area under cultivation for major winter (rabi) crops, such as wheat and gram, has seen a dramatic rise in Maharashtra , the agriculture ministry data show.Rabi gram has been sown over 19.6 lakh hectares, the highest since 2014-15. Rabi wheat has been sown over 8.61 lakh hectares — the largest area sown under the crop since 2017-18. This is also likely to spike the state’s production of gram and wheat in the coming period, stressed the state agriculture department officials.A report released by the ministry on the area coverage under rabi crops as on January 10, 2020, stated that higher-wheat sown area had been reported from Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat, Rajasthan and Maharashtra, among others.A state agriculture department official told TOI that area under rabi had been on the rise this time. “When there is late rain, like it happened in September and October 2019, the moisture availability in soil increases. This prompted farmers to plant more gram and wheat. It is likely that the area under the two crops may also go up,” he said.Ravi Patil, programme coordinator, Krushi Vikas Gramin Prashikshan Sanstha, said, “The rain during September and October last year increased moisture content in soil. Considering the optimum moisture level in soil, farmers planted more gram and wheat.” Anmol Raut, who heads a farmer-producer company, said the area under gram and wheat had gone up for most farmers in his company. “Area under gram has seen a spike compared to wheat, which means there will be an increase in gram harvest,” he said.

Title: First phase of Tamil Nadu census in June; officers to use app, ask phone numbers
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The first phase of Census 2021 in Tamil Nadu will be held for 45 days in June and July, says the state government’s communication to the census department. The second phase will be held between February 9 and 28 next year. The first phase will consist of house listing and housing census in which 34 questions will be posed to every household.

“Since 1971, we have been having two phases of census. We started preparing for this year’s census three years ago. Maps have been readied based on the number of districts in a state. There is a number code based on the state, district, taluk, town panchayat, village panchayat, municipality, corporation and ward. If an enumerator is working in a ward in Chennai city, he or she will be collecting details under a numerical code,” said a census official. Tamil Nadu has 37 districts, including the newly created ones. “We have made all arrangements for enumeration even for the new districts. But any further division of districts will not reflect in the forthcoming census,” said the official.

Training of enumerators will start in April-May. Four national trainers have been deputed to Tamil Nadu. They will train master trainers at district level. “About 1.5 lakh enumerators (mostly school teachers) will be on the field. There will be a three-day training programme for enumerators during which time they will be trained to handle the census app. All entries will be carried out using the apps installed in their smartphones,” said the official.

The first phase is likely to take about 20 minutes per household. “We had a dry run a few months ago in Ilayangudi in Sivaganga district , Coonoor in Niligirs district and Maraimalainagar in Chengalpet district . We observed that the app can work offline and once the enumerators starts using the app frequently, the time per household will come down,” he said.

Along the state borders, people who are well versed in Tamil and the regional language of the neighbouring state will be deployed for enumeration. Apps can be downloaded in all regional languages. For instance, an enumerator in Kanyakumari district will use both Tamil and Malayalam apps. The app will be available in Tamil, Kannada, Telugu, Malayalam and Hindi, he said.

The centre is spending more than Rs 500 crore for carrying out census in Tamil Nadu. If a house is locked during the enumerator’s visit, the staff will pay one more visit within the 45-day schedule fixed for enumeration. If the house is locked during the second visit also, it would be recorded as locked house, said the official.

Title: Notorious woman goon booked under Goondas Act
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Puducherry: The Karaikal police on Thursday arrested notorious woman goon R Ezhilarasi alias Meera, who was booked in three murder cases, including the murder of former speaker and minister V M C Sivakumar, under the Goondas Act .

The action came after the Karaikal collector issued an order to detain her under the Goondas Act following recommendations from the district police.

A police team, which reached the goon’s house, arrested her and took her to the SP’s office for preliminary inquiries. This is the second time she has been booked under the act. She was set free by the Madras high court after she was detained under the Goondas Act earlier.

The second wife of slain liquor merchant Ramu alias Radhakrishnan, Ezhilarasi was involved in a series of murders and attempt to murder cases. She murdered her husband’s first wife R Vinodha in 2015 and a travel agent Iyyappan in 2014 to avenge the murder of her husband. She engaged goons to murder the former minister in 2017 following a dispute over the properties of her husband. The former minister and her husband were close friends but turned foes after her husband abandoned his first wife and married her.

Title: Sainik welfare dept to frame rules for private academies
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Pune: The state government’s department of sainik welfare has decided to formulate a policy for mandatory registration and regulation of private military training academies to check rising instances of cheating of army job aspirants.

Laxminarayan Mishra, the department’s officiating director, told TOI, “We have decided to form a team which will study the nitty-gritty of functioning of these academies and based on their findings, we will draft a policy which will be submitted to the general administration department (GAD) under which our department functions.”
