Mishra said that there is a need to register and monitor these centres on a regular basis. Currently, they register themselves with the state’s charity commissioner’s office. “But their periodical inspection is needed for monitoring their functioning,” he added.

Over the last two years, the Military Intelligence (MI) unit of the Army’s Southern Command and the police in Kolhapur and Satara have exposed five cheating cases in which either owners or staffers of private military training academies were involved in illegal activities.

“In the absence of a proper regulatory mechanism, these academies exploit job aspirants. The government should delegate powers to either the district sainik welfare officers or the tehsildars for carrying out periodical inspection of these academies and check possible malpractices,” said another officer from the department.

As of now, more than 100 such academies operate in Satara, Sangli, Kolhapur and Pune. Most of them are run by ex-servicemen. These academies run classes for physical fitness, written examinations, etc on a daily basis.

“Since the owners are ex-servicemen, it becomes easier for them to lure job aspirants by boasting of their connections in the armed forces. Many aspirants and their parents fall for such claims and pay hefty amounts to the academy owners,” a senior official said.

Title: GHMC fines shopkeepers for violating two-bin rule
Content: SECUNDERABAD: Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) officials of Secunderabad zone on Thursday imposed nearly Rs 20 lakh penalty on individuals and owners of commercial establishments for littering public places. The offences also included dumbing garbage on the road, putting up illegal flex banners and wall posters, and draining water on roads.GHMC sources said that the corporation has decided to take strict action against offenders in a bid to improve the city’s ranking in Swachh Survekshan 2020.In Qutbulapur division Rs 2,000 fine was imposed on over 20 shops for not using separate bins for dry and wet waste. However, the shopkeepers said that they did not have prior information about the rule. “The sanitation team came and started imposing penalties without prior warning. If they had informed us about the bins, we would have installed them,” said a shopkeeper.However, civic officials said that all shopkeepers were informed about using two dustbins. “Twin bin system was introduced years ago and the media also highlighted it. We conducted several campaigns to inform shopkeepers about the bins and also banned plastic bags,” said a GHMC official.Meanwhile, GHMC officials said that they are attending meetings ahead Swachh Survekshan to decide on measures to keep the city clean. “We are also conducting meetings with residential welfare associations and owners of commercial establishments and explaining to them the importance of sanitation,” said G Ravinder Goud, GHMC assistant medical officer of health of Secunderabad.The ministry of housing and urban affairs has roped in IPSOS Research Private Ltd to carry out the assessment between January 4 and 31. The team will check the sanitation activities taken up by GHMC and rate them. They will also take feedback from citizens.

Title: Ready to deal with Chinese virus: Delhi hospitals
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: The new deadly coronavirus infecting people in China has no cure at present. No vaccine exists either to prevent the disease. India, therefore, is on alert to prevent the spread of the infection here from China, where it originated. In case it does spread, top doctors say, the hospitals are well-equipped to handle the situation.The virus causes flu-like symptoms, for example cold, chills and respiratory distress.Dr Randeep Guleria , the director of AIIMS , told TOI that evidence so far suggests mortality rates of the virus aren’t very high. “The government has already put in thermal scanners at airports to detect possible cases. So far, there have been none. But even if such cases are found, we have enough infrastructure and expertise to contain the spread of the disease,” he said.AIIMS, Dr Guleria said, has a cubicle where six to seven patients can be isolated for treatment. “Depending on the requirement, we can increase the capacity of isolation wards 100% or more,” he said. Ram Manohar Lohia (RML) and Safdarjung hospitals, too, have infrastructure in place to create isolation wards at short notice. Infected people may be required to be separated from other patients and the general population.Like seasonal influenza , which is quite common these days, coronavirus infection also spreads from an infected person to others through the air, by coughing and sneezing or through close personal contact. Dr Amit Suri, consultant in medicine department at RML hospital, said maintaining hand hygiene and following respiratory etiquette is important to prevent the spread of the disease.According to Dr Rommel Tickoo, senior consultant for internal medicine at Max Saket, not many people are aware of the new infection at present. “If a case is diagnosed in India, then people may panic. We need to have plan in place to educate the public about preventive measures if such a situation arises,” he said.Last year, scientists from the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) and the National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) — the most important health research bodies in the country — had identified 10 emerging viral infections that could pose a threat to public health in India. The list included MERS-CoV, or Middle East Respiratory Syndrome coronaviruses, which was first reported in Saudi Arabia in 2012 and has since spread to 26 countries.The Wuhan illness, as the new infection is being described because its epicentre is in the Chinese city called Wuhan, is of the same family that caused MERS-CoV.“National Institute of Virology, Pune is developing protocols to test the infection. In the next few days, more laboratories may be equipped to test people suspected to be infected,” Dr Chand Wattal, chairman of the microbiology department at Sir Ganga Ram hospital, said.Union health secretary Preeti Sudan on Thursday said she has asked states and union territories to review hospital preparedness in terms of isolation and ventilator management of critically ill patients, identify gaps and strengthen core capacities like surveillance and laboratory support.Thermal screening is being done at the international airports of Delhi, Mumbai, Kolkata, Chennai, Bengaluru, Hyderabad and Cochin.In Video: Taking all preventive measures, no need to panic, says Kerala Health Minister on coronavirus

Title: Friends come to help bereaved families
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The tragedy that occurred in Nepal has once again underlined the meaning of friendship. Friends of Praveen and Ranjith, who died in an unfortunate accident at Nepal, have taken the lead to help their bereaved families. They are coordinating procedures to bring back their bodies while ensuring help to relatives.

Ram Kumar and Jayakrishnan, who were travelling with Praveen and Ranjith, were busy on Wednesday. Ram and Jayakrishnan shuttled from hospital to embassy and the airport in Kathmandu to arrange the transport of the eight bodies and ensuring travel arrangements for five of their family members. Two of their friends from college days had rushed to Kathmandu on Monday itself. Another batchmate, who is working in the US, made the reservations for the family members to travel home.

Sandeep Krishnan, a batchmate of Praveen and Ranjith, said the autopsy procedures were completed and they were waiting to transport the bodies. “The flight tickets are yet to be confirmed but we expect the bodies of Praveen and his family to reach Thiruvananthapuram by Thursday evening. There are also reports of flights being delayed, so it is yet to be confirmed whether it will be possible. The families of both Ram and Jayakrishnan along with Ranjith’s elder son Madhav are on their way home,” he said on Wednesday evening.

Praveen’s neighbour Sreejitha G said that Praveen’s parents are deeply depressed. “His aged father and mother are mentally drained after learning about the tragedy. They had to be given medical assistance on Tuesday night. Praveen’s sister Praseetha’s husband came back from Dubai on Wednesday morning,” she said. Neighbours and relatives are staying with the family.

Title: Jaipur Literature Festival: Addressing the ‘non-mughal’elephant at Mughal Tent
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Vikram Sampath, Hindol Sengupta & Makarand R Paranjape

Swami Vivekananda’s call for national consciousness, Savarkar’s idea of Hindutva and Sardar Patel’s unapologetic Hinduness were held up to scrutiny at the Jaipur Lit Fest on Thursday, as writers and historians Vikram Sampath , Makarand R Paranjape and Hindol Sengupta came together to discuss the three “enigmatic” figures from modern Indian history.

Along the discussion, the speakers arrived at the conclusion that the common thread tying these three historic characters was their assertion for a “national identity, independent from religion”. “There’s an elephant in this room… It is ironic that we are having a conversation about these three individuals in the Mughal tent,” said Paranjape, while responding to an audience question. He added that there was an elephant in the Mughal Tent, and that was a non-mughal elephant. The “difficult question” that remained unaddressed, according to Paranjape, was the idea of a “political Hindu identity”, which was propagated by all three historical figures.

The speakers, while calling their branch of study as “corrective history”, maintained that the subjects of their research were not given their due in history. “It’s not surprising that there was no biography written about Sardar Patel for several decades before I wrote about him,” said Sengupta, adding that these figures were not studied because it did not suit a particular idea that the mainstream historians were trying to promote. Sampath said the same of Savarkar. “Savarkar was a persona non grata for the longest time. He was not studied by those who criticised him, or even those who claimed to have ownership over him. He was an untouchable when it came to academicians,” said Sampath, adding that it was important to revisit history and write it from different prisms and lenses.

Title: ‘Tech gaps, post-harvest losses cause shortage of pulses in India’
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Thanjavur: Technological gaps and post-harvest losses have led to acute shortage of pulses in India, director of IIFPT, C Anandharamakrishnan has said.

Addressing a two-day workshop jointly organized by the Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada and National Research Council of Canada for strengthening scientific partnership and collaborations in research on pulses, Anandharamakrishnan said that currently there is an acute shortage of pulses for consumption in India. “There is a 50% decline in per capita availability of pulses (since the last) three decades. The situation leads to the import of around five million tonnes of pulses annually,” he said.

“Due to lack of appropriate technology at field-level, post-harvest losses in pulses have also increased by 10%. There is a strong need to increase the domestic output, novel technologies for value addition, waste minimization and development of alternative food products for protein supplementation. So, the workshop aims to derive action points for conducting collaborative research with Canada to bridge technological gaps in Indian food industry and improve the economic prosperity of farmers by creating a strong backward linkage,” he added.

“The key areas of collaboration between two countries would be development of value-added products from pulses, engineered dynamic gastrointestinal system, technology for production of vegetarian meat with pulses and establishment of a pulse biopark in Tamil Nadu, alternative dairy products and alternative protein supplementation replacing the pulses,” he added.

Pitam Chandra, former director, Central Institute of Agricultural Engineering, Bhopal, inaugurated the workshop. Ramesh Vijayan, scientist, SERB, Sankaran Krishnaraj and Sijo Joseph from Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada and Kishore Rajagopalan from National Research Council, Canada, represented the Canadian delegation. The Indian delegation was led by senior-level scientists and executives from institution across the country.

Title: Kolkata: Climate change wiped out ancient river, city, says IIT study
Content:
A water reservoir at Dholavira

KOLKATA: The extinction of Dholavira — the biggest and most spectacular Harappan city in present-day Kutch district of Gujarat — was caused by the drying-up of a massive river that originated in the Himalayan glaciers in prehistoric times because of climate change , research by a team of scientists from IIT Kharagpur suggests.The river that ran through the desert of the Rann of Kutch was one of the main sources of sustenance for Dholavira. The scientists, led by geologists from IIT Kgp, said this was the first time that the existence of a perennial river located by a Harappan site was being vouched for.The findings, which have excited historians and archaeologists across the world, have been published in the Wiley Journal of Quaternary Science, a peer-reviewed academic journal published on behalf of the Quaternary Research Association. It covers research on any aspect of quaternary science, an inter-disciplinary field of study focusing on the Quaternary period, which encompasses the last 2.6 million years.The scientists said the river dried up because of climate change, when the glacier feeding it melted away. They said the river might remind one of the mythical Saraswati, which is also said to be lost, but is definitely not the same. The researchers have not been able to christen it yet, but have concluded that it might have been a distributary of the Indus, or might have been a “paleochannel” that ran beside Dholavira. A paleochannel is a remnant of an inactive river or stream channel that has been filled or buried by younger sediment.The river existed since prehistoric times but the civilisation started proliferating from 5,500 years ago and died about 3,800 years ago. The research has concluded that when the residents of Dholavira sensed that the river was gradually drying up, they adopted an advanced water-conservation system that helped them to survive for the last 1,700 years.While the research was led by Anindya Sarkar and his team from the department of geology and geophysics, the other agencies that collaborated were the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), Deccan College PGRI Pune, Physical Research Laboratory, and the department of culture, government of Gujarat.“Our data suggest that prolific mangroves grew around the Rann, when the river existed in the near southern margin of the Thar desert. This is the first direct evidence of the glacier-fed river, quite like the Saraswati, in the vicinity of the Rann,” Sarkar said.Ravi Bhushan and Navin Juyal from PRL, Ahmedabad dated the carbonates from human bangles, fish otolith and molluscan shells by accelerator mass spectrometer and confirmed the dating of the site. From potsherds and other remains found at the site, the researchers have also concluded that the Dholavirans were probably the original inhabitants of the region and had a fairly advanced level of culture even at their earliest stage. The study indicates that the city expanded for 4,400 years followed by an abrupt decline. Researchers R S Bisht and Y S Rawat from the ASI, who originally excavated the site, concluded that the decline was evident in the degeneration of architecture, craftsmanship and material culture of Dholavira.Arati Deshpande Mukherjee of the Deccan College said: “We have evidence from high-resolution oxygen isotopes in snail shells Terebralia palustris, which typically grow in mangroves and was a source of food for the Dholavirans.” Researchers also concluded that the snail isotopes suggested that the mangrove was fed by a glacial river that existed near the site. The drying of the river coincided with a mega drought period that is known in history as the Meghalayan drought. “Indeed, Dholavira presents a classic case for understanding how climate change can increase future droughts,” added Sarkar.

Title: Telangana Municipal Elections: Repoll in 3 poll stations today due to voter impersonation
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Women voters in Nizamabad

HYDERABAD: The Telangana State Election Commission (TSEC) has ordered repolling in three polling stations — one each in Kamareddy, Mahbubnagar and Nizamabad districts —following allegations of impersonation. The repoll will be held on January 24 between 7am and 5 pm. Incidentally, in all the impersonation cases, women cast votes.

According to TSEC secretary M Ashok Kumar, a woman voter, wearing a burqa, entered the polling station number 101 in Ward No 41 of Kamareddy municipality cast her vote in the morning at about 7.45 am. At about 4pm, another woman with the same voter slip number, claiming she was the genuine voter, cast a tendered vote with the permission of the presiding officer. The district collector admitted that there was laxity in the identification of the voter and also polling agents did not object to the impersonation due to either collusion among them or appointment of ineligible persons as polling agents.

At polling station 87 of Ward No 32 of Bodhan municipality, a woman voter, also wearing a burqa, walked into the booth around 10.45am and cast here vote. Later, around 1.45pm, another woman, claiming to be the actual voter, found her vote had already been cast by another woman. She produced her Aadhaar and other identity proofs too. She was allowed to cast a tendered vote after verification. The district collector found grave irregularities in the conduct of poll process at the polling station. In this municipality too, the SEC ordered repoll on January 24.

Repoll was also ordered in the Mahbubnagar municipality, where-in polling station 198 of Ward No 41, two burqa-clad women cast their votes. “When the polling staff asked them to remove the burqa, the women refused to do it stating that it was against their custom. They were allowed to vote based on their documents. The original voters came in the afternoon and exercised their tendered vote,” the secretary said.

Title: GHMC sets up cell to monitor complaints via social media
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Secunderabad: The enforcement, vigilance and disaster management (EVDM) wing of the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) on Thursday launched a central enforcement cell (CEC) and social media terminal to monitor complaints received via Twitter.

The EVDM officials also requested the complainants to post clear images and detailed addresses with their posts regarding unauthorised banners, flexis, cutouts, posters, and wall writings following which CEC teams will attend to the complaint and issue e-Challan to penalise offenders.

“For every offence a QR code will be generated. The aim is not to penalise offenders, but to generate awareness among people littering the city and to let them know there is an enforcement team monitoring them,” said EVDM director Viswajit Kampati.

After a complaint is posted on Twitter with a supporting picture, the EVDM officials will catch the offender. “If we get pictures of flex banners or wall posters, we will enquire and penalise the offender,” Kampati explained.

Till date 44,403 violations have been reported on CEC app and over Rs 14 crore penalty has been imposed,” read an official statement issued by GHMC.

Title: Two witnesses turn hostile, sentenced to two-month jail
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representattive image

YAVATMAL: Cracking down on key witnesses who turned hostile during trial in a murder case leading to acquittal of accused, the district and sessions judge TS Akali on Thursday sentenced two to undergo 2-month jail.

The judge also slapped a fine of Rs500 each on the hostile witnesses. Failure to pay the fine will increase the jail term by seven days.

Brief backdrop of the case was one Saurav Mahadev Kale (29), a resident of Umarsara area of the city, and two others were accused of murdering a youth.

The police, after filing an FIR under sections 302 and 34 of IPC and subsequent investigations, had named Shubham Uikey (23), a resident of Umarsara and Ankit Moon (20), a resident of Sankatmochan area, as main witnesses. During the trial, the duo turned hostile leading to acquittal of the accused on December 21, 2019.

However, the court was convinced that the witnesses had turned hostile and issued notices to them under Section 344 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) and asked them to explain as to why legal action should not be taken against them. The duo filed their reply, but the court refused to accept the explanation and sentenced them to 2-month jail.

Title: Tamil Nadu: 46 government colleges get full-time principals
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: The higher education department has appointed principals for 46 government arts colleges and colleges of education across the state.

This includes 14 constituent arts and science colleges functioning under various state universities that were recently converted into government colleges.

So far, the principals of nearby government colleges held additional charge of these colleges. With full additional charge given in July last year, there was a demand to appoint full-time principals to ensure effective administration.

An order issued on January 23 said that a total of 46 associate professors in various colleges have been promoted as principal grade – II in government arts colleges and colleges of education.

Associate professor, Government Arts College, Kumbakonam K Duraiarasan who is presently the controller of examination at Bharathidasan University has been appointed principal of Government Arts and Science College, Manalmedu.

With his appointment, the post of controller of examination has fallen vacant. Similarly, P S Vijayalakshmi, controller of examination, Periyar EVR College, Trichy has now been appointed as principal of Government Arts and Science College, Avinasi.

Title: Top cop promises ‘security audit’ of lovers’ points in city
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Nagpur: City police chief BK Upadhyay on Thursday promised a survey of places lovers visit for some quiet moments, putting themselves at risk of being targeted by goons. After the recent gang rape of a Standard XI student, Upadhyay wants to ensure security cover at such locations between 7pm and 10pm, when lovers are most likely to meet.

City police already have ‘dark spots’ identified in their anti-crime strategy, where patrolling and manpower are pressed into action at specific time slots. The latest survey too aims to thwart goons targeting couples at isolated places.

The city has witnessed some attacks on lovers at desolate places. Mohd Afroze Pathan and his gang had targeted several couples in the dark stretches along the Outer Ring Road in 2014 before being nabbed. The gang, like in the latest incident, would rob couples and also rape the women.

The police had promptly arrested the three culprits, including a juvenile, in the latest incident near Bhilgaon-Ranala Road on Tuesday. The top brass is now contemplating a more comprehensive security plan at certain isolated places. Lovers are known to visit these places despite awareness being created about locations more prone to attacks.

Upadhyay had in the past tried to create awareness among youngsters and their families to avoid isolated places as they are more risk-prone. This was done after the Hyderabad gang rape and murder incident. However, some sections of society did not heed the warnings nor implemented self-security measures.

“I intend to instruct officers to conduct a security audit in their police station jurisdiction, and identify the spots where couples mostly visit. We need to identify the unsafe places and introduce patrolling during vulnerable hours,” said the city’s top IPS officer. Upadhyay said police vehicles would visit such places at least twice or thrice in the sensitive time period.

In the meantime, New Kamptee police have allowed the court to take Shaikh Anwar and Mohnish Borkar into magisterial custody after producing them before the magistrate on Thursday to enable an identification parade soon. The cops have reserved the right to take the accused in remand later. The minor was sent to the government shelter home.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Transport minister M R Vijayabhaskar warns auto driver over excess emission
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

M R Vijayabhaskar

TRICHY: Transport minister M R Vijayabhaskar warned an autorickshaw driver to check his vehicle for emission levels after he noticed excess smoke emanating from it in on Thursday.

The minister also issued instructions to the regional transport office (RTO) officials asking them to monitor vehicles with such high emissions.

The incident took place on Thursday morning when the minister was returning after attending a school event in Vennaimalai of Karur district .

Finding excessive black smoke from an autorickshaw on the road, he asked the police escorting him to intercept the vehicle.

He went to the driver and warned him to rectify the issue and check the emission levels to avoid action from RTO officials.

Title: Writers busy with own exam, blind students left in the lurch
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: Dearth of writers for visually impaired students appearing in board examinations is a problem that arises every year. Students run pillar to post in search of writers and often are forced to give it a miss unable to find one.

But still no concrete steps have been taken by directorate of public instruction (Lok Shikshan Sanchalnalay) for these special children, who overcome all the odds to appear for the board exams .

Over 400 visually impaired students from Indore district and nearly 8000 visually impaired students from Indore division will appear for the board examination this year. And the problem is making them apprehensive and alarmed.

“Although it’s easy to find a writer for visually impaired for competitive examinations, it becomes a tedious task during board examinations. Although its’ duty of exam centre to provide a writer for visually impaired student, it’s only on paper. In reality it’s the visually impaired student that takes his own writer,” coordinator of Sanjeevani Seva Sangam, Sunil Singh Tomar told TOI.

Writer needs to be one class junior as writer for visually impaired student for which it becomes a task for them to find a suitable writer as their exams and that of the regular students take place in almost the same time.

“The biggest task that students appearing for board exams face is finding an eligible writer, who is able to understand and write in a good speed. In Class 10, my friend and I were ditched by our writer and so this time, we decided to find an additional writer to be sure,” said visually impaired student Kamlesh Patel, who will be appearing in Class 12 exam this year.

Other issues faced by visually impaired students are slow speed, bad handwriting and low understanding capacity of writer. There have been times, when visually impaired students are unable to give board examination due to unavailability of eligible writer.

“We also have a writer bank for competitive exam as there are no rules for such exams except the fact that writer should have basic knowledge of computer as most exams are conducted online,” development officer of National Association For The Blind (NAB), Sanjay Lokhande told TOI.

Moreover, there are times when new invigilator, who are unaware of rules end up wasting additional time in checking papers and asking for additional documents.

Title: NGO worker held captive by DMC staff, cops to the rescue
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Indore: A man hired by an NGO for monitoring ‘illegal ways’ of Dewas Municipal Corporation (DMC) catching stray dogs with metal pincers for sterilization under Animal Birth Control (ABC) programme was allegedly held captive for more than four hours by civic staff.

The man identified as Manish Vishwakarma was hired by Roopa Patvardhan, a local animal activist of Dewas to follow DMC’s workers engaged in catching stray dogs.

In a complaint to MG Road Kotwali police station, Patvardhan alleged that Vishwakarma was standing in front of DMC headquarters at 8.00am, when four DMC workers approached him and started hurling abuses.

“My worker was standing on main road and was speaking to me over phone when he was roughed up by Hemant Ubnare, a DMC health officer and three others. They abused him, snatched his mobile phone and dragged him to headquarter building and made him sit inside control room for more than 5 hours,” said Patvardhan while speaking to TOI.

She also claimed that workers also threatened him of dire consequences for recording videos, when they go and catch stray dogs. Patvardhan reached control room and asked DMC workers to let the guy leave. “DMC employees were not ready to let go my worker and he was released only when I approached police and lodged a complaint in this regard,” she added.

DMC commissioner Sanjana Jain refuted to allegations and said that the man was caught by workers on suspicion of theft of valuable items kept on premises of DMC building. “There were complaints that some individuals were stealing items like bathroom fittings etc from our premises on suspicion of which our staff caught the man and handed him to police,” commissioner said. Kotwali police said that they have received complaints from both victim and accused corporation employees. “While complainant alleged misbehaviour and being held captive, corporation employees accused him of stealing their equipment and hampering work. We are looking into the matter,” DSP Kiran Kumar Sharma told TOI. Animal activists had been alleging DMC staff of capturing stray dogs with metal pincers. Around 20 days back, Animal Welfare Board of India (AWBI) had issued a warning to DMC for using metal pincers to capture strays.

Title: Two held for trying to extort money by posing as policemen
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: Tukoganj police have arrested two persons including son of a policeman posted to 15th battalion colony for trying to extort money from manager of a coaching centre by posing as cops.

The accused were identified as Shubham Bansotiya, resident of 15th battalion colony and Rahul Kokre, 25, resident of Bhagirathpura.

According to police, complainant Vaibhav Sharma , resident of Vidyapati building, who ran an online learning education website, told police that two persons posing as police official had asked for Rs1 lakh from him. They said that his website hadn’t been registered and if he wants to continue his business without any hindrance he should pay them the money, police said.

One of the accused told complainant Sharma that he had been posted in Vijay Nagar police station. Sharma became suspicious and went to Vijay Nagar and enquired about them and came to know that there had been no policeman of such names. He then lodged complaint with Tukoganj police.

Meanwhile, Sharma bargained the amount of money with accused and the deal was done in Rs 25,000, police said. Both accused went to his office for collecting the money from him on Friday evening, when police arrested them. Kokre worked in a private company and was a friend of Shubham’s friend and went along with him, police said while talking to TOI.

Title: Delhi: 28 vehicles parked in open ground gutted in fire
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Sixteen old cars, nine motorcycles and three scooters got damaged

NEW DELHI: Twenty-eight vehicles, including cars , motorcycles and scooters, were burnt and damaged after a fire broke out in Shahdara’s Mansarovar park in the early hours on Thursday. An open ground was being used to park vehicles there. A case has been registered and so far the cause of the fire could not be determined. This is the second incident of vehicles on fire reported from Shahdara in a week.

“A call was received around 3am informing us about a fire near DDA flats in Mansarovar park. Six fire tenders were sent to the location and it was brought under control within half an hour. The fire was in sixteen old cars, nine motorcycles and three scooters that were parked in the ground,” said Atul Garg, director, Delhi Fire Services.

Investigating officers said that the cause of the fire could not be ascertained but it appears that the fire broke out in one of the vehicles and soon spread to the others. “The vehicles belonged to local residents. However, no one complained to police or raised suspicion about the fire. Taking cognizance of the incident, police registered a case. The forensics team was called to get evidence from the location,” said a police officer.

Title: Accused of model code violation, MP Arvind Dharmapuri puts up deleted Facebook posts
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Nizamabad MP Arvind Dharmapuri. (Photo: Twitter/@Arvindharmapuri)

HYDERABAD: Nizamabad MP Arvind Dharmapuri put up two posts on Facebook which he had deleted after requests from bureaucrats, even as an FIR has been registered against him for alleged violation of model code of conduct. The MP said that since a case was already booked against him despite him removing the posts, Dharmapuri was once again posting them. “There is nothing objectionable in the posts, but I still obliged and removed them. However, now I will fight it out,” he said. “Desperate CM’s office forced the Nizamabad police to file a case against me alleging provocative posts on social media. They were told to file it after municipal polls as anything before that would bring mileage to BJP,” Arvind Dharmapuri alleged on Thursday.

Title: 15-year-old Unnao girl pushed into flesh trade in Ahmedabad
Content:
Representative image

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

AHMEDABAD: A 15-year-old girl from Unnao district of Uttar Pradesh, which was recently in the news due to two particularly brutal rape cases there, was brought to the city with the promise of work by a distant cousin and his wife, who then allegedly pushed her into the flesh trade in the Sola area of the city.According to the FIR registered at Sola police station, the girl, from Kailash Khera-Patan village in Unnao district, whose mother is widow, was lured to the city by the Sola-based couple with the promise of work. The accused, Dipak and Varsha Verma, both around 35, were arrested by police on Thursday.“The Vermas went to Unnao in December, where they told the girl’s mother that they would get her a job in Ahmedabad. The girl, a Class VIII dropout, was not ready to leave her widowed mother alone, as her two brothers work in Nepal and Kanpur, and she refused at first,” said Inspector D H Gadhvi of Sola high court police.Gadhvi said that the girl was then promised a great deal and she ultimately decided to take up the offer. On December 22, 2019, they brought her to the city and took her to a shop at a mall on Science City road.“The shop looked like a spa from the outside but was actually where a prostitution racket was running. On December 23, they forced the girl to go with a man, who raped her,” said a city police official.The girl was raped every day since December 23 by various men. She couldn’t even tell her mother about her ordeal as the latter would tell her to work hard and earn a living. On Tuesday, she called her brother and told him everything.Her brother came to Ahmedabad and first approached Vatva police as he was staying there. He was sent to Sola police station, where an FIR was registered.Gadhvi said they have registered an FIR for rape and molestation along with charges under the POCSO (Protection of Children against Sexual Offences) Act.“We have conducted the medical examination of the girl which confirmed that she was raped multiple times,” said Gadhvi.He said police are hunting for the men who had sexually abused the girl.

Title: Assembly session begins today, likely to be stormy
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Jaipur: The budget session of the assembly beginning on Friday is likely to be stormy. The session has been convened early to pass a resolution against the contentious Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and to approve the Constitution (126th) Amendment Bill extending reservation to SC/STs in the state assemblies and Parliament.

The law providing reservation to members of SC/ST communities for the past 70 years in Lok Sabha and state assemblies is due to end on January 25, 2020.

The Constitution (126th) Amendment Bill was passed in Rajya Sabha on December 12 while Lok Sabha had passed the bill on December 10. The state assemblies have been asked to pass the amendment by January 25 by the Union government.

The session will also see the state Congress government pass a resolution against the contentious Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA)

“The Rajasthan government will introduce a resolution against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act in the assembly session beginning Friday,” deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot told reporters at the PCC HQs here.

He said the Centre should listen to the people protesting against the Act across the country and asserted that the democracy weakens if there is no dialogue.

“We are requesting the Central government to reconsider the Act. The Constitution has given the right to protest but if someone does it, they are attacked and called anti-nationals,” said Pilot on Thursday.

Kerala and Punjab have already passed the resolution seeking withdrawal of the new legislation.

After passing the resolution, which is likely on Monday, the session will be suspended until the state budget is ready for presentation by February end after the Union budget.

“Business Advisory Committee meeting of the House will be held after the obituary references on Friday,” said Mahesh Joshi, chief whip of the assembly.

He said it is likely that the assembly will be in session on Saturday also.

The Opposition will also corner the government on the delay in panchayat elections after a tussle between the state election commission and the panchayati raj department over delimitation of panchayats.

Meanwhile, the Opposition BJP at its legislature party meeting held on Thursday issued whip to all party MLAs to be present in the House during the session.

While talking to media, Opposition leader Gulab Chand Kataria questioned the move of the ruling party and asked how could Congress bring a resolution against CAA when the matter is pending at Supreme Court. He said there could be no discussion in the House on a sub judice matter.

He added that the SC/ST reservation bill was passed in assemblies and parliament in December but the state government was sleeping all this time and now an assembly session has been called hurriedly to pass the legislation.

Title: Ahmedabad: Woman assaults brother’s widow at SG Road club
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

AHMEDABAD: A 44-year-old woman from the Thaltej area of the city has filed a complaint with Sarkhej police alleging that her husband’s sister and her two children had beaten her as they suspected she was clicking their photographs at Karnavati Club in the Mumatpura area on SG Road on Wednesday evening.

In her FIR, Vaishalini Patel, resident of Manichandra Society near Surdhara Circle, states that she has been running a design studio and her husband had died two years ago. She had a membership of Karnavati Club where she visits often.

“As there was a meeting at the Karnavati club on Wednesday evening, I had gone there. When I was present there, I found that my sister-in-law Bhumika Patel, resident of Shetur Bungalows in Thaltej, and her two children were also present there as they are also members of the club,” said Vaishalini in the FIR.

Vaishalini further states, “My sister-in-law was not in good terms with me after my husband’s death. So, she very often picks up fights over trivial issues.”

“When I was standing at a swing inside the club at around 7pm on Thursday and was holding my cellphone in my hand. My sister-in-law and her two kids passed from nearby and asked me why I was clicking their photos. When I told them that I did not click their pictures, they began abusing me,” Vaishalini states in the FIR.

She alleged that the trio then started beating and abusing her. As Vaishalini began screaming for help, other club members rushed in and rescued her, states the FIR.

Vaishalini then called up police control room and cops from Sarkhej police reached there.

Inspector B B Goyal of Sarkhej police station said that that the family dispute took an ugly turn at the club. “We have directed the accused persons to come to the police station and record their statement. We have also begun collecting CCTV footage of the incident,” Goyal said.

Title: Maharashtra: Five in car found drunk near Futala, driver booked
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Patrolling cops, led by zonal DCP Vinita Shahu, intercepted a car in the wee hours of Thursday near Futala Lake in which five drunk persons, including two defence personnel, were travelling. Cops have booked car driver for drunk driving.

According to sources, during night patrolling, DCP Shahu spotted a car suspiciously stationed near Futala Lake. “On seeing the police vehicle, car driver tried to flee. The police chased and intercepted the vehicle at some distance. The police found that the driver was under the influence of liquor. Four others in the car, including two defence personnel, were also in inebriated condition. We booked the driver for drunk driving and others were let off after warning them under sections of 110 and 17 of CrPC,” said the DCP.

It is learnt that of the two defence personnel, one was from army while other was from navy, both on leave. The five had stopped near the lake while returning from a private function.

“I have directed cops to send a report of the incident to the respective units of the defence personnel. We have increased patrolling in Futala area to keep a tab on anti-socials as such elements were seen consuming liquor openly. The increased patrolling has certainly reduced the number of anti-socials indulging in unruly behaviour near the lake,” said the DCP.

Title: Telangana civic elections: Women outnumber men at poll stations, may tilt scales
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Women voters at polling station at Kompally on Wednesday.

HYDERABAD: Women turned up in large numbers in the polling held for 120 municipalities and nine municipal corporations on Wednesday. Nearly 70% women had exercised their franchise, 1% more than male voters, 69 per cent. Interestingly, at six places, 90% of the total woman voters turned up to cast their votes, while at a dozen places, women polling percentage crossed 85. The woman voters’ turnout is nearly same as the state poll average, i.e., 70.26%.

Of the 34.95 lakh votes polled on Wednesday, 17.37 lakh voters were women, approximately 69.94%, while 17.13 lakh voters were males (68.80%), Telangana State Election Commission (TSEC) authorities said.

The women seem to have shown more interest in polling in the municipalities than the corporations. In the Choutuppal municipality in Yadadri-Bhongir district, 93.22% of women turned up to vote, while 92.46% in Chandur and 92.22% in Pochamapally in Nalgonda and Yadadri districts respectively.

“During the previous civic body elections in 2014, woman voters’ polling percentage was about 65, which was 5% more than the previous election. The number of woman candidates in the electoral contests is also rising with every election,” a senior SEC official said.

Among districts, Yadadri-Bhongir topped the list with the maximum turnout of women, scoring 87%, followed by Warangal Rural (84%), and Suryapet, Sircilla and Khammam (83% each) rescpectively.

Election analyst S Ramakistaiah said, “It is a good sign that women turned up in large number at the polling stations, but we have to see whether it will be an advantage to the woman candidates. Even politicians believe female voters are more faithful than their male counterparts.”

Title: How Madras SaaS ‘mafia’ is giving desi cos a ticket to US
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

CHENNAI: After years of disciplined execution in building global products out of Chennai, a growing crop of Chennai’s tech product entrepreneurs crossed the seas in 2019 to prove their mettle in Silicon Valley.

From building teams and aligning to new cultures, it’s not an easy transition, but the new ‘Madras-Bay Area’ mafia has made it a point to help other Indian founders. They are acting as sounding boards for other founders with global ambitions and making their playbooks accessible to them to share common pitfalls.

Further, to formalise this support, a few Software as a Service (SaaS) entrepreneurs are working to launch a separate startups charter as part of the US-India Strategic Partnership Forum (USISPF), a non-profit for Indian-US bilateral ties since 2017.

With the US accounting for 70% of business for Indian SaaS, being closer to customers and outperforming American competitors are key reasons for making the move. It is also easier for startups to go public in the US markets -- an inevitable next step for them to provide lucrative exits to global investors.

As customer support platform Freshworks gears up for an initial public offering, co-founder Girish Mathrubootham wanted to go beyond being a rock star entrepreneur in Indian startup circles, and moved permanently to Silicon Valley. “It has helped me interact with other CEOs who have gone through this journey to see growth,” he says.

Umesh Sachdev, co-founder of conversational AI startup Uniphore, shifted base to Palo Alto last year as almost half of the $350 billion customer support industry is in the US. With the US and Europe as its primary markets, founders of Chennai-based Chargebee are contemplating a move. “We spend three to four months in the US and I am considering moving this year to mainly build presence closer to customers and assist sales,” Krish Subramanian, co-founder and CEO, Chargebee, says.

Vinod Muthukrishnan, co-founder of Cloudcherry, moved to the US in 2017, and since then, has been acquired by global giant Cisco.

These startups hire a mix of sales and deep tech leaders along with frontline marketing staff in the Valley. While Cloudcherry hired 15-16 people locally, for Freshworks and Druva, the number of hires in the US is significantly higher.

Giving back to the ecosystem comes naturally to SaaS entrepreneurs, says Muthukrishnan. “Everyone hosts founders who visit the Valley, help with introductions, and help others avoid common mistakes."

As more B2B SaaS startups adopt a dual headquarter structure between India and the US, the soon-to-be-launched USISPF Startup Connect aims to help CEOs make the transition smoothly and ensure steady pipeline of future moves. Uniphore’s Sachdev and CloudCherry’s Muthukrishnan are volunteering to lead the programme as co-chairs for now. “In its initial phase, USISPF Startup Connect wants to nurture and grow the wave of B2B startups from India and operating in the US-India corridor to drive value,” Sachdev says.

A standout feature of Chennai and Indian SaaS community is how close-knit they are, Arun Natarajan, founder, Venture Intelligence says. “We hear of such a culture in the Valley, but I don’t think a parallel exists in any other industry here,” he says.

A case in point is the SaaSBoomi conference (launched as SaaSX in 2014), which brings together the community to help peers. “The objective is to get as many companies into the Rs 25 crore [revenue] and above segment as quickly as possible by helping them avoid the same mistakes other founders made,” Suresh Sambandam, founder, Kissflow, says.

With 2019 breaking down fundraising barriers for SaaS, India is all set to emerge as the SaaS hub of the world, say industry trackers.

“SaaS companies based out of India can now go and win global enterprise deals,” Mathrubootham says.

“It is great to see products being developed out of India. We need more ventures that do deep R&D in the country,” says Zoho’s chief evangelist Raju Vegesna. However, he is quick to strike a note of caution. “We haven’t seen many SaaS companies in the West turn profitable yet and we shouldn’t expect different results if Indian companies here follow the same formula,” Vegesna adds.

Title: Swachh Survekshan teams visit different areas in Nashik
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

NASHIK: Two teams from the Centre, comprising two members each, have been in the city for the past five days for Swachh Survekshan 2020.

A Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) official said the survey began on last Friday and is expected to continue for few more days. The teams visited various parts of the city to ensure that garbage is lifted regularly, cleanliness is being maintained and citizens are not throwing waste on the road.

They also inspected some public toilets to see if they are being maintained properly. Moreover, the teams also took feedback from citizens about garbage collection and waste segregation.

The city had ranked 67 during last year’s Swacch Survekshan, but was included in top-10 clean cities during the first two quarters of cleanliness survey.

In Swachh Survekshan, there are around 40 different indicators including garbage lifting, waste segregation and composting, cleanliness drive, cleanliness of roads, public toilets and markets.

“The teams are conducting the survey and we have tried to do well in all segments to improve city’s ranking,” an NMC official said.

“We are doing our best to be among top-10 clean cities in the country. But contribution of the citizens is also important. Citizens should ensure that the city remains clean and they should segregate waste at source,” he added.

Nashik did not fare well in SS 2019 as its ranking among 425 cities had dropped to 67 from 63 in 2018. Citizens’ feedback accounts for 35% marks in the survey. But according to data compiled by union ministry of housing and urban affairs, there was poor response from the citizens of Nashik.

Apart from this, the NMC had not carried out proper documentation of cleanliness activities conducted by the municipal corporation in view of the Swachh Survekshan last year.

Nashik had figured among the top-10 cities in the first two quarters of the Swachh Survekshan League 2020. In the first quarter (April-June), the city was ranked fourth, while it slipped to seventh rank in second quarter (July-September).

Title: Fake currency gang busted, 2 in custody
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: Palasia police arrested two accused involved in printing and using fake notes of different denominations and recovered fake currency notes with face value of Rs 49,000 and a printer from them. The arrested accused, identified as Surya Pratap Singh Chauhan and Deepak Wankhede were produced in court on Thursday and taken into remand for inquiry.

SP (East) Yousuf Qureshi said that police had got a lead from an informer about a person trying to use fake currency note in Lalram Nagar. When the police team reached the spot, they found accused Chouhan trying to use fake currency and recovered fake currency notes with face value of Rs22000. Police arrested him under Section 489C for possession of forged currency. When police enquired him about the currency, he told about one of his accomplices Deepak Wankhede of Nagpur, Qureshi said.

A police team was sent to Nagpur and Wankhede was arrested and fake currency notes with face value of Rs27000 along with a high definition printer were recovered, Qureshi said.

Explaining modus operandi of accused, Qureshi said that both accused came in contact on Telegram app and met in Nagpur. Wankhede supplied fake currency notes with face value of Rs22,000 as first installment to be used in market. Wankhede is a cyberexpert, who used deep net and collected information about fake currency printing and business of body parts of wild animals, Qureshi said.

Wankhede also told police during questioning that he had been involved in foreign exchange and Bitcoin.

Title: In a fix over tunes, bands practise both
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

A tableaux of the Rafel Aircraft takes part in a full dress rehearsal for the upcoming Republic Day parade, in... Read More

NEW DELHI: Following an outcry over the move to replace “Abide with Me” by “Vande Mataram” in the “Beating Retreat” ceremony, the military bands are awaiting a final decision and practising both the tunes in the run-up to the musical ceremony on January 29.

Several prominent people have objected to the proposed discarding of Mahatma Gandhi’s favourite ‘Abide with Me’, the haunting Christian hymn composed by poet Henry Francis Lyte but usually sung to William Henry Monk’s melody “Eventide”, from the enchanting ceremony and replacing it with national song ‘ Vande Mataram ’.

A Congress spokesperson has also questioned the motive behind the move to drop ‘Abide with Me’ altogether from the ceremony held at Vijay Chowk on the majestic Rajpath . On Thursday, the Mizoram Congress slammed the Union government for pushing its “hidden Hindutva agenda”, with a senior leader claiming this was yet another move by “BJP and the Sangh Parivar organisations to suppress Christianity and other religious minorities”.

Defence ministry officials, however, said no final decision has yet been taken in the matter. They said the emphasis in recent years has been on replacing western tunes by “desi tunes” composed by Indian composers, with the popular “Sare Jahan se Achha” also replacing the decades-old tradition of playing ‘Abide with Me’ at the end of the ceremony.

Similarly, sitars, tablas and other Indian musical instruments have also been introduced in the ceremony over the last few years. This has caused some umbrage among purists who contend “Beating Retreat” is a traditional military ceremony of bugles, pipes and drums. The buglers sounded the retreat in ancient and medieval times as a signal to halt fighting, recall patrolling units and lower flags at sunset.

In 2018, 25 of the 26 performances were tunes composed by Indian musicians, with ‘Abide with Me’ being the only western tune. Last year, ‘Abide with Me’ was among the eight western tunes out of the 27 performances. This time, ‘Abide with Me’ and the ‘Drummers Call’ are the only western tunes among the 27 performances being rehearsed for the ceremony.

Title: File report on AirAsia probe, HC tells ED
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Delhi high court on Thursday directed the Enforcement Directorate to file a status report on its probe into a money laundering case lodged against some officials of AirAsia India whose licence has been challenged by BJP leader Subramanian Swamy .

A bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar made ED a party in Swamy's petition challenging the flying licence and Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) clearance granted to AirAsia, a joint venture of Tata Group and Malaysia's largest budget airline AirAsia Berhad.

The court directed the probe agency to file its status report in a sealed cover before the next date of hearing on May 14. Swamy had earlier urged the court to seek a report from ED on the status and progress in its probe.

The BJP leader had, in July last year, moved a plea to stay the airline's application for permission to operate international flights but the high court had dismissed it.

In his primary plea, Swamy has contended that the flying rights granted to the carrier were in violation of the government's policy on foreign investment. He has argued that as per the policy, foreign investment was allowed only in existing airlines and was not meant for floating or starting a new airline, like AirAsia India.

The Centre has denied that there was any violation of FDI norms while granting approval to the low-cost AirAsia (India) Pvt Ltd.

Title: PM should open borders for free movement: Deputy CM Nitin Patel
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Gujarat's deputy chief minister Nitin Patel (File Photo)

AHMEDABAD: Deputy chief minister Nitin Patel on Thursday said that the educated people of the country who are opposing the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) are blind to the reality behind the changes in the citizenship law.

He further said that people with vested interests were trying to mislead others about CAA. Patel said this at the Gujarat University campus on Thursday, at an event to pay tribute to Subhash Chandra Bose, on his birth anniversary.

“Many are seeking freedom. I request PM Narendra Modi to open the country’s borders for some time so that such people can go wherever they want,” he said adding that such people (who seek freedom) “lack mental capacity”.

About the protests against CAA and the all-India National Register of Citizens (NRC) in Ahmedabad recently, Patel said he had no issues with students protesting outside the Indian Institute of Management . “But I have an issue with their parents for not giving proper guidance to their children,” he said.

Title: Teachers reveal the sad news to Kerala kid who survived Nepal tragedy
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Madhav, the lone survivor of Ranjith Kumar's family, is clearly oblivious to what he has lost for ever, even a... Read More

KOZHIKODE: They all have inhaled a gas which made them go to a deep sleep. They will not wake up again and have gone to be with God. You should not try to wake them up when you see them tomorrow and should give them a parting kiss — two days after the death of his parents and younger brother in the Nepal resort tragedy , seven-year-old Madhav, the lone surviving member of his family, was told about his grievous loss by the teachers and a counsellor from his school on Thursday.

Young Madhav stared at them listless for some time and broke down in tears later.

The four-member team from Silver Hills School , including the principal and the class teacher of Madhav, broke the news to the child at his relative’s house next to Madhav’s maternal house at Mukavoor in the afternoon. Madhav had arrived at his home in the early hours of Thursday and was expecting his parents and brother to arrive on Friday.

“It was a heart-wrenching moment for all of us and we were all moved to tears. Madhav stood silent for some time and later he cried. He seemed to have somewhat understood that he has lost his parents for ever. We all consoled him and made him feel that we are all with him and later brought him a new bicycle to cheer him up,” Nikhil MC, cousin of Madhav’s mother Indu Lakshmi said.

On getting the new cycle, Madhav was upbeat and went around showing it off to his friends and relatives and riding it, seemingly forgetting about his loss for the moment.

Madhav’s class teacher Simmi S Nair said that they revealed the news of demise of his parents and brother to Madhav indirectly as being a child he cannot fully understand the concept of death.

Relatives said till then Madhav was thinking that his parents will be coming back the next day and he had told his cousins that they will be bringing chocolates, which he will share with them.

Madhav told his teachers that his parents were near him when he went to sleep at the Nepal resort and that when he woke up in the morning he had cried after finding that they were not around. Madhav also told the teachers that his father’s friend Ram uncle took him to a nearby room where he saw his parents and others all lying in the bed and that they were then taken to the hospital.

Title: Natural gas pipeline likely by end of March: Gail
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The work site beside Netravathi River between Innoli and Arkula where GAIL India is laying the Kochi-Koottanad... Read More

MANGALURU: The 438km Kochi-Koottanad-Mangaluru re-gasified liquefied natural gas (RLNG) pipeline that GAIL India Ltd is laying could be commissioned by March this year. Completion of this line will help GAIL India Ltd commence RLNG supply to industries and other stakeholders. This comes after GAIL failed to meet the September 2018 deadline due to issues in laying the pipeline across the Chandragiri and Nethravathi rivers.

GAIL had awarded the contract to lay the 111-km pipeline in north Kerala and Karnataka at an estimated cost of Rs 160 crore in August 2017. Work on laying the pipeline across the Nethravathi to a length of 410 metres between Innoli and Arkula should be completed by February 15, said Tony Mathew, general manager, GAIL, Kochi. The company adopted cut and cover method to lay the pipeline beneath the riverbeds with help of cofferdams

GAIL’s latest attempt in May to complete the crossing was futile, Mathew told TOI on Thursday. We faced a big challenge in crossing the Chandragiri River that is abutted by steep hills on both sides and thickly populated areas. We had to adopt drilling technology from hill to hill as it was difficult to move machinery to the river bank. At the present pace, we should complete the Chandragiri crossing by February-end, Tony Mathew said.

Workers executing the pipeline work at the Nethravati worksite at Innoli-side said the welded pipeline has been laid 6 metres below the riverbed almost up to the middle of the Nethravathi River. “We hope to complete the rest of the work by February 15,” they said. GAIL at the same time has taken up work on RLNG terminal on Arkula-side to pump gas towards Malavoor and further towards the terminal near Mangalore Chemicals and Fertilisers.

Kochi city is already deriving benefits of clean fuel, Mathew said. Most autorickshaws and taxis have been converted to use compressed natural gas as alternative fuel. Autorickshaws derive mileage of at least 40 km/kg. City gas distribution in Mangaluru with CNG as auto fuel will take time as the contractor has to lay the distribution pipelines across the city. The pipeline is designed to transport 16 million cubic metres of RLNG, he said.

Title: Specify date and time for debate, VS Ugrappa tells Amit Shah
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Former MP VS Ugrappa said that he was willing to take on Union home minister Amit Shah in a debate on CAA

HUBBALLI: Responding to Union home minister Amit Shah ’s challenge to the BJP’s political opponents to a public debate on the Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ), former MP and senior Congress member VS Ugrappa on Thursday announced his readiness for a verbal joust with the former.

A confident Ugrappa asked the BJP to merely specify the date, place and time, and he would come prepared to take on any senior member of the saffron party. “Let Shah or Prime Minister Narendra Modi or Union minister for parliamentary affairs Pralhad Joshi step forward to participate in the debate on the controversial Act,” said Ugrappa.

During the ‘Jan Jagran’ rally in Hubballi, Shah had invited former president of the All India Congress Committee (AICC) Rahul Gandhi for a debate with Joshi. “I would ask leaders of the BJP to first face leaders such as myself before they take on Rahul, who is a tall leader. If Shah is really interested in a debate on CAA, let the BJP decide on a date, and we will be ready,” said Ugrappa.

Stepping up his attack on Modi and Shah, Ugrappa called the duo progenies of ‘Shani’ (a Demigod in the Hindu pantheon believed to bring misfortune). “Under Modi’s leadership, the country is gradually moving towards a dictatorship. Both Shah and the PM appear to be bent on destroying the spirit of the Constitution, and the secular fabric of our country,” rued the former MP.

Reiterating the Congress’ stance against the CAA, Ugrappa said that the Act discriminated between people on the basis of faith, and violated many articles of the Constitution. “The Modi government has failed on multiple fronts and meet the expectations of the people,” said Ugrappa.

The former MP was also critical of the BS Yediyurappa-led government for the declining law-and-order situation in the state, of which the bomb scare at the Mangaluru airport was an example. “It reflects the failure of the intelligence wing,” said Ugrappa.

Former MP IG Sanadi, and other Congress members such as Anil Kumar Patil and Altaf Halwoor were among those present at the press conference with Ugrappa.

Title: Six Karnataka Air Squadron resumes NCC air flying in Mangaluru
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The 6 Karnataka Air Squadron of NCC on Thursday started giving its junior cadets a unique opportunity to take ... Read More

MANGALURU: In a move aimed at giving wings to the dreams of air wing National Cadet Corps (NCC) cadets, the 6 Karnataka Air Squadron of NCC on Thursday started giving its junior cadets a unique opportunity to take to the skies. It is almost after a gap of more than 15 years that this NCC Air Squadron has again started this activity using Pipistrel Virus-D aircraft, for which senior air wing cadets had to go either to Bengaluru or Belagavi.

With Colonel A K Sharma, group commander, Mangalore group HQ of NCC, taking the lead to resume NCC flying in this coastal city, it was left to Group Captain A G Srinivasan who is commanding the 6 Karnataka Air Squadron to pilot this twin-seater aircraft with NCC junior wing cadets joining him for the sortie. The directorate-general of NCC has issued this Pipistrel Virus-D aircraft to the Karnataka and Goa Directorate of NCC.

Group Captain Srinivasan told TOI that it was a historic moment for the 42 junior air wing cadets undergoing their annual training camp to undertake this air experience sortie on board the aircraft that can fly to height of 13,000 feet. “Due to constraints, these sorties on an average, last anywhere between five to seven minutes,” he said, adding in the odd chance that the aircraft must hover due to the movement of other commercial aircraft, the ride becomes a bit longer.

These air sorties, also referred to as joyrides, are mandatory for cadets appearing for their A certificate. Such cadets should have passed their written test based on a syllabus, and the flying part is the practical aspect, he said. Resumption of NCC air flying at Mangaluru is also the result of efforts of earlier commanding officers of the air squadron, Group Captain Srinivasan said, hoping that flying such sorties could spur the cadets to go on and join the Indian Air Force.

Title: Relentless opposition to CAA only way to get law repealed, says former bureaucrat
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

DHARWAD: Exhorting the citizenry to sustain the momentum of the agitation against the controversial Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), former bureaucrat Kannan Gopinath on Thursday said, “Continuing this protest is the only way we can get the CAA repealed, and prevent the National Register of Citizens (NRC) from being implemented.”

Gopinath, participating in a symposium organised by Left parties and other like-minded organisations at the Karnataka Vidyavardhaka Sangha, said that the people needed to be a proactive part of the democratic polity. “The people’s voice must be heard in a democracy. So it is vital the people intensify the stir against CAA, NRC and the National Population Register (NPR) to keep up the pressure on the government. We must remember that the Emergency ended not because of an order issued by the Supreme Court but relentless opposition from the people,” said Gopinath.

Founder-president of the Samaj Parivartan Samudaya SR Hiremath hearkened back to the days of the Nav Nirman Movement launched by freedom fighter Jayaprakash Narayan , and opined that there was a need for a similar campaign against the CAA, NRC and NPR. “The participation of large number of women, students and other youngsters in the protests has raised my hopes of such a mass movement eventualising again,” Hiremath said.

Meanwhile, activist Ramanjanappa Aldalli questioned the Supreme Court’s reluctance to consider cases filed against the CAA, NRC and NPR. “The BJP-led NDA government is trying to make it appear as though the protest against these laws is associated with one particular community. The Congress, in its 50-year-rule over India, tried to divide the country along communal lines, while the BJP has done more in this direction in a mere five-and-a-half years. It is important for the people to continue protests against the Centre, but it is equally important that we don’t allow political parties eyeing electoral dividends to hijack the movement,” Aldalli said.

Ramzan Darga, Dr MI Sheikh, Isabella Xavier, MM Haveripet, Laxman Bakkai were among those who participated in the symposium.

Title: India’s largest tricolour in Belagavi shrinks, residents upset
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

The National Flag, fluttering at a height of 110m, was spread across 9,600sqft. The Belagavi City Corporation ... Read More

BELAGAVI: It was the pride of Belagavi, the 9,600sqft national tricolour , the tallest in the country, fluttering at the Kote Kere front.

Now, the Belagavi City Corporation has decided to reduce the size of the flag that was erected on a 110-meter-tall flag pole. The size will be reduced to 5,400 sqft. And, residents here are understandably upset.

The 350-kg used to be hoisted every day. However, hoisting was discontinued after the flag was reportedly damaged in the inclement weather.

The flagpole was erected at Fort Lake, famously called Kote Kere in March 2018. A 10hp motor costing Rs 1.62 crore was used to hoist the flag. The flag had become a tourist attraction.

Assistant executive engineer, Mahantesh N who is privy to the development said the flag size will be reduced to 5,400 sqft. The corporation has decided to start hoisting the flag from January 26. Four flags at Rs 75,000 each have been stitched by a Mumbai-based company. These flags will be hoisted on rotation. The flag will be hoisted every day for a week on trial basis. If it withstands the vagaries of the weather, it will be hoisted every day. However, if it is damaged once gain then hoisting will be discontinued.

Speaking to TOI, City Corporation commissioner Jagadish H K said he will hold talks with the flag manufacturer as to how the flag can last longer.

Title: Accused used public transport to mask unlawful activities: Police
Content:
This story is from January 24, 2020

Accused Aditya Rao being brought to court in Mangaluru on Thursday

MANGALURU: Aditya Rao ,36, an engineering and management graduate and the mastermind behind the bomb scare at Mangalore International Airport(MIA), preferred to use public transport as he thought it would make it harder for the authorities to detect his unlawful activities.

Aditya Rao, a resident of Mannapalla in Manipal, Udupi, had surrendered before the police in Bengaluru on Thursday, and was later brought to Mangaluru by the authorities. Police sources said that the accused had used public transport extensively, as it would make it harder for the authorities to trace him. “Aditya, who zeroed in on MIA as his target, had travelled in and around the airport more than four times to do a recce. He used public transport to travel to MIA. On January 20, the day he dropped the bag with the explosive material at the airport, he travelled from Karkala in a private service bus to State Bank bus stand in the city, and later boarded a bus going to Bajpe. He boarded an autorickshaw to reach the airport,” the source added.

He continued to use public transport even after dropping the explosive-material-laden backpack at the airport, and fled from Mangaluru city by using a KSRTC bus. He went to Sirsi and Shivamogga before finally going to Bengaluru. “Aditya learnt through the media that the police is searching for him and that he is the prime suspect in the case. The CCTV grabs of him were displayed across the media, and as he knew that he had less chance to escape, he boarded a bus to Bengaluru and surrendered before the police,” said P S Harsha , city police commissioner.

Why did he take up a hotel job ?

Aditya, who earlier worked in white collar jobs, which included MNCs, insurance companies and in the automobile sector, later shifted to blue collar jobs. He worked as a security guard in various colleges in Mangaluru and Bengaluru, before moving to the hotel industry. Aditya received a BE in mechanical engineering from a prestigious college in Mysuru and an MBA in marketing and operations from a college in Manipal. He worked for a brief period in all firms where he was recruited. He had forged his experience certificate when he joined an automobile company in Bidadi, which he quit in a few months.

PS Harsha said that he started blue collar jobs from 2012, starting with working as a security guard and later shifted to the hotel industry. “He found the hotel industry to be conducive as he felt less pressure. Apart from it, it provided him three meals a day and free stay. The investigators learnt that he worked in more than eight food joints including American fast food joints. He had joined a restaurant in Mangaluru in the first week of December, and quit the same on January 18. Three days before the incident, he joined another hotel in Karkala as a steward.

Device used was an IED: PS Harsha

Clearing the air about the contents of the bag, which was dropped by the accused at Mangalore International Airport, P S Harsha, city police commissioner, said it was an improvised explosive device (IED). “It was a technically sound device and the same was revealed by Aditya during primary investigation. However, I will not disclose about the contents due to security reasons,” he said.

Harsha added that Forensic Science Laboratory (FSL) tests will be able to give a more clear idea about whether the bomb was linked to a timer or not, and other related details.

Mentally unstable? Harsha says no comment

When the city police commissioner was asked whether the accused was mentally unstable , he chose not to answer, and said that the issue is related to a national threat to the country and an act of sabotage. The police have taken it seriously, he said.
